questions.text: 1. A patient diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease is being treated with sucralfate. Which of the following adverse effects can be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Gastric bezoar can be seen in a patient taking sucralfate. Sucralfate produces a viscous gel that has a ‘sticky nature’. The sticky nature may be responsible for gastric bezoars, particularly in those with gastroparesis.

Sucralfate is composed of a sulfate of sucrose with Al(OH)3. It undergoes cross-linking to produce a viscous polymer that sticks to epithelial cells and ulcers in acidic environments. It inhibits hydrolysis of the mucosal proteins by pepsin.

It is used in the prophylaxis of stress ulcers, and in conditions where mucosal ulceration is not responding to acid suppression.

Adverse effects of sucralfate include constipation and bezoar formation. It may inhibit absorption of other drugs like digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics due to the viscous layer formed in the stomach. Hence it should be taken at least 2 hours after administration if these drugs.

The other options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency and increased risk of bone fractures are side effects of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). However, their clinical significance has not been proven yet. Hypergastrinemia is more commonly seen with PPIs than H2 receptor antagonists.

questions.text: 2. The image given below is the structure of aggrecan, which is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage. Identify the three glycosaminoglycans which are labeled as A, B, and C respectively.

choices.text: Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and chondroitin sulfate
Chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratan sulfate
Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and heparan sulfate
Heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulphate, and keratan sulfate

questions.solution:
Aggrecan contains glycosaminoglycans hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, and keratan sulfate along with link and core proteins. It is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage.



Various glycosaminoglycans include: 

* Hyaluronic acid: Present in the extracellular matrix of nearly all tissues, but more concentrated in the skin and umbilical cord, bone, cartilage, joints (synovial fluid), vitreous humor in the eye, as well as in embryonic tissues. It plays a role in cell migration during morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid together with chondroitin sulfates in the cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

* Chondroitin Sulfates (Chondroitin 4-Sulfate & Chondroitin 6-Sulfate): The repeating disaccharide units are GlcUA and GalNAc. They maintain the structure of the extracellular matrix and are located in endochondral bone and cartilage. They are also found in high amounts in the ECM of the central nervous system. In addition to their structural function, they act as signaling molecules in the prevention of the repair of nerve endings after injury.

* Keratan Sulfates I & II: They consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units. They are found in the cornea and in the cartilage. Keratin sulfate I or II are differentiated based on the different linkage to the core protein. They play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in the proteoglycan composition are seen in corneal scars.

* Heparin: Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in the liver, lung, and skin and is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI. Its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin.

* Heparan Sulfate: It is found on many extracellular cell surfaces. The predominant uronic acid is GlcUA. Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells as receptors, and may also participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication. It is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney and determines the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.

* Dermatan Sulfate: Dermatan sulfate has a widespread distribution in tissues, and is the main GAG in the skin. It may also play a part in blood coagulation, wound repair, and resistance to infection.

questions.text: 3. A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joints for the past week. He has a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. On examination, he has conjunctivitis and the following skin lesions are seen. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute arthritis and conjunctivitis following a recent infection and the given image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica point to the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is non-purulent arthritis following enteric or urogenital infection. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis.

It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive, involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle.

Extraarticular manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

* Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.

* Oral ulcers: superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.

* Circinate balanitis refers to vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis is commonly seen in young adults. It has a strong association with the HLA-B27 genetic marker. Patients will present with lower lumbar back pain which is insidious in onset. It is accompanied by low-back morning stiffness that improves with activity.



X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis:



Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting, onycholysis, dactylitis, and enthesitis. There is pronounced telescoping of the digits. Axial involvement may also occur.

Radiological features include:

* Pencil-in-cup deformity at the distal interphalangeal joint, as shown in the image below.

* Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation known as whiskering.



Option C: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved.

Pearl PM1728: Uveitis Associated with HLA B-27-associated Arthritis

* Ankylosing spondylitis

* Psoriatic arthritis

* Reiter’s syndrome

* Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (previously known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis)

4. A 25-year-old patient was scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Endotracheal intubation was performed after placing the patient under general anesthesia. Sequentially arrange the following steps of intubation from first to last:
* Introduction of laryngoscope
* Check breath sounds with a stethoscope
* Neck extension and flexion
* Inflation of tube cuff
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps is 3-1-4-2.

Correct positioning of the patient is essential for adequate glottis exposure during laryngoscopy. The patient is typically placed in the sniffing position with:

* Moderate head elevation (7-9 cm above the surgical table)

* Atlantooccipital joint extension

* Flexion of the lower portion of the cervical spine by resting the head on a pillow

The image below shows the following steps of endotracheal intubation:

* Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)

* Symmetric chest rise

* Bilateral breath sounds

* Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium

* Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

* Large exhaled tidal volumes

* Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: 5. A researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the harmful effect of UV radiation on human skin. He observed that UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms corrects this particular defect?
questions.solution:
The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.



Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair, leading to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As time passes these lesions become permanent. As the age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. Since deeper structures like eyelids, cornea, and lens are shielded, are lesser affected.

XP is ultimately fatal. Early detection of skin lesions and their management (prevention of exposure to UV rays) prolongs life.

questions.text:
6. An ultrasound scan of a 35-year-old woman revealed a unilocular cyst of 5 cm in her ovary. She is asymptomatic. She does not have a family history of breast, ovarian, or colon cancer. She has not received treatment for infertility in the past. CA-125 levels are 35 U/mL. What is the next best step in her treatment plan?

OCPs - oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a functional cyst in the ovary. Among the given options, the next best step in her treatment plan is to follow up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs. 

A functional cyst is usually asymptomatic, unilocular, and contains clear fluid unless a hemorrhage occurs. In the childbearing period, around 70% of ovarian tumors are functional. They usually regress spontaneously within a few months. It is usually between 3-7 cm in size.

A simple, unilocular cyst of less than 7 cm should be observed. It usually regresses within 4-6 months. Oral contraceptive pills can be prescribed for 3-4 months to women of child-bearing age to hasten its regression. 

A follow-up ultrasound can pick up a persistent cyst. On ultrasound, if any cyst persists for longer than 3 months or its size increases to more than 7 cm, the possibility of malignancy should be investigated. 

Before opting for surgical management, it is important to be certain that the tumor is benign and the other ovary healthy by frozen-section biopsy.

Laparotomy is advised for tumors more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

In a young woman, in order to conserve the healthy ovary, the ovarian cyst should be enucleated (cystectomy). If this is not possible, ovariotomy should be done. 

Laparoscopic cystectomy–ovariotomy is a minimally invasive surgery done for small ovarian cysts. The other options of treatment are laparoscopy/ ultrasound-guided aspiration and removal of the cyst.

Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are recommended in peri-menopausal women, even in the case of benign and unilocular cysts.

questions.text: 7. Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast drain into all of the following group of lymph nodes except:
questions.solution:
Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast do not drain into parasternal nodes.

Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast drains into Axillary group of lymph nodes which includes

* Lateral

* Anterior

* Posterior

* Central

* Apical group of lymph nodes

Lymphatic drainage:

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into the axillary and internal mammary lymph nodes.

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one third of breast.

The Axillary nodes receive 85 per cent of the drainage:

* Lateral - along the axillary vein-drains most of upper limb

* Anterior - along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast (1st relay station for lymph)

* Posterior - along the subscapular vessels.

* Central - embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla.

* Apical - It receives the efferents from all the other groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.

* Interpectoral (rotters node) a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.



Pearl PM0194: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: 8. The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

* Jejunal branches

* Ileal branches

* Middle colic artery

* Right colic artery

* Ileocolic artery

* Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

* The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).

* This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: 9. A patient was diagnosed to have a deficiency of the enzyme which catalyzes the given metabolic step. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry is the screening test of choice in newborns
Can present with macrocephaly and intellectual disability
Mainstay of treatment is low phenylalanine diet

questions.solution:
The enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine is phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria presents with microcephaly and intellectual disability.

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism, due to the deficiency of an enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body fluids and the brain. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones, namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.

Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odour in the skin and urine in PKU.

Other characteristic clinical findings include:

* Affected infants are lighter in complexion

* Neurological abnormalities like seizures, spasticity and hyperreflexia

* Microcephaly and growth retardation

Tandem mass spectroscopy is the screening method of choice and a low phenylalanine diet forms the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: 11. A 62-year-old woman presented with complaints of indigestion, dysphagia, and nausea for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed rugal flattening in the gastric antrum and a biopsy revealed the following on histopathological examination. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?

choices.text: Loss of function in APC gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and biopsy findings are suggestive of the diagnosis as diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma is caused due to loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene, which encodes for E-cadherin.

The biopsy specimen shows signet ring cells. This along with the presence of dysphagia, dyspepsia, nausea, anemia, and endoscopic findings of loss of rugal folds is suggestive of the diagnosis as diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma

Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the stomach and constitutes more than 90% of all gastric cancers. Based on the gross appearance, the gastric adenocarcinoma is classified into two types:

* Diffuse type, which is characterized by infiltrates and thickening of the gastric wall.

* Intestinal type, which is characterized by bulky masses or an ulcerated infiltrative tumor

Diffuse adenocarcinoma:

In diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma, the wall of the stomach is thickened and firm. When the large areas of the stomach are involved, diffuse rugal flattening and a rigid, thickened wall may impart a leather bottle appearance to which the term linitis plastica. A barium swallow image of linitis plastica is given below.



There are no identified precursor lesions for this subtype and the prevalence is the same in men and women.

Majority of the gastric cancers are not hereditary. However, in some cases with a family history, the condition is usually associated with loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene, which encodes for E-cadherin. The loss of E-cadherin plays a key role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer. The invading tumor cells induce an extensive desmoplastic reaction that stiffens the gastric wall. Signet ring cells are seen on biopsy, they are named so because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumor cells.

Intestinal-type gastric cancer:

This subtype develops from precursor lesions including flat dysplasia and adenomas. The mean age of presentation is 55 years, and twice as common in men compared to women. Loss of function in the APC gene (Option C) and gain of function in the β-catenin gene are involved in the development of intestinal-type gastric cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Translocation (11;18) is associated with extranodal gastric MALToma. Patients generally present with dyspepsia, epigastric pain, hematemesis, and weight loss. Histologically, the diagnostic feature is the infiltration of neoplastic lymphocytes into the gastric glands to form lymphoepithelial lesions as shown below.



Option B: Excessive secretion of TGF-α is seen in Ménétrier's disease. It is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and irregular enlargement of gastric rugae in the fundus and body as shown below. The antrum is spared.



There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Microscopically, there is hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

questions.text: 12. A stool sample was taken from a patient with severe diarrhoea and microscopy revealed small curved Gram negative rods with darting motility. The sample was cultured in Skirrow's medium and colonies appeared within 48 hours. A decision was taken to start an antibiotic due to worsening disease. Which of the given antibiotics is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for Campylobacter sp.-induced diarrhea is Azithromycin.

The given clinical scenario describes an individual with severe diarrhea who had a stool sample taken which on microscopy showed small curved Gram negative rods with darting motility. Culture of the sample in Skirrow's medium, a selective medium showed the development of colonies in 48 hours, which is consistent with a diagnosis of Campylobacter as the etiological agent responsible for the diarrhea.

Campylobacter is a gram-negative, slender, spirally curved rod which is a non-sporing and motile microaerophilic and occasionally thermophilic bacterium. It shows seagull wing appearance on microscopy. The species known to cause diarrhea are C.jejuni, C.lari, and C.coli, of which C.jejuni is the most common pathogen implicated. C. fetus causes extraintestinal disseminated disease.

Skirrow's and Butzler's medium and microscopic appearance of Campylobacter is given below:





The incubation period is 1-7 days. Usual clinical manifestations are watery diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The disease is normally self-limiting and spontaneously resolves in a few days. C. fetus is a vasculotropic bacterium with several extraintestinal manifestations like endocarditis, septic thrombophlebitis, etc. 

Most notable complications are reactive arthritis and Guillian Barre syndrome. The latter is believed to occur due to molecular mimicry of some sialylated lipopolysaccharides present in C.jejuni. Reactive arthritis is common in HLA-B27 serotype individuals.

Diagnosis is done by taking the stool sample and subjecting it to microscopy and culture which is the gold standard. Adjunctive tests that have now superseded microscopy for routine diagnosis are PCR and MALDI-TOF. The stool is typical for inflammatory diarrhea and must not be confused with inflammatory bowel disease.

The mainstay of treatment is oral and IV fluid and electrolyte replacement. Antimicrobials are usually not required, but conditions necessitating antibiotic treatment are:

* High fever

* Bloody and/or severe diarrhea

* Persistence for > 1 week

* Worsening of symptoms

* C.fetus disseminated/extraintestinal infections

* Any bacteremia with systemic manifestations

* Immunocompromised 

The agent of choice is Azithromycin as 500mg once daily for 3 days or a single 1 gram dose is given. Other drugs which can be used are ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin, but resistance to both has been on the rise and must be given cautiously.

The commonest agent, C.jejuni, is intrinsically resistant to Trimethoprim(Option B), Penicillin(Option C), and several beta-lactams (like cefazolin-Option D), and hence these agents are not used in documented Campylobacter infections. Antimotility agents are also contraindicated and may cause toxic megacolon if used concurrently.

questions.text: 13. Which of the following molecules helps in diapedesis through the endothelium during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

* Lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:

* Margination: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of stasis of blood flow.

* Rolling: Leukocytes start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium.

* Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. 

* Transmigration of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium.

* Migration towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues.

Selectins, integrins, and their ligands are the most important proteins involved in adhesion and migration. Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on endothelium, and P-selectins present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins. Chemokines that are produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This in turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.

This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.

Diapedesis occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text:
14. A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. On physical examination, she has a positive Brudzinski sign, and neck stiffness is noted. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
* Clear, colorless appearance
* White blood cell count: 100 cells/µL (predominantly lymphocytes)
* Protein concentration: 60 mg/dL
* Glucose concentration: 70 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The CSF findings and clinical features in this case suggest viral meningitis, which typically presents with pleocytosis, normal or mildly elevated protein (20-80 mg/dL), normal glucose levels, and slightly elevated opening pressure. The total CSF cell count usually ranges from 25 to 500 cells/microliter, predominantly lymphocytes.

Other options:

A) In bacterial meningitis, classic CSF abnormalities include polymorphonuclear (PMN) leukocytosis (>100 cells/μL in 90% of cases), decreased glucose concentration (<40 mg/dL), elevated protein concentration (>45 mg/dL in 90%), and increased opening pressure (>180 mmH₂O in 90%). Additionally, CSF bacterial cultures are positive in >70% of patients, and Gram’s stain identifies organisms in >60% of cases.

C) The characteristic CSF abnormalities in fungal meningitis are a mononuclear or lymphocytic pleocytosis, an increased protein concentration, and a decreased glucose concentration.

D) The classic CSF abnormalities in tuberculous meningitis are elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis (10–500 cells/μL), elevated protein concentration in the range of 100–500 mg/dl, and decreased glucose concentration in the range of 20–40 mg/dL.

questions.text: 15. A male patient presented with a fracture of the shaft of the femur following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. Fat embolism is suspected. Based on which criteria would he be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism syndrome is diagnosed based on Gurd's criteria.

Fat embolism is caused by the fat globules originating from the bone marrow following the fracture of long bones. Clinical features of fat embolism are usually seen within 72 hours. They include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness.

There is no specific test for diagnosis. However, sputum and urine analysis to look for fat globules and monitoring of blood pO2 are done. Management of fat embolism is mostly supportive, with oxygen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Garden classification is used for fracture neck of the femur. It is based on the degree of displacement of the fracture.

Option C: Modified Wells Criteria is used to predict the likelihood of pulmonary embolism.

Option D: CURB-65 scoring is used to assess the severity of illness in a case of pneumonia, especially community-acquired pneumonia.

Pearl PM1500: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria

* Petechial rash

* Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes

* CNS depression.

Minor criteria

* Tachycardia

* Pyrexia

* Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)

* Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)

* Acute thrombocytopenia

* Acute decrease in hemoglobin

* Fat globules in sputum

* Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text:
16. A 54-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of swollen fingers, heartburn, and occasional joint pains. On examination, the skin over her hands is shiny, taut, and thickened with non-pitting edema. Distal skin creases are absent. Movement of the hand is limited and there appears to be some muscle weakness. Autoantibody assays showed the presence of topoisomerase I antibodies and Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. Which among the following features are less commonly seen in this variant of the disease?
* Esophageal involvement
* Skin involvement
* Scleroderma renal crisis
* Ischemic ulcers on digits
* Interstitial lung disease
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with positive ANA antibodies, topoisomerase I antibodies, and Anti-RNA polymerase I and III antibodies is diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Esophageal involvement and ischemic ulcers on digits are less commonly seen in this variety of the disease. 

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder of connective tissue resulting in fibrosis of the skin, internal organs, and vasculature. It is characterized by Raynaud’s phenomenon, ischemia of the digits, sclerodactyly, and cardiac, lung, gut, and renal disease. The peak age of onset is between the fourth and fifth decades of life.

It is divided into:

* Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (30% of cases) - poor prognosis

* Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (70% of cases)

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

* Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.

* Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

* Anti-RNA polymerase I and III antibodies - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

* Anti centromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: 17. A 60-year-old female who had recently undergone a lower limb surgery and is currently on bed rest presents to the emergency department with severe leg pain and left leg swelling. On examination, her left leg is swollen and tender to palpation. Blood tests reveal elevated D-dimer and an eGFR of 40 ml/min. What is appropriate pharmacological management?

choices.text: Rapid anticoagulation using unfractionated heparin followed by long term anticoagulation using enoxaparin
Rapid anticoagulation using unfractionated heparin followed by long term Warfarin anticoagulation via bridge therapy for prophylaxis
Rapid anticoagulation using Enoxaparin followed by enoxaparin weekly subcutaneous inj for prophylaxis
Rapid anticoagulation using enoxaparin  followed by long term warfarin anticoagulation using bridge therapy for prophylaxis

questions.solution:
The history, examination, and d-dimer point to deep vein thrombosis and chronic kidney disease, which is appropriately treated with rapid anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin and long-term anticoagulation with warfarin.

The history of unilateral lower limb swelling and pain in a patient who is bedridden following surgery is most indicative of Deep vein thrombosis. DVT requires rapid anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparins like enoxaparin. Enoxaparin is not preferred in our patient because she suffers from CKD, which necessitates a dose adjustment and increases the risk of bleeding.

Warfarin is used for long-term anticoagulation therapy to prevent recurrence as the patient has risk factors for DVT. Warfarin is metabolized by the liver, so it is safe for use in CKD.

questions.text: 18. A boy was brought with complaints of pain over the left flank, associated with fever with chills with leukocytosis. The CT scan of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with flank pain, fever, leucocytosis, and a CT scan showing a heterogenous, hypodense collection in the psoas muscle is suggestive of a psoas abscess.

Note that in the given axial section, the pus collection lies posteromedial to the kidneys and immediately lateral to the vertebral column, affecting the psoas major muscle. Hence a renal pathology (options A and D) is ruled out.

Psoas abscess is a type of retroperitoneal abscess. It occurs due to a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment due to an infection. Tuberculosis of the spine is the leading cause of psoas abscess in resource-limited countries. Because of the decline of M. tuberculosis as a major pathogen in resource-rich countries, psoas abscess in these places is mostly secondary to a contiguous spread of infection from the gastrointestinal or urinary tract. It can also be seen secondary to Crohn's disease.

Clinical features include back pain and fever. A soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin may be present, because of the tracking of the pus along the iliopsoas muscle. Pain on passive extension of the hip due to spasm of the psoas muscle may be present (positive psoas sign).

A CT scan helps in the diagnosis and delineating the possible source of the infection. It is treated with percutaneous CT-guided drainage under antibiotic cover. Surgical intervention may be required if these are unsuccessful.

The image given below shows the hypodense collection in the psoas muscle in a coronal CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, suggestive of psoas abscess.

questions.text: 19. An elderly male presents with an autosomal dominant syndrome, where the gene responsible for the illness is found on chromosome 3p and acts as an inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors. Which of the following features will this patient present with?

choices.text: Renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the CNS and retina, pheochromocytoma
Neurofibromas, neurofibrosarcoma, acute myelogenous leukemia, brain tumors
Pancreatic islet cell tumors, parathyroid hyperplasia, pituitary adenomas
Gastrointestinal carcinomas, breast cancer, testicular cancer, benign pigmentation of the skin and mucosa

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Von Hippel Lindau's syndrome caused due to germline loss-of-function mutations of the VHL gene present on chromosome 3p that acts as an inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors. It is an autosomal dominant syndrome where the patient will present with renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type), hemangioblastomas of the CNS and retina and pheochromocytoma.

Mutations in the VHL gene, prevent the ubiquitination and degradation of hypoxia-inducible transcription factor 1α (HIF1α), even under normoxic conditions, and are accordingly associated with increased levels of angiogenic growth factors and alterations in cellular metabolism that favour tumour cell growth.

Option C: Pancreatic islet cell tumors, parathyroid hyperplasia, pituitary adenomas are associated with Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 due to MEN1gene on chromosome 11q13.

questions.text: 20. A patient is planned to undergo tympanoplasty. In which type of tympanoplasty is the graft placed in contact with the structure marked in the given image, according to Wullstein's classification?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the incus. Type II tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus is eroded due to middle ear disease and the graft is placed on the incus.

The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear. It has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic and can be identified by the long process that hangs vertically and attaches to the head of the stapes.

Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane. It involves ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicular chain) with or without myringoplasty.

The main objective of the procedure is the eradication of middle ear disease with the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

Myringoplasty is the term given for the closure of perforation of pars tensa of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from the external ear.

Type | Defect and repair Type I | Perforation of tympanic membrane which is repaired with a graft (myringoplasty) Type II | Perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus. Type III | Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head (myringostapediopexy) Type IV | Only the footplate of stapes is present. The graft is placed between the oval and round windows on the stapes footplate Type V | The stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functioning. The graft is placed in contact with a new window created on the fenestra in the horizontal semicircular canal

questions.text: 21. A 35-year-old female presents with a lump in the breast which is not associated with pain. An ultrasound-guided aspiration drains clear fluid. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Biopsy of the cyst wall and excision

questions.solution:
The given case scenario with the presence of a lump not associated with pain and drainage of clear fluid on aspiration indicates a diagnosis of breast cyst. Breast cyst is a benign condition of the breast and no further management is required.

Breast cyst comes under ANDI (Aberrations of Normal Development and Involution). It usually presents in women from 35-55 years of age as a painless lump. It may be solitary or multiple and bilateral. It is classified as a BIRADS 2 lesion. Ultrasound is done for diagnosis and Ultrasound-guided aspiration is done.

If the fluid drained is clear and not blood-stained, no further management is required. Cytological evaluation of fluid is not required. If there is some nodularity or the aspirate is blood-stained, a core biopsy or excision for histology is suggested.

questions.text: 22. A newborn baby has rashes over the face as shown below, microcephaly, bilateral cataracts, and sensory neural hearing loss. What is the most common type of cataract seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. The type of cataract seen in this condition is a nuclear pearly cataract. 

Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs due to the transplacental transmission of the virus from an infected mother to the fetus. The transmissibility is highest in the first trimester (<11 weeks).

Affected babies present with a triad of:

* Sensorineural deafness

* Cataracts- nuclear pearly cataracts

* Congenital heart disease- the most common is the patent ductus arteriosus.

Other important features are rashes over the body, salt and pepper retinopathy, and microcephaly. Some babies may develop meningoencephalitis following CRS.

It is diagnosed by the presence of IgM antibodies against rubella in the cord or neonatal blood. Administration of MMR vaccine in prepubertal and women who are about to get married can prevent the disease.

Pearl PM1450: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

* The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:

* Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome

* Congenital cataract

* Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus

* Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester

* Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness

* If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities

* Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

* Also called the German measles

* Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae

* Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash

* Droplet trasmission

* The incubation period is 2-3 weeks

* The rash appears on day 1

* Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx

* Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia

* The most serious complication is encephalitis

* Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: 23. A 56-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for a few weeks. On staining his sputum, gram-negative bacilli with the typical safety pin appearance were identified. Culture on Ashdown medium showed wrinkled, purple colonies. Which of the following could be the possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the patient, detection of gram-negative bacilli with safety pin appearance, and formation of wrinkled, purple colonies on culture are together suggestive of Whitmore's disease or melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Infection with B. pseudomallei is acquired by contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Melioidosis can be of two types:

* Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case fatality rate. 

* Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibodies and indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. 

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium.



Option B: Burkholderia mallei causes glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and persons working with/caring for horses. Acute infection presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration.

Option C: Burkholderia cepacia is an opportunist pathogen, usually seen in cases of cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease. It causes a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia (cepacia syndrome) in cystic fibrosis patients.

Option D: Paraburkholderia species do not cause human infection. They are beneficial to plants.

questions.text: 24. A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of hematuria, fever, and weight loss. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the left iliac fossa. Histopathological features of the mass are shown in the image below. Identify the false statement about this type of renal cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Most common type of renal cell carcinoma
Is associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
Commonly arise from distal convoluted tubules
May extend into the inferior vena cava

questions.solution:
The false statement about this type of renal cell carcinoma is that it arises from the distal convoluted tubules.

The given clinical vignette of a man in his 7th decade of life presenting with symptoms of hematuria, fever, and weight loss and examination showing a palpable mass in the left iliac fossa with the histopathological image given above is indicative of clear cell carcinoma.

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of renal cell cancer and the third most common of urological cancers.

Most of the cases are sporadic, but can also occur either in familial forms or in association with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. Nevertheless, all three forms are associated with the loss of sequence of the short arm of chromosome 3.

Those with VHL disease inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosomal band 3p25 and lose the second allele by somatic mutation. This VHL gene is involved in the majority of sporadic clear cell carcinomas. Cytogenetic abnormalities giving rise to loss of a segment on chromosome 3p that has the VHL gene are seen in sporadic renal cell cancers. The second, non-deleted allele is inactivated by a somatic mutation or hypermethylation. Thus, loss or inactivation of both copies of the VHL gene is the common underlying molecular abnormality in both sporadic and familial forms of clear cell carcinomas.

The VHL protein causes the degradation of hypoxia-induced factors (HIFs), which are transcription factors that contribute to carcinogenesis by stimulating the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) that helps drive tumour cell growth.

Histologically, they are composed of cells with clear cytoplasm. Most of them arise from the proximal tubular epithelium and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions. They are bright yellow-grey-white spherical masses of variable size that distort the renal outline.

The margins are sharply defined and confined within the renal capsule. In clear cell carcinoma, the growth pattern varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular (resembling tubules). The tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids.

One of the characteristic features of clear cell carcinoma is its tendency to grow as a solid column of cells that extend from the renal vein, up to the inferior vena cava, and sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.

questions.text:
25. A 33-year-old woman receiving treatment for infertility presented with abdominal pain and distension. On examination, her pulse was 130/min, blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation was 97 %. Per abdominal examination revealed ascites, and no mass was palpable. Ultrasonography of the pelvis is shown below. Which of the following measures are ineffective in the prevention of this condition?

1. Withholding of FSH dose prior to hCG

2. Increasing the FSH dose

3. Substitution of FSH with hCG

4. Withholding the hCG trigger

5. Withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone, hCG-Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). The given sonogram reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts. Increasing FSH dose and withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives have no role in preventing OHSS.

Strategies to avoid OHSS induction include :

* Decreasing follicular stimulation - Decreasing the FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone) dose

* Coasting- Withholding FSH administration for one or more days prior to the hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin) trigger injection 

* Prophylactic treatment with volume expanders during and after oocyte retrieval

* Substitution of hCG for FSH during the final days of ovarian stimulation.

* Low-dose hCG administration- this supports the maturation of larger ovarian follicles but causes atresia of small antral follicles, reducing the risk of OHSS.

* Withholding the hCG trigger - results in cycle cancellation. IVF should then be considered in this case.

* GnRH antagonist protocol: This would allow a single dose of GnRH agonist in place of hCG. The resulting endogenous LH surge then brings about the maturation of the follicle and oocyte

* Pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives is done to prevent cyst formation, improve the chances of ovulation induction, and reduce hyperstimulation.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

* Polycystic ovarian syndrome

* Young age

* High estradiol during ovulation induction

* Pregnancy

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

questions.text:
26. A middle-aged man developed severe pain abdomen and fever 3 days after undergoing surgery for bowel perforation. There is no dehiscence or discharge from the sutured wound seen. His blood pressure was 60/40mmHg and his intra-abdominal pressure was 35mmHg. The procedure in the given image was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?

IAP- Intrabdominal pressure
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is abdominal compartment syndrome.

The above clinical features of increase in intraabdominal pressure >35 mmHg without any wound dehiscence, discharge and the given image showing rapid decompression of the abdomen by letting out the bowel and covering it with a plastic bag (Bogota bag) are suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome.

Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) leading to organ dysfunction. The normal IAP is 5-7 mmHg. When the IAP is > 12 mmHg, it is termed intra-abdominal hypertension. Abdominal compartment syndrome occurs when the IAP is > 20 mmHg as in this clinical scenario.

Physiological changes in ACS are:

* Central nervous system- Increased intracranial pressure

* Respiratory system- Decreased compliance, increased airway pressures, pulmonary artery pressure, and central venous pressure

* Cardiovascular system- Decreased venous return, cardiac output, stroke volume, and increased systemic vascular resistance

* Renal system- Decreased renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and urine output

Grading of ACS:

* Grade I: 10-15 mmHg

* Grade II: 16-25 mmHg

* Grade III: 26-35 mmHg

* Grade IV: > 35 mmHg

Diagnosis is made by measuring IAP using a urinary bladder (Foley's catheter) or gastric catheter. CT scan, abdominal perfusion pressure, renal filtration gradient are some of the tests done to check organ dysfunction.

The primary goal of management is to reduce the IAP. So rapid decompression is done by opening the abdomen and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall using a mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag). After the resuscitation and management of the specific causes, a definite closure of the abdomen can be done by vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), split-skin graft, or prosthetic mesh.

Other options:

Option B- Meleney's synergistic gangrene of the abdominal wall is the post-operative infection due to microaerophilic streptococci, staphylococci and other anaerobes. It is characterized by sudden pain, redness, blackening, and gangrene of the skin with abdominal wall necrosis. It is most commonly seen in HIV, diabetes, and immunocompromised people. Treatment includes antibiotics like penicillins and metronidazole, excision of the gangrenous tissue till it bleeds, skin grafting and management of toxaemia, hyperbaric oxygen, and critical care.

Option C- Burst abdomen is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days. A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound. Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above.

Below is an image showing a burst abdomen.



Option D- Divarication of recti is the thinning of the linea alba in the epigastrium with protrusion of the abdominal wall with prominent edges of both recti. It becomes prominent on lifting the head from the bed. No treatment is required in the divarication of recti.

questions.text: 27. A 24-year old male patient presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.



Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.



Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.





Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Pearl PM2033: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.



Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.



Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.



Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.



Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.



Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.



Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).



Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

questions.text: 28. A medical intern attended a session conducted by the college on the topic ‘Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare’. Six specialists spoke on this topic, one after the other, and the intern asked a question at the end of the session. What method of communication was used in this session?
questions.solution:
Symposium method of communication was used in this session, where specialists spoke on the topic one after the other without any discussion.

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, and at the end, the audience is allowed to ask questions. There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other Methods of communication are: Individual approach | Group approach | Mass approach 1. Personal contact 2. Home visits 3. Personal letters | 1. Lectures 2. Demonstrations 3. Discussion methods

* Group discussions

* Panel discussion

* Symposium

* Workshop

* Conferences

* Seminars

* Roleplay | * TV

* Radio

* Newspaper

* Printed material

* Direct mailing

* Posters

* Health museums

* Health exhibitions

* Folk method

* Internet

Other options:

Option A: Panel discussion comprises 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. It has a chairman, a moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

Option C: Workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups, each with a chairman and a recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option D: Group discussion is a form of communication where multiple individuals come together to exchange ideas, discuss a topic, solve problems, or make decisions, considered very effective in health communication. The group usually includes 6-12 members interacting face to face, seated in a circle.

questions.text: 29. A patient presented to a primary care physician with complaints of depression. She takes a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. The physician added another anti-depressant following which she developed restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be added?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient who is on a Monoamine Oxidase (MAO) develops diarrhea, restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability which is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. The newly added drug must have been a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the given options, fluoxetine is an SSRI.

When an SSRI is administered along with an MAO-I, tramadol, and pethidine, plasma levels of serotonin are raised resulting in serotonin syndrome. Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include diarrhea, agitation, restlessness, rigidity, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, twitchings followed by convulsions, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death.

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Other options:

Option B: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant. Common side effects include anticholinergic symptoms, sedation, weight gain, and cardiac arrhythmias. TCAs given with MAO inhibitors can result in hypertensive crisis with excitement and hallucinations.

Option C: Mirtazapine acts by enhancing noradrenaline and 5-HT release. It helps patients with insomnia. Common side effects include increased appetite and weight gain. It doesn't cause sexual dysfunction.

Option D: Trazadone is also an atypical antidepressant. Common side effects include postural hypotension and priapism.

questions.text: 30. Which of the following changes occur if you exercise at high altitude?
questions.solution:
Rise in urinary bicarbonate level is observed if a person exercises at high altitude.

Adaptation at high Altitudes:

* The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.

* Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.

* This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing Respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.

* To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.

* Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: 31. A pregnant lady with a gestation of 8 weeks comes to your clinic. While examining her, you notice she has severe acne. She tells you she has been taking oral medication and was advised to avoid excessive sun exposure while taking this drug. Which of the following is not a potential teratogenic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Oral medication for acne is likely to be isotretinoin. Macrognathia is not a potential teratogenic effect of isotretinoin.

Vitamin A derivatives(isotretinoin, acitretin) belong amongst the drugs with high teratogenic effects. They result in retinoic acid embryopathy by inhibiting neural crest cell migration during embryogenesis. This causes cranial neural crest defects involving the central nervous system, face, thymus, and heart. 

Specific anomalies include

* Ventriculomegaly

* Maldevelopment of the facial bones and cranium

* Microtia or anotia

* Micrognathia

* Cleft palate

* Conotruncal heart defects

* Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia

Systemic retinoids are highly teratogenic and are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women, those planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding mothers. Two negative pregnancy tests (on separate occasions) are required for females of childbearing age before starting acitretin or isotretinoin.

Baseline evaluation of serum lipids, transaminases, and CBC should be done before starting any systemic retinoids. These values should be checked monthly for the first 3–6 months and once every 3 months thereafter. Monthly pregnancy tests should be done while on the drug. Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after discontinuing acitretin treatment for cutaneous psoriasis.

questions.text: 32. A 60 year old man is admitted with a suspicious red papule on the shaft of his penis that has been biopsied. The histology report has come back with a diagnosis of carcinoma in situ. There is no lymph node involvement. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
Total penectomy would not be advised in this patient since the patient has been diagnosed with Carcinoma in situ. Total penectomy involves removal of the entire penis, which is a  radical procedure. It is reserved for invasive or advanced squamous cell carcinoma when the stump length is < 2cms. It is not justified in carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive and treatable with conservative options.

When the diagnosis of carcinoma in situ is confirmed, the following treatment options are considered:

* Topical 5-fluorouracil

* CO2 laser ablation

* Surgical excision.

Carcinoma of the penis is commonly a squamous cell carcinoma. It arises from the skin of the glans penis or the prepuce. The lesion can be flat or warty in appearance.

Jackson staging is used for the staging of penile carcinoma:

* Stage I - Only glans / prepuce involved

* Stage II - Tumour extending into the body of penis

* Stage III - Tumour having mobile inguinal nodes

* Stage IV - Tumour spreading to adjacent structures / fixed nodes

Tumors of low-grade and low-stage are managed by Mohs’ surgery with margins of at least 2 cm. Tumors involving the glans penis require glansectomy, and in advanced cases require partial penectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Surgical excision involves wide local excision with adequate margins. It is used when the lesion is localized and accessible. It offers definitive removal of the lesion and preserves penile structure.

Option B: Laser ablation uses CO₂ lasers to precisely ablate the lesion. It is minimally invasive and spares the penile structure. It is suitable for well-demarcated superficial lesions.

Option D: Topical chemotherapy agent that interferes with DNA synthesis such as 5 FU is used. Effective for superficial epithelial neoplasia, including penile CIS. It is applied directly to the lesion over a course of several weeks. Topical 5% Imiquimod is also used for penile intraepithelial neoplasia.

questions.text: 34. A lady at 14 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain and persistent browny vaginal discharge for a few days. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than the period of gestation with a closed cervical os. Doppler ultrasound reveals non-audibility of the fetal heart sound which was audible before. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with 14 weeks of gestation presenting with abdominal pain, persistent browny vaginal discharge, smaller uterus for gestation, closed cervical os, non-audibility of the fetal heart sound in ultrasound is suggestive of missed miscarriage.

Missed miscarriage or early fetal demise is termed when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period.

Patients usually present with features of threatened miscarriage like dull pain or bleeding per vaginum followed by:

* Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge

* Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms

* Retrogression of breast changes

* The uterus appears smaller in size (cessation of uterine growth)

* Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound

* Closed cervical os

* Cervix feels firm

* Negative immunological test for pregnancy

* Empty sac in real-time ultrasonography

Beyond 12 weeks, the retained fetus in the uterus becomes macerated and mummified. 

The expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival is termed abortion.

Classification of abortion:



Other options:

Option A- Inevitable miscarriage is the type of abortion where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

* Increased vaginal bleeding

* Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature

* Dilated internal os

* Rupture of the membranes

Option C- Threatened miscarriage is the type of abortion where the process of miscarriage has started but in a state from which recovery is possible. 

Features:

* Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color

* Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage

* Closed external os

* Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea

* The uterus and cervix feel soft

* On ultrasound:

* Well-formed gestation ring

* Presence of fetal cardiac motion 

Option D- Complete miscarriage is termed when products of conception are expelled en masse.

Features:

* Abdominal pain subsides

* Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding

* The uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhea

* The cervical os is closed

* Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.

* Ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity

Note:

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity.

* Pain in the lower abdomen

* Vaginal bleeding

* Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea

* Patulous cervical os

* Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents.

Features:

* Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for >24 hours

* Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge

* Lower abdominal pain and tenderness

questions.text: 35. A 16-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of mildly itchy, multiple rash-like lesions on the back since two weeks. He says that it was preceded by a single large patchy lesion on his lower back. An image of the physical examination findings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pityriasis rosea, which has typical collarette scales. A collarette scale is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms. It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.

The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch. Christmas tree pattern along cleavage lines with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign is also seen. 

Note: Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated stratum corneum.

questions.text: 36. Injury to the nerve marked by the red arrow in the given image results in loss of which of the following sensations of the tongue?

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: 38. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the vasa recta in the counter-current mechanism?

choices.text: U-shaped structure helps in minimizing medullary solute washout
Solute concentration increases on descent in medulla

questions.solution:
The vasa recta plays no role in creating the medullary hyperosmolality. The hyperosmolarity of the renal medulla is primarily established by the countercurrent multiplier system within the loops of Henle. The vasa recta's function is to maintain this gradient, not to generate it.

Other options:

Option A: The U-shaped structure of the vasa recta functions as a countercurrent exchanger, effectively preventing the rapid removal of solutes from the medullary interstitium by blood flow.

Option B: The vasa recta minimize the washout of solutes from the medullary interstitium. Consequently, the vasa recta plays a key role in preserving the high solute concentrations within the medulla, which is essential for the kidney's ability to concentrate urine.

Option C: As blood descends into the medulla towards the papillae, its concentration progressively increases, facilitated by solute entry from the interstitium and water loss into the interstitium.
