questions.text: 39. An elderly man presents for evaluation following an episode of syncope the same day. He reports having fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. 2D-echo shows left ventricular hypertrophy, with an aortic valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. What will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis (AS), which is associated with the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused by the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis:

* Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. This causes exertional dyspnea.

* Angina pectoris: It occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery 

* Syncope: It occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component, or there may be a paradoxical splitting of S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component. The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids. 

Severe AS is defined as the aortic valve area <1 cm2. Patients even with severe AS may be asymptomatic as the left ventricle undergoes hypertrophy to increase the intraventricular pressure and maintain the stroke volume. Symptomatic AS is an indication for valve replacement.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism, and tension pneumothorax.

Pearl PM1194: Grading of Aortic Stenosis

Grading of stenosis | Area of aortic valve Mild | 1.5 – 2 sq cm Moderate | 1 – 1.5 sq cm Severe | < 1 sq cm

questions.text: 40. A 28-year-old woman with a history of mild asthma presents to the emergency department with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. Her symptoms worsened over the last 6 hours, and she has been using her inhaler more frequently with no relief. On physical examination, her respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min, pulse is 100 /min; Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On lung auscultation, an expiratory wheeze is noted. She does not respond to nebulized albuterol for 30 minutes. What is the most appropriate next step if the patient’s symptoms remain unchanged?

choices.text: Initiate intravenous methylprednisolone and repeat nebulized albuterol.
Chest X-ray to rule out a pneumothorax
Discharge the patient on oral steroids.

questions.solution:
The patient has presented with signs of asthma exacerbation and has not responded to nebulized albuterol. As symptoms persist after persistent bronchodilator use, systemic corticosteroids are initiated (intravenous methylprednisolone).

According to the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA), an asthma exacerbation is defined as a significant change in a patient's asthma status that requires a change in treatment.

Features of Acute severe attack of asthma include:

* Inability to speak a complete sentence in one breath

* Pulse >120/min

* Respiratory rate >25/min

* FEV1 between 33 to 50% of predicted

* Pulsus paradoxus of >10 mmHg

Management of Severe Asthma Exacerbation: All patients require a fast-acting β-agonist: LABA formoterol combined with ICS, SABA albuterol combined with budesonide, or albuterol alone. The preferred combination is with ICS. Albuterol treatment can be administered via an MDI or nebulizer.

Indications of systemic glucocorticoids include

* Recurrent symptoms over the following 1 to 2 days.

* Peak flow remains less than 80% of their normal baseline 

* Does not improve after 1 to 3 doses of a fast-acting bronchodilator.

* If they have recently completed a course in OCS.

* On a maximal dose of controller medications.

Other options:

Option B: Chest x-ray is not indicated in severe asthma exacerbation unless there is suspicion of pneumothorax.

Option C: CPAP is indicated in patients with acute respiratory failure. If this patient does not resolve with systemic glucocorticoids, then CPAP can be considered.

Option D: The patient cannot be discharged as he has a poor response to nebulization therapy.

questions.text: 41. A 10-year-old boy gets stung by a bee while playing in the garden. 15 minutes later, he collapsed while returning home and was admitted to the ER. The BP of the patient is recorded to be 60/40 mm Hg. Which of the following values does not increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
The case scenario of hypotension and collapse after a bee sting points towards a diagnosis of anaphylactic shock. Due to vasodilation throughout the body,  systemic vascular resistance decreases. 

Anaphylactic shock is a type of distributive shock and is caused due to histamine release. There is vasodilation throughout the body leading to A-V shunting and reduced cellular utilization of oxygen. In distributive shock, the mixed venous oxygen saturation, base deficit, and pulse rate are high whereas systemic vascular resistance is low. In later stages, hypovolemia may set in due to fluid loss into interstitial spaces leading to myocardial depression.

questions.text: 42. A 3-month-old infant who was born at term presented with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. Physical features are shown in the image below. The lower limb X-ray revealed an absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, protruding tongue, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes.

Screening is usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally, and usually, dried blood samples are used for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first, as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based screening.

In untreated hypothyroidism, as the child grows older, there is a discrepancy between chronological age and osseous development. Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. Radiotracer uptake study with radioactive iodine or technetium should be done as soon as primary congenital hypothyroidism is diagnosed.

Treatment with levothyroxine should be started within 2 weeks in order to maintain normal cognitive and physical development. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. 

Other options:

Option A- Down’s syndrome also presents with developmental delay and hypothyroidism. They have characteristic facial features such as a flat face, depressed nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a single palmar crease. The image shown below depicts an infant with Down's syndrome. Radiological features include atlantoaxial dislocation.



Option B-  Congenital rickets is a rare condition resulting from severe maternal vitamin D deficiency and can present with symptomatic hypocalcemia, intrauterine growth retardation, decreased bone ossification along with classic rachitic changes.

Option D- Hurler's syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis which may present after 6 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

questions.text: 43. In the mediastinum, the nerves that pass immediately anterior and posterior to the root of the lung, respectively, are?
questions.solution:
In the mediastinum, the phrenic nerve passes immediately anterior to the roots of the lungs, while the vagus nerves pass immediately posterior to the root of the lung.

The sequence of structures at the right hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic: 'BABV')

questions.text: 44. A 40-year-old man who is a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. Angiography showed an anterior communicating artery (ACA) aneurysm. The ultrasound abdomen is shown below. What is the best management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with an aneurysm and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The best management would be tolvaptan and long-term dialysis.

Management of ADPKD includes non-pharmacological methods by increasing fluid intake to prevent renal stone formation and to reduce the growth of cyst by depressing ADH release.

Pharmacological methods include using analgesics, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs to control blood pressure and slow the cyst growth, and tolvaptan(V2 receptor antagonist) to reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function.

Surgical decompression may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts. If nephron-sparing surgery isn't possible, nephrectomy is indicated.

More than half of the patients require long-term peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis or kidney transplant.

* Characterized by medullary cysts

* Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 

* Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

* Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney

* Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: 45. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of swelling and restriction of movement at the left elbow joint. Physical therapy was used to treat his supracondylar fracture. Radiographs performed is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This boy following physical therapy for supracondylar fracture humerus now presenting with pain and restriction of movement at the elbow has developed heterotopic calcification. 

Myositis ossificans is characterized by formation of lamellar bone in the extaskeletal tissues. Patients usually present with a painful, firm, mobile mass. Development of which is caused by the increased expression of bone morphogenic proteins leading to migration of stem cells into the lesion which then mature into fibroblasts, chondrocytes and osteocytes , resulting in metaplastic bone formation.

It is a highly inflammatory, rapidly growing, and painful muscular mass, which is seen following muscular trauma, orthopedic surgery. It can also be seen in patients with stroke or neurological injury. The late stage is characterized by a typical zonal pattern (zonal phenomenon). It consists of three zones:

* Innermost zone: made of proliferating fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis

* Intermediate zone: contains osteoblasts with the immature osteoid formation

* Peripheral zone: the mature bone

Other options 

Option A : Tear in the brachialis tendon would likely present with pain on flexion of the forearm. Also, radiograph suggestive of tear is not seen in this case.

Option B : Necrotizing myositis is an infection caused by group A Streptococcus. Patients would present with severe pain, erythema and edema of the limb which is not seen in this patient.

Option C : Patients with neoplastic bone disorders presents with severe pain during the night with stretch of the muscle overlying the bone not likely to cause pain. Also, this patient's recent supracondylar fracture makes myositis ossificans the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: 46. The image shows urinary casts under polarized light. Which parasite shows a similar appearance on a Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
The urinary cast shows Maltese cross appearance. The organism showing a similar appearance on Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear is Babesia microti.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts. Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment:

* Mild: Atovaquone + Azithromycin

* Severe: Clindamycin + quinine

* Fulminant case: exchange transfusion

Maltese cross appearance can be found in:

* Short-range shotgun wound

* Babesiosis

* Urine analysis in Fabry's disease under polarized light

Interpretation of casts in urine:

* Hyaline casts: Physiological, concentrated urine, fever, exercise

* Red blood cell casts: Glomerular causes

* White blood cell casts: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis

* Muddy brown casts: Acute tubular necrosis, interstitial nephritis

* Fatty casts: Heavy proteinuria

* Broad casts: Chronic renal failure

Pearl PM1885: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: 47. In which of the following conditions do you see a 'headlight-in-fog' appearance, as seen below?
questions.solution:
The "headlight-in-fog' appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis. 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infestation due to Toxoplasma gondii. It primarily affects the central nervous system and retina. In humans, it occurs as congenital, acquired, or recurrent.

Toxoplasmosis has a variable presentation. Congenital toxoplasmosis is acquired by the transplacental route. Infants are usually born with inactive disease. Iridocyclitis can be granulomatous or non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, which gives the 'headlight-in-fog' appearance as in the image in question. Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and papillitis with granulomas. 

Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with pigmented borders as in the image below. Bilateral healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular area are usually seen. In acquired toxoplasmosis, punched-out lesions similar to congenital toxoplasmosis are seen. In addition, punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis (PORT) may also be seen.



Other options:

Option A - Posterior staphyloma is used to describe a bulge in the sclera with the choroid behind the equator. On ophthalmoscopy, there is an excavated area with retinal vessels dipping in it. 

Option B - Fundal coloboma occurs due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft. It appears as a comet-shaped defect with the apex towards the disc which may or may not be involved. A few choroidal or retinal vessels may also be seen on the surface. 

Option C - Congenital rubella typically produces a salt and pepper appearance of the fundus.

questions.text: 48. A CKD patient presents with severe hypocalcemia despite calcium supplementation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Bone histology study in this patient would reveal:

choices.text: Reduced bone resorption and bone cysts
Osteitis fibrosa and bone marrow fibrosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism with high bone turnover (elevated PTH).  Bone histology of this patient would show osteitis fibrosa and bone marrow fibrosis.

In CKD, the kidneys fail to convert vitamin D to its active form, reducing calcium absorption from the gut. Additionally, impaired renal excretion leads to phosphate retention, which binds to calcium, lowering free calcium levels. This hypocalcemia stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more PTH, resulting in secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Bone pathology in CKD patients can be characterized by:

* high bone turnover with elevated PTH-  osteitis fibrosa cystica. Bone histology in osteitis fibrosa cystica shows abnormal osteoid, bone and bone marrow fibrosis, bone cysts (brown tumors when hemorrhagic).

* low bone turnover with low/normal PTH- adynamic bone disease. Reduced bone resorption and mineralization are seen in this condition. (option D)

Defective bone mineralization is seen in CKD due to reduced action of vitamin D, seen as widened osteoid seams on histology.

Osteosclerosis involves excessive bone formation, resulting in overly dense bones. It is generally not associated with CKD.

questions.text: 49. A 40-year-old male who works at a dock helping in loading ships, comes to the hospital with a black lesion on his neck. A few days later he developed breathing difficulty and high fever following which he passed away. His doctor has sent a swab from his black lesion for microbiological examination. What is the likely observation on culture smear microscopy and the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis which shows Bamboo stick appearance on culture smear microscopy.

Anthrax is a zoonotic disease, caused by a spore-forming obligate aerobe, Bacillus anthracis. Humans acquire infection through contact with an infected animal or through inhalation of spores.

Human beings acquire anthrax via 3 routes.

* Cutaneous mode- via spore entry through abraded skin

* Pulmonary anthrax via inhalation of spores

* Intestinal anthrax via ingestion of carcasses of animals containing anthrax spores.

Hide porters disease (cutaneous anthrax) commonly occurs in dock workers. It is characterized by a Malignant pustule which evolves to a painless vesicle followed by the development of black eschar

Lab Diagnosis of anthrax

* Gram staining: Gram-positive, large rectangular bacilli. Shows Mcfadeyeans reaction and Ascoli’s thermo precipitation test. 

* Culture:

* Nutrient agar: medusa head appearance colonies

* Blood agar: dry wrinkled, non-hemolytic colonies

* Gelatin stab agar: inverted fir tree appearance

* Culture smear: Gram-positive rods with bamboo stick appearance.

Cutaneous Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae may occasionally skin lesions; it is caused by the organism itself and not toxin-mediated. Extremities are commonly affected. It presents as punched-out ulcerative lesions with necrosis or rarely with pseudomembrane formation. Image seen below

questions.text:
50. A patient with DIC develops skin necrosis on his arms and back. He is diagnosed to have purpura fulminans. Which of the following is likely associated with this condition?

DIC-Disseminated intravascular coagulation
questions.solution:
This patient has developed a complication of DIC known as purpura fulminans characterized by widespread skin necrosis. This condition is associated with a congenital protein C deficiency. 

This process is similar to how warfarin-mediated skin necrosis occurs. The lack of protein C leads to increased susceptibility to clotting as it is an anticoagulant factor and suppresses coagulation. 

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acquired syndrome characterized by the widespread activation of blood clotting factors within blood vessels, resulting in a loss of clotting control. The primary mechanism of DIC involves the uncontrolled generation of thrombin through multiple pathways which leads to sustained coagulation activation, the formation of fibrin, and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets.

Infections are the most frequent cause of DIC.

Laboratory investigations in DIC are

* Decreased platelet count 

* Prolonged PT/TT

* Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)

* Decreased fibrinogen

* Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)

* Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

The treatment involves platelet transfusion when platelet counts are below 10,000-20,000/μL. Replacement of fibrinogen and coagulation factors is with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) along with cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate.

In cases of low-grade DIC associated with solid tumors or acute promyelocytic leukemia low doses of continuous-infusion heparin has been effective.

questions.text: 51. A young boy is posted for tonsillectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, it was found that he had increased activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, the platelet counts and prothrombin time (PT) are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has an elevation of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal platelet count. This is likely to be due to hemophilia.

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive hemorrhagic disease due to mutations in the F8 gene (hemophilia A or classic hemophilia) or F9 gene (hemophilia B). It typically affects men, and women are usually asymptomatic. Depending on the residual activity of factor VIII or IX, the manifestations can be mild, moderate, or severe. 

Early in life, the patient may have prolonged bleeding after circumcision, or as intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint, hemarthrosis is seen. They present as painful swelling and reddening of the knee, elbow, ankle, shoulder, or hips. 

Laboratory investigations will show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated with the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

Prothrombin time- measures the integrity of extrinsic and common pathways. It measures factors VII, fibrinogen, II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Activated partial thromboplastin time, aPTT, measures intrinsic pathways. It measures factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII, I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Elevated aPTT with normal PT and platelet count is seen in factor XI and factor XII deficiency, hemophilia, von Willebrand disease, an inhibitor to factor VIII, lupus anticoagulant, presence of heparin, etc.

Elevated PT with normal aPTT and platelet count is seen in factor VII deficiency and oral anticoagulant therapy.

Elevated PT and aPTT with normal platelet count are seen if there is any defect in the common pathway. It is seen in afibrinogenemia; deficiencies of factors II, V, and X; and deficiency of vitamin K–dependant factors. 

Elevated PT and aPTT with low platelet counts are seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation, liver disease, and lupus anticoagulant.

questions.text: 52. Which of the following glycogen storage disorders results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen having fewer α-1,6 branch points and more α-1,4 linked glucose units with longer outer chains?
questions.solution:
Type 4 Glycogen Storage Disorder results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen having fewer α-1,6 branch points and more α-1,4 linked glucose units with longer outer chains, resulting in a structure resembling amylopectin.

Type IV GSD(Andersen’s Disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the deficiency of branching enzyme (amylo-α(1→4)→α(1→6)-transglycosylase) activity. These excessively long peripheral glucan chains form polyglucosan bodies, which are positive on periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) and resistant to diastase digestion. Polyglucosan body accumulation is seen in all affected patients but to different degrees and in different tissues.

Patients with Type 4 Glycogen Storage Disorder(Andersen’s Disease)  present with hepatic cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy, myopathy, peripheral neuropathy, motor neuron disease, and leukodystrophy, failure to thrive, and death occurs by the age of 5 years due to hepatic failure.

Other Options:

Option A: Type 1 Glycogen Storage Disorder(Von Gierke disease)occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. 

Option B: Type 2 Glycogen Storage Disorder(Pompe’s Disease) is due to the deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase) which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes of the liver (hepatomegaly), skeletal muscles in the form of large vacuoles (hypotonia and weakness), cardiac muscles (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). The child generally dies by the age of 2 years due to cardiac failure. The adult form presents with muscle dystrophies.

Option C: Type 3 Glycogen Storage Disorder (Cori's disease) is due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme (amylo-α(1→6)-glucosidase). On liver or muscle biopsy there is an accumulation of branched polysaccharides(limit dextrin). Infants usually present with ketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia. Muscle weaknesses are mostly seen in the third to the fourth decade of life.

questions.text: 53. A postoperative case of left frontotemporal craniotomy, with a tracheostomy in situ, who was on mechanical ventilator, was planned for weaning. Which of the following can be used for the same?
questions.solution:
Mapleson E or Ayre’s T piece can be used for weaning a patient from mechanical ventilator. Mapleson D, E and F or T-piece group are efficient in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation, and hence can be used for weaning a patient from mechanical ventilation.

Weaning refers to gradual withdrawal of mechanical ventilator support. Circuits which can help in controlled ventilation, as well as spontaneous ventilation, must be used for the same. Ayre’s T piece is the most common circuit used during weaning in the ICU setup.

Mapleson breathing systems include circuits from A to F, which are classified on the basis of position of fresh gas flow, APL valve, reservoir bag and corrugated tubing. They can be subclassified into 3 functional groups:

* Magill’s ciruit which includes Mapleson A – best for spontaneous ventilation

* Mapleson B and C

* T piece group which includes Mapleson D, E and F – best for controlled ventilation



Mapleson breathing systems include circuits from A to F, which are classified based on the position of fresh gas flow, APL valve, reservoir bag, and corrugated tubing. They can be subclassified into 3 functional groups:

* Magill’s circuit, which includes Mapleson A – best for spontaneous ventilation

* Mapleson B and C

* T-piece group, which includes Mapleson D, E, and F – best for controlled ventilation

questions.text:
54. A 1-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia presents with hypertension. The infant is diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Which of the following findings will you see in this infant?

(ACTH- Adrenocorticotrophic hormone)
questions.solution:
Decreased androgen levels are seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase enzyme deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is an autosomal recessive disorder where adrenal steroid hormone synthesis is affected. There are many variants of CAH depending on enzyme deficiency. The most common enzyme deficiency is the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. 

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:



In the above image, we understand that 17 alpha-hydroxylase is required for the conversion of pregnenolone to 17 hydroxy pregnenolone and progesterone to 17 hydroxy progesterone. Pregnenolone and progesterone are further converted to cortisol and androgens. Therefore deficiency of this enzyme will lead to reduced levels of cortisol and androgens. The accumulated pregnenolone and progesterone lead to increased synthesis of aldosterone.

Patients will present with ambiguous genitalia due to a deficiency of androgens. Excessive aldosterone will lead to increased sodium retention, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Cortisol deficiency stimulates the pituitary and increases ACTH secretion, leading to adrenocortical hyperplasia. The ability to synthesize corticosterone from its precursor deoxycorticosterone is preserved in these patients.

Treatment:

* It includes glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone to control hypertension by suppressing deoxycorticosterone synthesis. 

* Removal of intra-abdominal testes or orchidopexy to prevent malignant transformation and appropriate sex hormone replacement therapy at puberty depends on the sex of rearing.

Pearl PM1987: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

questions.text: 55. A 26-year-old female patient presents with high-grade fever, and lower abdominal pain. She gives a history of spontaneous abortion at home 2 weeks back. She did not consult any doctor after this. A provisional diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is made. Which of the following features is least expected to be seen in PID developing after abortion?
questions.solution:
In PID developing after abortions, the formation of a distended fallopian tube is unlikely.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to the infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract until the ovaries. Most of the PIDs are due to ascending or blood-borne infection, hence the lesion is often bilateral. The anatomical proximity of the ovaries to the tubes invariably leads to its involvement as well. 

The most common etiological agent leading to post-abortal PID is Chlamydia trachomatis. In such cases, infection is spread through the cervical lymphatics to the broad ligament. As a result, the fallopian tube is affected from the outside and the mucosa is affected last. The wall of the tube is thickened with minimal distension. Mucosal involvement in later stages leads to blockage of the fallopian tube by multiple adhesions.

In PID occurring due to ascending infections, the mucous membrane is affected first. It becomes oedematous and infiltrated with leucocytes and plasma cells. The exudate so formed is discharged into the lumen of the tube. This causes the tube to distend, usually at the ampullary end. The inflamed and ulcerated mucosa eventually causes adhesions and tubal blockage or narrowing of the lumen. This leads to infertility or ectopic pregnancy.

In earlier stages of the disease, the inflammatory exudate pours out of the open fimbrial end to form a pelvic abscess. Eventually, the fimbrial end gets sealed and pus accumulates within the lumen leading to the formation of a distended retort-shaped fallopian tube called a pyosalpinx. 

The pyosalpinx may respond to antibiotics, and the pus contained therein becomes sterile within 6 weeks of the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as a chronic pyosalpinx or hydrosalpinx.

Acute PID usually presents as bilateral pain abdomen, high-grade fever, vomiting, dehydration, menstrual irregularities, and in cases of pelvic abscess, it may present as severe diarrhea due to rectal irritation.

Management includes rest, rehydration, analgesics, and antibiotics based on culture sensitivity. Antibiotics commonly used are cefoxitin, azithromycin, ofloxacin, levofloxacin, and clindamycin. RCOG guideline recommends a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg twice daily with metronidazole 400 mg twice daily for 14 days as outpatient treatment. Ceftriaxone IM followed by azithromycin 1 g per week for 2 weeks is an alternative.

questions.text: 56. Which of the following diseases are incorrectly matched with their imaging modality of choice?

choices.text: Hirschsprung’s disease- Plain x-ray abdomen with air contrast
Neonatal hepatitis- Nuclear medicine; hepatobiliary scintigraphy

questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrografin enema. 

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel.



Other options:

Transfontanel cranial ultrasonography or a neurosonogram reliably delineates ventricular size and anatomy in neonates. It is an excellent primary imaging technique for the evaluation of the many clinical problems related to ventricular dilatation. 

* Ventriculomegaly

* Differentiating nonobstructive ventricular dilatation from obstructive enlargement (hydrocephalus)

* Cause of hydrocephalus

* Temporary management of patients with hydrocephalus

* Aiding in the management of patients with permanent ventricular shunts

Ultrasound in pyloric stenosis will show a dilated, fluid-filled stomach and proximal duodenum with obstruction. A coexisting volvulus can show as a whirlpool sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy is a radionuclide imaging that shows metabolic activity in different cell types based on the substance taken up by the various cells.

questions.text: 57. Which of the following structures passes through the opening of the diaphragm marked as '?' in the image below?
questions.solution:
The opening of the diaphragm marked in the given image is the esophageal opening. Among the given options, the structure that passes through this opening is the left vagus nerve. 

The esophageal opening passes through a major opening in the muscular part of the diaphragm at the level of the T10 vertebra, a little to the left of the aortic hiatus. The structures passing through the esophageal opening are:

* Esophagus

* Right and left vagal trunks

* Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels

Option A: The thoracic duct passes through the opening in the crus of the diaphragm at the level of T12 along with the aorta.

Option B: The superior epigastric artery passes through a minor opening called the Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) between the sternal and costal parts of the diaphragm.

Option D: The right phrenic nerve passes through the opening in the central tendon at the level of T8 along with the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: 58. During the examination of a Heart failure patient in the ICU, you find out that the liver of the patient is enlarged. The intensivist suspects Congestive hepatomegaly secondary to heart failure. Which of the following conditions also affect the same zone in the liver as the condition mentioned above?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to have chronic venous congestion-induced liver injury affecting Zone 3 of the liver, which is also affected in conditions like Paracetamol poisoning.

The hepatic lobule, on histopathology, is divided into three zones, as shown in the image below:



Zone 1 lies closest to the portal triad and is hence richly nourished with oxygen and nutrients. As we move from zone 1 to zone 3, the supply of oxygen reduces, making the centrilobular (Zone 3) cells more susceptible to hypoxic injury, while the zone 1 cells may only show fatty changes.

In chronic venous congestion (like in the case of heart failure), these centrilobular areas stand in the form of dark reddish brown areas due to the deposition of hemosiderin, while the relatively unaffected zone 1 cells appear pale. This creates a pattern on gross specimens, commonly known as “Nutmeg Liver” (as seen in the image below)



Other options:

Option A: Viral hepatitis- The inflammatory cells lead to the injury of periportal hepatocytes.

Option B: Pre-eclampsia- It leads to periportal haemorrhage in the liver.

Option C: Yellow fever- Viral antigens were found most frequently in hepatocytes from the midzonal area than in other lobule areas.

questions.text: 59. You are treating a 34-year-old male outpatient diagnosed with uncomplicated influenza. The patient has been symptomatic for 36 hours and is a known case of mild COPD. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate choice for treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor that blocks the release of progeny virions from infected cells. It is administered orally and is effective for both influenza A and B. It can reduce the duration of symptoms by approximately one day when initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset. It helps lessen disease intensity, minimizes the likelihood of being admitted to the hospital, and contributes to a shorter inpatient stay. It has a proven efficacy profile for uncomplicated influenza, is easy to administer, and is the most widely used anti-influenza drug.

Other options:-

B) Zanamivir is also a neuraminidase inhibitor effective against influenza A and B. It is administered via inhalation, which may be difficult for patients with respiratory comorbidities like asthma or COPD. Due to the risk of bronchospasm, it is contraindicated in patients with chronic respiratory conditions. 

C) Peramivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor administered as a single IV dose. It is comparable to oseltamivir in uncomplicated influenza, but it requires IV administration, so it is not given in this case as it is outpatient. 

D) Baloxavir inhibits cap-dependent endonuclease, an enzyme required for viral replication. It is often reserved for patients at high risk of complications. Also due to resistance concerns, it is not used routinely.

questions.text:
60. An 18-year-old male with a history of type I diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department in an altered mental state. An arterial blood gas (ABG) was done. Which of the following is most accurate regarding his acid-base status?

pH: 7.15

HCO₃⁻: 8 mmol/L

PaCO₂: 18 mmHg

choices.text: The PaCO₂ is appropriately compensated, ruling out any coexisting respiratory disorder.
The PaCO₂ is higher than expected, suggesting an additional respiratory acidosis
The PaCO₂ is lower than expected, suggesting an additional respiratory alkalosis
The PaCO₂ cannot be interpreted without knowing the anion gap

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is in metabolic acidosis. The expected PaCO₂ is calculated using Winter’s formula:

Expected PaCO₂=(1.5×HCO₃⁻)+8±2 = 18−22 mm Hg

The measured PaCO₂ is 18 mmHg, which is within the expected range. This indicates proper respiratory compensation with no coexisting respiratory disorder.

Winter’s formula is critical in evaluating whether respiratory compensation is adequate in metabolic acidosis. It predicts the expected PaCO₂ based on the HCO₃⁻ level. Deviations from the expected range can uncover additional acid-base disturbances, such as respiratory acidosis (PaCO₂ > expected) or respiratory alkalosis (PaCO₂ < expected).

questions.text: 61. A 70-year-old woman presented with severely pruritic, large, tense, multiple blisters on the trunk and flexor surfaces. Histopathology shows subepidermal blisters with eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence reveals IgG deposits as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is wrong about this disease?

choices.text: The main target antigen is BP180.
There is an association with psoriasis.
Nikolsky's sign is positive in this disease.
Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the direct immunofluorescence image are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Nikolsky's sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders. It is mostly a disease of the elderly. It is characterized by a subepidermal split, with tissue-bound and serum IgG antibodies against BP180 and BP230 antigens.

Bullous pemphigoid is associated with psoriasis and treatments of psoriasis, like phototherapy and psoralen. It is also precipitated by triggers like trauma, burns, skin grafting, and drugs like furosemide.

Clinical features:

* Prodromal phase:

* Excoriated papules, eczematous or urticarial skin lesions, and hemorrhagic crusts may be seen.

* Bullous phase:

* Intense pruritus is almost constantly present.

* Symmetrically distributed tense bullae and vesicles are seen over the flexural aspects and abdomen of the body.

* Partly hemorrhagic crusts and erythematous plaques with an annular pattern are seen.

* Lesions heal without scarring, provided there are no superinfections.

* The bullae contain clear, sometimes hemorrhagic, exudates.

* Nikolsky's sign is negative.

* Oral or mucosal lesions and milia formation are rare.

The image given below shows the lesions seen in bullous pemphigoid.



Histopathology shows the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils. Immunofluorescent microscopy shows the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.



Untreated bullous pemphigoid has a chronic, self-limiting course, with remissions and relapses. Complete remissions are possible with treatment.

Bullous pemphigoid is mainly treated with topical and systemic corticosteroids. Other drugs like azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, and immunomodulators are also used.

questions.text: 62. On routine examination of a neonate, the left eye was smaller in size and had a white pupillary reflex. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is persistent fetal vasculature.

The points in the clinical vingette pointing to this diagnosis are: 

* White pupillary reflex in the left eye (unilateral leukocoria)

* Smaller size of the left eye (microphthalmos) and 

* Fundoscopy image showing a leash of vascularized fibrous tissue extending from the back of the lens to the optic nerve head

Persistent fetal vasculature was earlier known as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. It is the failure of primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress. This eventually leads to contraction and opacification combined with the hypoplasia of the posterior portion of the vascular meshwork.

It is unilateral in most of the cases. It is bilateral in cases that are associated with Trisomy 13, trisomy 22, Norries disease, and Walkers Warburg syndrome. 

Clinical Findings include:

* Leukocoria

* Microphthalmia 

* Shallow anterior chamber 

* Retrolental cataract 

* Esotropia 

* Angle-closure glaucoma 

* Dilated iris vessels 

* Persistent hyaloid artery 

* Vitreous hemorrhage

* Tractional retinal detachment 

Investigations:

* CT scan of orbit to evaluate for the presence of calcification, which is present in retinoblastoma but absent in persistent fetal vasculature. 

* B-scan ultrasonography to evaluate for retinal detachment when a cataract limits the view to the retina.

Treatment is done by pars plana lensectomy and vitrectomy to remove the retrolental fibrovascular membrane to prevent angle-closure glaucoma, followed by aggressive amblyopia therapy

Image below shows the falciform fold of detached dysplastic retina encircling the persistent hyaloid artery that extends from the optic nerve head to the retrolental mass.



Option A:

Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina. Leukocoria and squint are the most common presentation of retinoblastoma. It may also present as painful red eye, cataract, buphthalmos, proptosis(not microphthalmos) and pseudohypopyon.



Option B:

Coats' disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It presents as unilateral visual loss, leukocoria (because of exudative retinal detachment), and strabismus. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation. 

The image below shows total retinal detachment with subretinal exudate containing cholesterol crystals and a fibrous nodule in the posterior pole seen in Coats' disease.



Option C:

Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the inner layers of the retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.

Fundus shows smooth and convex (usually round) retinal detachment. Shifting fluid will be seen in exudative type. Shaffer's sign - Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.

questions.text: 63. Identify the organism transmitted by the vector whose life cycle is shown below.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle, showing transovarian transmission, is of trombiculid mite which acts as a vector for transmission of O. tsutsugamushi responsible for scrub typhus. 

Humans are seen to be infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae (chiggers). Transovarian transmission of microbes occurs in mites. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Option A: R. conorii causes Indian tick typhus. The parasite is transmitted by ticks, and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar.

Option B: R. rickettsii causes Rocky mountain spotted fever. It is transmitted by ticks (Dermacentor andersoni), and the patients present with fever, headache, rash but no eschar.

Option D: Trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness is transmitted by the vector Tse-Tse fly. It is an arthropod-borne parasitic disease of humans and other animals. It is caused by protozoa of the species Trypanosoma brucei

questions.text: 64. Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titers of HLA antibodies are seen in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

* smoking

* chronic alcohol use

* shock, liver surgery

* mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: 65. A woman is currently 34 weeks pregnant. She had a stillbirth at 30 weeks, a second-trimester MTP and an abortion at 8 weeks. What is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of the patient is G4P1A2L0.

The components of the obstetric score are:

* G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one. It is irrespective of the period of gestation.

* P - Parity, denoting the total number of previous pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India. This includes both live births and stillbirths. The current pregnancy is not included

* A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.

* L - Living children

For the given patient,

* G- Gravida is 4 because she is currently in her fourth pregnancy

* P- Parity is 1 because she had one stillbirth at 30 weeks

* A- Abortions are 2 because she had an MTP and an abortion at 8 weeks

* L- Living children is 0

questions.text:
66. Match the following respiratory patterns with their corresponding names.
* Cheyne-Stokes respiration
* Biot’s breathing
* Normal breathing
* Hyperpnea
questions.solution:
The correct match is A - 4, B - 3, C - 1, D - 2

The different patterns of respiration are shown below.



The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Cheyne-Stokes' breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.

When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.





In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 

Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.

Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 

Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.

questions.text: 67. A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma located in close proximity to the GE junction. The consultant decides to treat the tumor surgically. According to Siewert classification, what type of tumors are to be treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Siewert Type III tumors are be treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma.



Note: Siewert types I and II tumors are treated similar to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: 68. A 35-year-old woman presents with generalized body aches, fatigue, and anxiety for the past 4 months, but her sleep is not affected due to pain. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations were normal. You suspect fibromyalgia in her. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is preferred in fibromyalgia patients having pain along with fatigue and anxiety, as it has antidepressant action as well.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences (earlier considered as a part of the diagnostic evaluation) and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. Other symptoms include fatigue, depression, sleep disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and anxiety. It is predominantly seen in females. 

Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue. This includes chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes. It is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, cognitive-behavioral strategies, and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) for movement-evoked pain and fatigue.

Pharmacotherapy with single agents to treat multiple symptom domains is recommended. Cyclobenzaprine, pregabalin, and sedating antidepressants like amitriptyline are used in fibromyalgia pain associated with sleep disturbances (Option A, B). However, in patients having pain associated with fatigue, anxiety, or depression, drugs that have both analgesic and antidepressant/anxiolytic effects, such as duloxetine or milnacipran, are used.

Option C: Glucocorticoids are not effective against fibromyalgia-related symptoms.

questions.text: 69. A 15-year-old male presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head confirmed angiofibroma confined to the nasopharynx. Which of the following surgical approaches can be used for the treatment of angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
A transpalatal surgical approach can be used for the treatment of angiofibroma in this patient with angiofibroma confined to the nasopharynx.

The surgical approaches are based on the origin and extensions of the angiofibroma.  Location | Surgical approaches Nose and nasopharynx | Transpalatal or Endoscopic Nose, nasopharynx maxillary antrum and pterygopalatine fossa | Lateral rhinotomy with medial maxillectomy or Endoscopic or Le Fort I Above + Infratemporal Fossa | Extended lateral rhinotomy or Infratemporal Fossa approach or Maxillary swing approach Above + Cheek extension | Maxillary swing approach Above + Intracranial extension | Extended lateral rhinotomy, Combined intracranial and extracranial approach or Radiation if the intracranial part is inaccessible

It is most commonly seen in males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen.  The patient most commonly presents with profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. The patient may also present with proptosis, diplopia and swelling of the cheeks, depending on the extent of the tumour.

Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head shows the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign which is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.

questions.text:
70. A sputum sample shows gram-positive cocci on microscopy. The organism is catalase-negative and shows partial hemolysis on blood agar. Which of the following tests can be performed to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci?
* Optochin sensitivity
* Bacitracin sensitivity
* Growth in 6.5% NaCl
* Bile solubility
* Novobiocin sensitivity
questions.solution:
Gram-positive cocci with catalase negative test and partial α hemolysisis suggestive of Streptococcus. Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests can be done to further differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci.

Gram-positive cocci are differentiated based on the catalase test. Staphylococci are catalase-positive while streptococci are catalase negative. Streptococci are further differentiated based on hemolysis on blood agar. Partial α hemolysis can be seen in cases of Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci. These are differentiated based on optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests which are both positive in Streptococcus pneumonia.



Other options:

Option 2: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes

Option 3: Enterococcus species (S.faecalis and other enterococci) show growth in 6.5% NaCl.

Option 5: Novobiocin sensitivity is seen in Staphylococcus epidermidis.

questions.text: 71. Which of the following types of rhinitis is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia, along with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment to the affected part. Ointments with antibiotics and steroids can also be used.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinitis caseosa is a condition in which the nose is filled with purulent discharge/cheesy material. It is a unilateral condition mostly affecting males. This condition usually results from chronic sinusitis, where the mucosa of the sinuses becomes granulomatous and the sinuses are filled with cheesy material. Management includes the removal of debris and ensuring good drainage of the sinuses.

Option C: Secondary atrophic rhinitis is a condition when atrophic changes in the nasal cavity occur secondary to specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

questions.text: 72. Waste sharps are taken from the autoclave after sterilization. Which waste treatment method would be employed next?
questions.solution:
Waste sharps are treated by mutilation or shredding. Shredding of waste is done to reduce the volume of waste and to increase the extent of contact.

Waste sharps are treated by autoclaving or dry heat sterilization, followed by mutilation or encapsulation.

questions.text: 73. A primigravida mother presented to the emergency room in the early stage of labor. On abdominal examination, there is infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. On per vaginal examination, the pelvis is found to be adequate. Image 1 shows the initial engagement of the head and Image 2 shows the position of the head after the internal rotation. What is the outcome that can be expected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows that the presentation of the baby is occipito-posterior and image 1 shows that the head is engaged in the right occipito-posterior position. Image 2 shows that the head has undergone a short posterior rotation (1/8th of a circle). Since the pelvis is favorable, face-to-pubis delivery is possible in this mother.

Right occipito-posterior position (ROP) is the most common malposition, which occurs when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint, or directly over the sacrum. It is associated with the risk of delayed engagement of the head, prolonged labor due to transverse arrest, and the need for cesarean sections.

Features of the occipito-posterior position include infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds localized to the flank. The fetal parts are more prominently felt near the midline. The head engages through the right oblique diameter in ROP and the engaging AP diameter is occipitofrontal or suboccipito-frontal. 

In the majority of cases where the pelvis is favorable, uterine contractions are strong, and no complications arise, it results in normal vaginal delivery. With the occiput (back of the baby's head) as the leading part, it rotates approximately 3/8th of a circle towards the front, positioning itself behind the symphysis pubis. Due to the limitations of the neck's ability to withstand such torsion, the shoulders then rotate about 2/8th of a circle, aligning with the right oblique diameter. Consequently, the remaining progression of labor resembles that of the right occipitoanterior position in ROP.

When there is incomplete forward rotation during labor, the occiput undergoes an anterior rotation of approximately 1/8th of a circle, causing the sagittal suture to align with the bi-spinous diameter of the pelvis. Subsequent further anterior rotation is unlikely, and when labor arrest occurs in this position, it is referred to as deep transverse arrest.

In certain instances, the labor process does not involve rotation and instead leads to a condition called oblique posterior arrest. This occurs when both the sinciput (front part of the baby's head) and the occiput (back part of the head) touch the pelvic floor at the same time. This simultaneous contact is a result of the head being moderately deflected, preventing the occiput from rotating. The sagittal suture lies in the oblique diameter.

When the head is severely deflected during labor, it can result in posterior rotation, known as the occipitosacral position. Under favorable conditions, such as having a baby of average size, strong uterine contractions, and a well-suited pelvis (such as an anthropoid or spacious gynaecoid pelvis), spontaneous delivery may occur as face to pubis. However, in unfavorable situations where labor arrest occurs, it is referred to as occipitosacral arrest.

Indications of cesarean section in the occipito-posterior position include the arrest of labor, inadequate uterine contractions, fetal distress, and other obstetrical complications.

During the second stage of labor, if the anterior rotation of the occiput is completed, delivery occurs spontaneously or may require the application of ventouse or low forceps.

questions.text: 74. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

questions.text: 75. A 28-year-old woman presents to the hospital in active labor. During her routine prenatal care, she was found to have a positive VDRL test, but she did not receive treatment due to a lack of access to healthcare. After delivering a premature baby, you are asked to evaluate the newborn for possible signs of congenital infection. Which of the following is NOT an early manifestation of the congenital infection that the child is likely to exhibit?”
questions.solution:
Positive VDRL in the mother suggests syphilis, and the infant is likely to exhibit symptoms of congenital syphilis. Clutton joints are a late manifestation of congenital syphilis.

Early signs typically emerge within the first two years of life, while late manifestations appear gradually over the next two decades. Due to transplacental spirochetemia, early manifestations are varied and affect multiple organ systems.

Common early signs include:

* hepatosplenomegaly

* jaundice

* elevated liver enzymes

* diffuse lymphadenopathy, which may resolve spontaneously, though shotty nodes can persist

Other characteristic features include osteochondritis, periostitis, and a mucocutaneous rash with erythematous maculopapular or vesicular bullous lesions, often followed by deformities of the hands and feet, mucus patches, snuffles (persistent rhinitis), and condylomatous lesions. 

Bone involvement, such as Wimberger lines due to demineralization of the medial proximal tibial metaphysis, is also common. Osteochondritis, known as Parrot pseudoparalysis, may cause pain, irritability, and refusal to move the affected limb. Neurosyphilis is often asymptomatic in the neonatal period, though CSF abnormalities may occur. Renal manifestations can include hematuria, proteinuria, hypercholesterolemia, and hypocomplementemia.

Less common early signs of congenital syphilis include peritonitis, pancreatitis, pneumonia, eye involvement, nonimmune hydrops, and testicular masses. Blood and moist open lesions from infants with congenital syphilis, as well as children with acquired or secondary syphilis, are infectious until 24 hours after appropriate treatment.

Late manifestations often involve:

* Skeletal changes due to recurrent periostitis lead to thickening of the affected bones

* Dental abnormalities, such as Hutchinson teeth, are common

* The Hutchinson triad consists of Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and eighth cranial nerve deafness

* Clutton’s joints refer to unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling caused by synovitis with sterile synovial fluid, which tends to resolve after several weeks

* Soft tissue gummas 

* Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria

questions.text: 76. Which of the following cytolytic toxin is not associated with Staphylococcus?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus doesn't have theta cytolytic toxin. Theta toxin is an oxygen-labile hemolysin produced by Clostridium perfringens.

Staphylococcus has cytolytic toxins that are membrane-active substances, consisting of four hemolysins- alpha, beta, gamma, delta and leucocidin.

* Alpha hemolysin - It is a protein that gets inactivated at 70 degrees Celsius but gets reactivated at 100 degrees Celsius. It is dermo necrotic (on intradermal inoculation in rabbits), neurotoxic and lethal (on intravenous inoculation in rabbits). It is toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex and the circulatory system. 

* Beta hemolysin - It is a sphingomyelinase exhibiting a hot-cold phenomenon (haemolysis begins at 37 degrees Celsius but becomes evident only after chilling).

* Gamma hemolysin - It consists of two separate proteins.

* Delta hemolysin - It has a detergent-like effect on the cell membranes of erythrocytes, leucocytes, macrophages and platelets. 

* Panton-Valentine Leucocidin (called PVL) is also a two-component toxin, like gamma lysin. It is composed of the S and F components. Such bi-component, membrane-active toxins have been grouped as synergohymenotropic toxins.

questions.text: 77. A patient with a history of asthma presents to the clinic with complaints of wheezing and shortness of breath despite inhaled corticosteroid therapy. He also reports worsening of symptoms following Aspirin intake, characterised by nasal congestion. Which of the following is the most appropriate leukotriene receptor antagonist to be added for this patient?
questions.solution:
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that blocks CysLT1 receptors, effectively reducing the airway inflammation, bronchoconstriction, and mucus secretion associated with asthma. It is particularly effective in patients with Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease, as it can mitigate the leukotriene-mediated effects triggered by Aspirin. It is taken orally and has a favourable safety profile.

Other options:

Zileuton inhibits 5-lipooxygenase to prevent leukotriene synthesis and can also be effective in Aspirin-sensitive asthma, it requires frequent dosing and monitoring for liver function, making it less convenient than Monetelukast.

Doxophylline is a long-acting oral methylxanthine used for the management of asthma.

Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that prevents mediator release, but it does not directly target leukotriene receptors.

questions.text: 78. To maintain perfusion in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAS), the substance responsible is released from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
In the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAS), renin is secreted from JG cells/granular cells, labelled as 2 in the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

In the given image, 1 represents the macula densa. Specialized cells at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle form the macula densa. They detect the sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. 

3 represents the Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells between the afferent and efferent arterioles.

4 represents the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). It is not part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. It contains a brush border and is responsible for the reabsorption of solutes and water from the ultrafiltrate.

The afferent arteriole's modified smooth muscle cells manufacture, store, and release renin. Renin secretion is stimulated by increased sympathetic activity in response to low extracellular circulating fluid volume, low perfusion pressure in the afferent arteriole(RAS, in particular), and signals from the macula densa when salt delivery to the distal convoluted tubule is decreased.



Pearl PM1344: Factors that affect renin secretion

Stimulatory

* Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerves

* Increased circulating catecholamines

* Prostaglandins

* Na+ depletion

* Diuretics

* Upright posture

* Hemorrhage

* Hypotension

* Dehydration

* Cardiac failure

* Cirrhosis

* Constriction of the renal artery or aorta

* Various psychological stimuli

Inhibitory

* Increased Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa

* Increased afferent arteriolar pressure

* Angiotensin II

* ADH (vasopressin)

Pearl PM1346: Actions of Angiotensin II

Actions of Angiotensin II Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP

Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion

Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons

Constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow

Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption

Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II

Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text: 79. A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent abdominal pain, jaundice, and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. MRCP reveals a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct without intrahepatic ductal involvement. What is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRCP image showing fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct suggests a type I choledochal cyst. Type 1 choledochal cyst is mananged by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.



Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. They are more common in females and are typically diagnosed in childhood. The most common classification system is the Todani classification, which divides choledochal cysts into five types based on location and morphology.

The diagnosis is made initially with a right upper quadrant ultrasound, following which a confirmatory MRCP can be carried out to help in pre-operative planning. 

Treatment for type 1 choledochal cyst is a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy and radical resection of all the biliary tissue. Surgical removal is usually recommended because there is a risk of malignant transformation in long-standing disease.

Todani classification of the choledochal cysts along with their management is as shown below~ Type of choledochal cyst | Surgical management Type I -  fusiform dilatation of the bile duct (most common - seen in 75% of patients) | Complete surgical excision, cholecystectomy, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy Type II - saccular diverticulum from the common bile duct | Diverticulectomy, cholecystectomy, and common bile duct repair Type III- diverticulum within the pancreas, also known as choledochoceles | ERCP + sphincterotomy (Only cyst in which reconstruction is not required) Type IV

* A. multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic)

* B. - multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree | Liver transplant

Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy) Type V - multiple cysts involving only intrahepatic ducts (Caroli's disease) | Liver transplant

Pearl PM1539: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

* Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction

* CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS

* MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts

* ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract

* Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done

* PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract

* Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed

* EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: 80. Which of the following is an indication for alprostadil use?

choices.text: Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for the temporary maintenance of the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates, keeping the ductus arteriosus open. 

Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15 hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome,  and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of ductus arteriosus in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia, and cyanosis. Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates is essential in some congenital heart diseases before corrective surgery is performed, and alprostadil is used for this purpose.

Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, erectile dysfunction, and pulmonary hypertension. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

PGE1 analogs like alprostadil, misoprostol, and rioprostil can also be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

Other options:

Option A: PGF2α analog carboprost is used as an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Option B: Indomethacin a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug is used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus.

Option D: Dinoprostone (PGE2) can be used for the induction of labor.

questions.text: 81. Which of the following functions is regulated by the lateral superior hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior hypothalamus regulates thirst. It is also an integrating area for hunger. 

Other options:

Option A: Body rhythm control is integrated by suprachiasmatic nuclei of the hypothalamus.

Option B: Sexual behavior is integrated by the anterior ventral hypothalamus.

Option D: Temperature regulation is integrated by the anterior and posterior hypothalamus.
