questions.text: 82. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician by his parents with concern about his head size, noting that he has always had a larger head compared to his peers. On examination, his head circumference is in the 98th percentile for his age. However, he is developmentally on track, and there are no signs of neurological deficit. The paediatrician observes that the father has a large head as well. What would be the next step in the management of this child?

choices.text: Order a cranial MRI to rule out any structural abnormalities
Refer the child to a geneticist for further evaluation
Reassure the parents and recommend routine follow-up
Refer the child to a pediatric neurologist for further investigatons

questions.solution:
This child most likely has benign familial megalencephaly.

Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference greater than two standard deviations above the mean for a child’s age and sex. Megalencephaly, which refers to the enlargement of brain tissue, may be familial or linked to inherited syndromes or neurometabolic disorders. 

Children with benign familial megalencephaly typically present with an increased head size at birth that continues to track along the upper percentiles throughout infancy, while their body size, neurologic examination, and overall development remain normal. In contrast, children with metabolic causes often have a normal head circumference at birth, with macrocephaly becoming apparent as they grow older.

Evaluation for macrocephaly is recommended if the head circumference exceeds three standard deviations above the mean for age and sex or if serial measurements indicate a progressive enlargement, such as an increase of more than 2cm per month during the first six months of life or crossing one or more major percentile lines between routine visits. Measuring head circumference and assessing parental head size can be helpful in diagnosing familial cases. Generally, children with asymptomatic familial macrocephaly or benign enlargement of the subarachnoid space do not require treatment.

questions.text: 83. Choose the option in which the enzyme and its function are incorrectly matched.

choices.text: DNA polymerase - involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization
Helicase - prevents premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA
Topoisomerase - relieves torsional strain caused by unwinding of DNA
DNA ligase - sealing nicks in DNA strands

questions.solution:
Helicase is not involved in the prevention of premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA (dsDNA); this is the function of single-strand binding proteins (SSBs)

Helicases belong to a class of proteins involved in DNA replication. They are involved in ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options:

Option A- DNA polymerases - Involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization

Option B- Topoisomerases - Relieve torsional strain resulting from unwinding

Option D- DNA ligase - Seals nicks in the DNA strand during replication

Primase | Initiates synthesis of RNA primers. Topoisomerase | Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding. Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) | Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA. DNA ligase | Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

questions.text:
84. A 45-year-old male presents with abdominal distension and difficulty breathing. He reports a decrease in appetite for the past 15 days. Paracentesis revealed ascitic fluid with SAAG 1.1 g/dL and an ascitic protein level of 3.5g/dl. What is the most probable diagnosis?

SAAG- Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with abdominal distension, difficulty breathing, SAAG > 1.1 g/dL and ascitic protein level of 3.5g/dl suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Congestive heart failure.

Reduced cardiac output in congestive heart failure causes increased afterload and increased intravascular volume which further leads to ascites. Ascites leads to abdominal distension, difficulty breathing and decreased appetite due to the pressure. 

Serum-ascites albumin gradient can be used to differentiate between the different causes of ascites. It is given by the formula:                                     

SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level

Interpretation of SAAG:

* SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. Some possible causes are Cirrhosis, Congestive heart failure, Constrictive pericarditis, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.

* SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the aetiology:

* ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites as in Congestive heart failure.

* <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein as in cirrhosis.

Other options:

Option A: Tuberculosis has SAAG < 1.1 g/dL.

Option B: Cirrhosis has SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL.

Option C: Peritoneal carcinomatosis has SAAG < 1.1 g/dL.

Pearl PM2049: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: 85. A patient who was started on an antiepileptic drug presented with secondary angle closure glaucoma during the follow-up. Which of the following is most likely the drug responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Topiramate is the drug that causes choroidal effusions, resulting in secondary angle-closure glaucoma.  

Other adverse effects of topiramate include- Weight loss, renal calculi, metabolic acidosis, and somnolence. 

Adverse effects of other antiepileptic drugs: 

Valproate (option A)

* Vomiting

* Alopecia

* Liver toxicity

* Pancreatitis

* Rash

* Obesity

* Anorexia

* Teratogenicity

* Edema

Lamotrigine (Option B): Dizziness, ataxia, blurred vision, Severe rash (especially in children), and rarely Steven Johnson syndrome.

Rufinamide (option c): Nausea, fatigue and somnolence.

questions.text: 86. A patient has been diagnosed with keratosis obturans in the right ear. Which of the following tuning fork test results is seen in the patient?

choices.text: Rinne’s positive in the right ear
Weber’s lateralised to the right ear
Absolute bone conduction test reduced in the right ear
Weber’s lateralised to the left ear

questions.solution:
The tuning fork test present in this patient is Weber’s lateralised to the right ear (affected ear). 

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. It presents with conductive type of hearing loss in the affected ear.

In conductive hearing loss - 

* Rinne’s test is negative in the affected ear (bone conduction > air conduction)

* Absolute bone conduction test (ABC) normal in the affected ear.

* Schwabach test is lengthened in the affected ear.

Keratosis obturans is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytic agents such as 2% salicylic acid.

Note - Widening of the ear canal is associated with keratosis obturans, not narrowing.

Pearl PM1800: Tuning fork tests

Tests | Normal | Conductive 

loss | Sensorineural

questions.text: 87. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Pallor of the conjunctiva and pale skin are evident. Yellowing of the sclera is also seen. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. The image of the peripheral smear is given below. The urine urobilinogen levels in this patient will be ______
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the peripheral smear point to the diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. The urine urobilinogen levels are increased in cases of hemolytic jaundice.

This patient's fatigue, weakness, pallor of the conjunctiva, and pale skin are indicative of anemia. Yellowing of sclera is indicative of jaundice and splenomegaly suggests that the of anemia is likely to be hemolytic. Further, the peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes. These are red blood cells which appear abnormally small and lack the central pale area that is present in normal red blood cells. All these findings make hereditary spherocytosis the most likely diagnosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) causes hemolytic anemia due to a red cell membrane defect. The mode of inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis can be autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive (more severe). It can be caused by mutations of ankyrin and spectrin which are proteins found in membrane-cytoskeleton complex.

The diagnosis can be made with a positive family history, typical peripheral smear findings and some special tests. These include the osmotic fragility test, the acid glycerol lysis test, the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test, and SDS-gel electrophoresis of membrane proteins. Sometimes a definitive diagnosis may require molecular studies for demonstrating specific gene mutations.

When the jaundice is secondary to hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin. This results in the increased production of urobilinogen in the intestine. This is reabsorbed into the blood and appears in increased amounts in the urine. The increased levels of urine urobilinogen and the absence of urine bilirubin is suggestive of hemolytic jaundice.

questions.text: 88. Which of the following region of mRNA offers protection from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.  Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.

Other options:

Option A: The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

Option B: TATA box is the site of pre-initiation complex formation, which is the first step in transcription initiation.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: 89. A 5-year-old male child is brought to the pediatrics opd by his parents with a mass protruding per rectum, mucoid diarrhoea and stomach pain. A microscopic stool examination reveals the following. Which is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The history along with the stool microscopy is suggestive of a whipworm infection for which the drug of choice is mebendazole.

Trichuris trichiura is diagnosed by stool microscopy showing barrel-shaped, bile-stained eggs with smooth outer coat and a single underdeveloped embryo.



Whipworm infection affects the large intestine, causing mucous diarrhea, which later develops into rectal prolapse due to an increased rate of peristalsis. 

Albendazole can also be used as treatment, but it is not the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option A: Ivermectin can be used for Ancylostoma, Strongyloides, and filarial infections.

Option C: Praziquantel can be used for tapeworm infections.

Option D: Diethylcarbamazine can be used in filariasis.

questions.text: 90. An 80-year-old man is brought to the casualty after falling at the bus stop. An ECG was done, as depicted below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A shot of 1mg epinephrine IV is the best next step for a patient with an ECG showing asystole.

Asystole is the complete and sustained absence of electrical activity. It is usually seen as a terminal rhythm in a resuscitation attempt that started with another rhythm, or in a patient with unwitnessed or prolonged cardiac arrest. The prognosis for persistent asystole is poor. A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

Shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include Pulseless ventricular tachycardia and Ventricular fibrillation whereas Non-shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include Pulseless electrical activity (PEA) and Asystole. (Option B)

Given below is a flow chart showing the adult ACLS algorithm.



Other options:

Option C: Atropine was removed from the 2010 ACLS guidelines as standard treatment for cardiac arrest patients with a non-shockable rhythm or adults with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) or asystole due to a lack of clear benefit. 

Option D: Performance of endotracheal intubation should not precede an injection of 1mg epinephrine as the latter would be very beneficial to kickstart the failing heart. Also, an endotracheal intubation may be performed particularly in patients with a compromised airway.

questions.text: 91. A 7-year-old boy presents with dyspnea on exertion and bluish discoloration of lips, which is relieved on squatting. A chest x-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing cyanotic spells and chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette are suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has been classically characterized by the following components:

* Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)

* Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)

* Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and

* Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks (hypoxic, “blue,” or “tet” spells) are a problem during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved on squatting. Short episodes are followed by generalized weakness and sleep. Severe spells may progress to unconsciousness and occasionally to convulsions or hemiparesis.

Older children with tetralogy of Fallot characteristically increase pulmonary blood flow by squatting. Squatting is a compensatory mechanism, it increases peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and thus decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-ray describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

* "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot.

* The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.

* The aorta is usually large.

Other options:

Option B - A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium, coronary sinus, SVC, IVC, or ductus venosus.

On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart which is as shown below



Option C - A downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, a cyanotic heart disease. Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia. 

Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow as shown below.



Option D - An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum causing a left-to-right shunt.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard.

questions.text: 92. A boy presented to the emergency with severe rice-watery diarrhea and dehydration. Upon investigating, he was diagnosed to have cholera. On which of the following enzymes in the intestinal tract does the cholera toxin act?
questions.solution:
Cholera toxin acts on the adenylyl cyclase enzyme. The diarrhea is due to the action of this toxin that acts by stimulating the enzyme adenylate cyclase, which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin: 

The cholera toxin is made up of an active (A) subunit, and a receptor binding (B) subunit. B subunit attaches to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. Once bound, the entire toxin complex is endocytosed by the cell and the A subunit is released inside. This A subunit then binds to the stimulatory Gα-coupled receptor causing activation of cellular adenylate cyclase which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

High levels of cAMP start a cascade leading to overactivity of the cell resulting in outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the lumen. This is the reason for rice-watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.

All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

questions.text: 93. An unknown disease of suspected infectious origin has come up in your town. As a microbiologist, you collect the relevant samples and detect the etiological cause. Which of the following types of PCR would you do?
questions.solution:
Multiplex PCR can be used to identify an unknown infectious agent.

Types of PCR:

* Multiplex PCR: Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 

* Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. Used in GeneXpert to detect Mycobacterium TB and resistance to rifampicin.

* Quantitative PCR: Apart from just detecting the target sequences, it also  tells the number of such target sequences. We can quantify the HIV viral load with this technique.

* Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR. Unlike conventional PCR which can only amplify DNA, this one can even amplify RNA. It is used to detect H1N1 from Nasopharyngeal swab.

* Real-time PCR: This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR).

questions.text: 94. A 55-year-old male presents with intermittent abdominal pain, early satiety, and a palpable epigastric mass. A CT scan shows a well-circumscribed submucosal mass in the stomach. Histopathology reveals spindle-shaped cells with positive immunohistochemistry for CD117. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathogenesis of this tumor?

choices.text: Gain-of-function mutation in the KIT gene

questions.solution:
The patient presenting with intermittent abdominal pain, early satiety, and a palpable epigastric mass, along with a well-circumscribed submucosal gastric mass on CT scan, suggests a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Histopathology showing spindle-shaped cells with CD117 positivity confirms the diagnosis. The underlying pathogenesis involves a gain-of-function mutation in the KIT gene.

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract. It arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which regulate gut motility. KIT (CD117) or PDGFRA mutations drive GIST, leading to uncontrolled tyrosine kinase receptor activation, which promotes tumor growth and survival.

Clinical features include abdominal pain, early satiety, gastrointestinal bleeding (if ulcerated), and a palpable mass. Diagnosis is confirmed by CT/MRI, biopsy showing spindle or epithelioid cells, and immunohistochemistry positive for CD117 and DOG1. Management includes surgical resection for localized tumors and tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) for metastatic or unresectable cases.

Other options:

Option B: Loss-of-function mutation in the APC gene is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and colorectal adenocarcinoma, leading to Wnt signaling dysregulation, not GIST.

Option C: Overexpression of HER2/neu is found in HER2-positive gastric and breast cancers, driving epithelial cell proliferation, but GIST originates from mesenchymal cells.

Option D: BCR-ABL fusion gene translocation occurs in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) due to t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome), leading to dysregulated tyrosine kinase activity in hematopoietic cells, not gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

questions.text: 95. “Motorcyclist’s fracture” is which of the following

choices.text: Ring fracture of base of skull
Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.solution:
Motorcyclist's fracture is Hinge fracture of the base of skull in which base of skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge.



Option b- ring fracture Falls from a height onto the top of the skull or onto the feet, where the force is transmitted to the base of the skull through the spine, may result in ring fracture of the base of the skull around the foramen magnum



Option c- comminuted fracture Comminuted fractures are those in which the bone shatters into multiple pieces. They are commonly seen with the use of heavy weapon with broad striking surface and in vehicle and railway accidents.



Option d – depressed fracture Depressed fractures will force fragments of skull inwards. Blows to the head by implements, like round-headed hammers, may cause depressed vault fractures.

questions.text:
96. A 25-year old dancer presented with sudden pain in her right knee during her performance. On examination, the knee is swollen. The resident performs the test shown in the image and a click sound is heard at the end. The best investigation for diagnosis is ________.

CT - Computed Tomograhy

MRI - Magnetic Resonance Imaging
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image demonstrating a positive McMurray's test indicate injury to the menisci. The best investigation for diagnosis is an MRI. 

The rotational forces at the knee compress and rotate the menisci anteriorly or posteriorly, causing a tear in them. The medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral meniscus and hence is more prone to injury.

McMurray's test: This test is used to detect injuries to the menisci. The patient is made to lie in the supine position, and the knee is completely flexed. One hand is used to stabilise and palpate the knee joint while the other hand is used to internally and externally rotate the leg. The leg is then slowly extended. Any palpable or audible click indicates injury to the menisci.

The image below shows McMurray's test:



Other options:

Option A: Arthroscopy can also be used to diagnose, but MRI is more sensitive and can reveal tears that are missed by arthroscopy. Arthroscopy is invasive, although it is the gold standard, but it doesn't necessarily mean it is the best. A gold standard investigation refers to a method or procedure widely accepted as the most accurate and reliable for a specific purpose, while a best investigation can have broader criteria, including feasibility, cost-effectiveness, and timeliness. 

Option B and D: X-ray and CT scans are not used in the diagnosis of meniscal injuries.

questions.text: 97. A young man presented with seizures refractory to medication. The finding on the skull X-Ray is shown below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bracket calcification which is seen in the lipoma of the corpus callosum.

Majority of the lipomas arise near the corpus callosum. These tumors have marginal calcification where they merge with the adjacent cortical tissues. This gives rise to the characteristic bracket appearance. Intracranial lipomas are asymptomatic. Epileptic seizures are common and are occasionally refractory to anticonvulsant treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

* Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve

* Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges

* Mental retardation

* Seizures, hemiplegia

* Skull radio-opacities i.e tram track calcification.

Below image shows Tram track calcification



Option B- Tuberous sclerosis shows cortical tubers and calcification of ependymal nodules in the wall of ventricles. 

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 (chromosome 9) or TSC2 (chromosome 16) genes, which code for hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

Tuberous sclerosis presents usually at a young age. Patients may have retinal hamartomas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. The patients present with characteristic cutaneous signs. The first cutaneous sign that develops is the ash leaf macule, which is a macular hypomelanotic patch, commonly seen on the lower back. Another cutaneous manifestation is the shagreen patch, which is a hypermelanotic nevus. It is located in the lumbosacral region. The characteristic bumps that develop on the face are called adenoma sebaceum or facial angiofibromas.

The image below shows the characteristic ash leaf macule.



The below image shows adenoma sebaceum.



The below image shows Shagreen patch



Option C- Meningioma on X-Ray shows calcification, hyperostosis of adjacent bone, and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen falx. Imaging shows the presence of a dural tail sign.

questions.text: 98. You are working at a PHC and a pregnant woman in her second trimester is diagnosed with a bacterial respiratory tract infection. You need to prescribe an antibiotic treatment. Which one of the following medicines can be safely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Amoxicillin-clavulanate has a well-established safety profile during pregnancy. It is commonly used for bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections, without posing significant risks to the fetus. It is a first-line treatment option for many infections during pregnancy.

Other options:

A) Doxycycline belongs to the tetracycline class of drugs and is contraindicated during pregnancy as it binds to calcium in the fetus, leading to deposition in developing bones and teeth. This can result in permanent discoloration of teeth and bone growth inhibition.

B) Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is not recommended during pregnancy due to its potential for cartilage damage and musculoskeletal toxicity in the developing fetus.

D) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole - While this drug can be used cautiously in the second trimester, it is generally avoided during pregnancy due to the risks associated with trimethoprim, which interferes with folate metabolism (raising the risk of neural tube defects, especially in the first trimester). Sulfamethoxazole may also increase the risk of neonatal kernicterus when used near term.

questions.text: 99. A 50-year-old man has been complaining of left shoulder pain for the past several months. He is a painter, and he states that overhead movements now cause him pain in his left shoulder. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lateral shoulder. The doctor suspects a complete rotator cuff tear. Which of the following signs will he be looking for?
questions.solution:
This presentation of a painter with a history of pain in the left shoulder, and painful overhead movements points towards the diagnosis of Rotator cuff tear, which is characterized by a Drop Arm Sign (Option D) in which a person can not hold the arm in abduction and the arm drops rapidly.



Other Options:

Option A: Lag sign is seen in the tear of supraspinatus or infraspinatus. It is performed by asking the patient to lift his arms slightly away from the body and place them in maximum external rotation. A positive test is signaled when the patient cannot maintain that position on one side and allows the arm to drift into a more neutral position. This suggests a tear of infraspinatus or supraspinatus.



Option B: The Lift-off test is for Subscapularis.  The patient places one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The patient’s hand is lifted off the back and the patient is told to hold it there. The inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness.



Option C: Neer’s impingement sign is seen in painful arc syndrome. The scapula is stabilized with one hand while the other hand of the examiner raises the affected arm to the full extent in passive flexion, abduction, and internal rotation, thus bringing the greater tuberosity directly under the coracoacromial arch. The test is positive when pain, located in the subacromial space or anterior edge of the acromian, is elicited by this maneuver.



Important tests for impingement are:

* Painful arc test

* Hawkin-Kennedy's test

* Neer's impingement sign

* Jobe's test

Belly press test | Subscapularis Abduction paradox

questions.text: 100. A patient with stroke came to your OPD. His neurological examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the examination finding?

choices.text: It is non-rhythmic, non-voluntary muscular contraction
It is due to increased gamma motor neuron activity
It is due to decreased alpha neuron activity
It is a result of lower motor neuron type palsy

questions.solution:
Clonus is due to sustained hyperactivity of alpha and gamma motor neurons.

Clonus is defined as regular, rhythmic, repetitive involuntary (Option A) muscle contractions of the part of a limb (ankle, patella) when abrupt sustained muscle stretch is given. When the clonus is sustained for 5 or more beats, it is considered to abnormal.

Normally during flexion of the ankle, reflex extensor stimulation is inhibited by Renshaw cells. These cells are inhibitory interneurons that receive excitatory input from cortical fibers and lead to the inhibition of alpha and gamma motor neurons. Thus clonus is seen in upper motor neuron-type palsy (Option D) which removes the inhibitory cortical control, allows hyperactivity of alpha (Option C) and gamma neurons , and causes contraction of the ankle flexors and extensors in sequence. Management includes treatment of the underlying cause along with physical therapy.

questions.text: 101. Which of the following is the pathogenesis involved in Breast Feeding Jaundice?

choices.text: Increased enterohepatic circulation due to inadequate milk intake
Increased hemolysis due to blood group incompatibility
Breast milk inhibition of bilirubin conjugation by β-glucuronidase

questions.solution:
The pathogenesis for breast feeding jaundice involves increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin due to insufficient feeding, which leads to delayed passage of meconium and prolonged exposure of bilirubin to the intestinal tract, promoting its reabsorption back into the bloodstream. This increases the overall bilirubin load and can lead to jaundice.

Breast feeding jaundice is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which occurs in the 1st week after birth in breastfed infants. It is the result of decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. Frequent breastfeeding of >8 times /24 hr (NOT withholding breastfeeding), rooming-in with night feeding, and ongoing lactation support helps to reduce the incidence of early breastfeeding jaundice. Even when breastfeeding jaundice develops, breastfeeding should be continued if possible. Supplementation with formula or expressed breast milk is appropriate if the intake seems inadequate, weight loss is excessive, or the infant appears dehydrated.

Other options:

Option B: Inherited deficiency of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme would lead to pathological jaundice.

Option C: ABO incompatibility can cause jaundice in newborns, but it typically presents earlier, often within the first 24 hours and is one of the causes of pathological jaundice.

Option D: Breast milk jaundice occurs due to certain substances in breast milk, like β-glucuronidase, which can inhibit bilirubin conjugation in the liver. It usually presents in the second week of life unlike breast feeding jaundice, which occurs in the first week of life.

questions.text: 102. An elderly male with h/o CKD who missed his last dialysis session presents with shortness of breath. His BP is 170/100 mmHg, distended jugular vein and bilateral lung crackles. On examination, K⁺ is 5.8 mmol/L, and Troponin is borderline elevated with absent ECG changes. Echo shows a dilated left ventricle with an EF of 50% and moderate LVH. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a history of shortness of breath, elevated blood pressure, jugular venous distention, and bilateral crackles suggests fluid overload due to missed dialysis, leading to volume expansion. Left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction is more consistent with diastolic dysfunction.

Diastolic dysfunction is common in dialysis patients due to chronic hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy, which can lead to impaired ventricular filling and increased filling pressures, especially when fluid is overloaded. This patient's elevated blood pressure and distended jugular veins are classic signs of diastolic heart failure.

Dilated cardiomyopathy and LVH are the strongest risk factors for cardiovascular problems in patients with CKD, but this patient has ventricular hypertrophy, which is not a feature of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Hyperkalemia-induced arrhythmias are also a concern in dialysis patients, but the absence of acute ECG changes in this case makes this less likely to be the primary issue.

Acute myocardial infarction is less likely because the borderline troponin elevation in dialysis patients can be due to chronic kidney disease and fluid overload, not necessarily acute ischemia.

Pearl PM2427: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis Hemodialysis | Peritoneal dialysis Comparatively difficult access | Easy access Better clearance | Good clearance Short time for treatment | Longer time may be required Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane. | Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane Must be done in hospital | Can be done at home Complications:

* Hypotension

* Disequilibrium syndrome

* Muscle cramps

* Anaphylaxis reaction | Complications :

* Peritonitis

* Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections

* Weight gain

* Metabolic disturbances

* Residual uremia

questions.text: 103. Mr. Kumar, a 60-year-old male had pain in the eye and visual disturbances 2 days after undergoing cataract surgery. The image of his eye is given below. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows a picture of inflammation and hypopyon. This, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis:

* Cardinal features are pain, conjunctival or lid injection, and swelling and decrease in vision.

* Postoperative endophthalmitis patient classically presents acutely within 7 days after surgery with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber.

* The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Other modalities of treatment include:

* Topical antibiotic

* Cycloplegia

* Oral steroids

* Pars plana vitrectomy

Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterized by diffuse limbus-to-limbus corneal edema and anterior segment inflammation. The following points differentiate it from endophthalmitis

* Vitreous inflammation is rare (vitreous inflammation present in endophthalmitis).

* No pain/ little pain unless the IOP is very high. (Pain more often indicates endophthalmitis).

* A fixed, dilated pupil–often with spotty or diffuse areas of iris atrophy. (Not seen in endophthalmitis)

* Extremely high IOP early in the postoperative period is an unusual finding for endophthalmitis and points toward a diagnosis of TASS.

* A therapeutic response to topical steroids is clearly present for several days in TASS, unlike in endophthalmitis, where the patient's condition worsens even after the application of topical steroids.

Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: 104. What is the mechanism via which long-term lithium medication contributes to the development of hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Inhibition of release of thyroid hormone

questions.solution:
Lithium-induced hypothyroidism primarily arises from the suppression of thyroid hormone release from the thyroid glands.

Individuals who are undergoing long-term lithium therapy may experience the development of hypothyroidism due to the suppression of thyroid hormone secretion from the thyroid gland. This would further lead to reduced circulating T3 and T4 with increased TSH secretion from the pituitary. There are several publications that also propose the potential of lithium in inhibiting the conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3), yet the findings from these investigations lack conclusive evidence.

Patients who develop hypothyroidism as a result of lithium treatment are typically advised to continue their lithium prescription without interruption. In addition, they may be prescribed exogenous thyroid hormones as a supplementary treatment.

Individuals undergoing long-term lithium therapy are also at an increased risk of developing thyroiditis, although this condition is less common compared to hypothyroidism. These patients may continue lithium medication while also receiving carbimazole. 

Other options 

Option A: Amiodarone has reported thyroid receptor antagonistic activity while lithium acts by inhibiting the secretion of thyroid hormone from the gland.

Option B: Substances like milk, iron and cholestyramine are known to sequester thyroid hormones. 

Option C: Lithium is not known to cause damage to the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. However, it does lead to a rise in TSH levels due to inhibited release of thyroid hormones from the gland.

questions.text: 105. A toddler has been consuming excessive amounts of vitamin A-containing foods in the diet. The child has dry-flaky skin, frequent headaches, episodic vomiting, and splenomegaly. Which of the following findings would likely be seen on taking an X-ray of the long bones?
questions.solution:
The history of excessive vitamin A consumption along with scaly, itchy skin, headache, vomiting (suggestive of pseudotumor cerebri), and splenomegaly, all point towards a diagnosis of hypervitaminosis A. In this condition, x-ray of the long bones would most likely show hyperostosis.

Hypervitaminosis A refers to the excessive consumption of vitamin A. Amounts greater than 6,000 micrograms per day in children can be toxic (>15,000 micrograms in adults). Since there is no way to degrade the excess vitamin A, it gets stored in the liver and various other tissues. This stored vitamin will continue to exert toxic effects on the body, even if consumption is stopped. In young children, hypervitaminosis A can present with headache, vomiting, and even bulging fontanelles. Pseudotumor cerebri (with elevated intracranial pressure), can present with diplopia and even papilledema. There can also be patches of itchy, desquamating skin. Abdominal examination may reveal hepatosplenomegaly.

Bones may show hyperostosis on x-ray. This is an overgrowth of bone, commonly along the middle part of the shafts of long bones. 

Stopping further consumption is the only way to manage this condition.

The image below depicts hyperostosis-



Other options-

Option (A): Salt and pepper sign is seen in the skull in primary hyperparathyroidism. This disorder causes demineralization and resorption of bone, resulting in pathological fractures, bone erosions, etc. 

The image below shows the salt and paper appearance of the skull-



Option (C): Bone cysts can be simple or aneurysmal. They are usually incidental findings on radiographs. Sometimes these cysts can present with pain due to recurrent bleeding or pathological fractures. Bones cysts can sometimes be seen in hyperparathyroidism as well.

The image below depicts a bone cyst in the femur -



Option (D): Decreased bone density can be seen most commonly in osteoporosis. The most common causes for this decreased bone mineral density are- vitamin D deficiency, gonadal sex steroid deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, decreased bone formation with age, etc. Hypervitaminosis A causes the opposite in the form of hyperostosis.

The image below demonstrates decreased bone density in osteoporosis-



Pearl PM2180: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

* Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.

*  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.

* Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.

* In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.

* Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.

* Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).

* Prognosis:

* Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.

* Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: 106. Identify the postmortem change shown in the following image.
questions.solution:
The image shows Tache noire.

If the eyelids remain open for a few hours after death, a layer of cell debris and mucus forms a yellow triangle on the sclera at either side adjacent to the iris. The base of the triangle is towards the margin of the cornea and the apex is towards the canthus of the eye. This debris turns brown color when the dust settles on them. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

* Cornea: Dull, and opaque due to the lack of lacrimal moistening.

* Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure.

* Pupils- Soon after death, pupils are slightly dilated due to the relaxation of the iris muscles. At the onset of rigor, the pupils become constricted.

* Kevorkian sign- It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour.

* Increase in potassium concentration in the vitreous. It is helpful in determining the time since death.



Tardieu spots are the petechial hemorrhages seen in the scalp, eyelids, and face. They are commonly found in hanging and strangulation and occur due to acute increase in venous pressure, over distension and rupture of thin walled peripheral vessels and capillaries especially in their lax, unsupported tissues.

questions.text: 107. A 56-year-old patient who had undergone cataract surgery previously is noted to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding noted in the image above is Soemmering's ring, which is one of the types of after-cataract.

After-cataract is the most common postoperative complication encountered following cataract surgery. Soemmering's ring is defined as a thick ring of after-cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction.

No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear. If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

The image given below shows different types of after-cataract.



Other options:

Option A: Vossius' ring is a small ring shaped pigment on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule that occurs following blunt trauma.

Option C: Weiss' or Vogt’s ring is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: 108. Which of the following tests on live birth are based on the changes in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Wredin’s test is based on the changes in the middle ear.

Tests for live birth:

* Wredin’s test – Before birth, the middle ear does not contain air. It only contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and the gelatinous substance is replaced by air. For this, the middle ear must be opened underwater by removing tegmen tympani. If an air bubble comes out, the test is said to be positive. This is not at all reliable.

* Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30–40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.

* Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.

* Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70

* Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35

* Breslau’s second life test: Air enters the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. So if respiration has taken place, they float in water, otherwise, they sink.

questions.text: 109. The process shown in the image given below is used for which of the following?

choices.text: Trickling filter method for sewage treatment

questions.solution:
The image shown depicts the Nalgonda technique, and it is used for the deflouridation of water.

The Nalgonda technique was developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment. The process used for the defluoridation of water involves the addition of lime and alum followed by, flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration. This process can be used for domestic and community water supplies.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

* Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth. It causes mottling of dental enamel, chalky-white appearance, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance.

* Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

* Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

Other options:

Option A - Removal of the hardness of water involves boiling water or the addition of lime to it for temporary hardness, or Base exchange/Permutit method for permanent hardness.

Option C - The Trickling filter method is a type of Secondary treatment for Sewage.

Option D- Controlled superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

questions.text: 110. A 58-year-old male with type 2 diabetes is started on Sitagliptin. Two weeks later, he complained of severe, disabling joint pain. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue Sitagliptin and switch to an alternative antidiabetic drug
Prescribe NSAIDs to relieve joint pain and continue sitagliptin
Check serum uric acid levels to rule out gout

questions.solution:
Severe joint pain is a rare but significant adverse effect of DPP-4 inhibitors, including sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin, and alogliptin. The FDA has issued a warning about this side effect, which can be disabling in some patients. The most appropriate response is to discontinue the drug and switch to an alternative antidiabetic medication to manage blood glucose.

Other options

Option B: Continuing Sitagliptin while prescribing NSAIDs does not address the underlying cause of the joint pain.

Option C: Dose reduction does not alleviate this adverse effect as it is not dose-dependent.

Option D: While gout can cause joint pain, the timeline and association with starting Sitagliptin make the diagnosis unlikely in this scenario.

Patients typically experience resolution of symptoms after stopping the medication. Awareness of this side effect is critical in clinical practice.

questions.text: 112. A mass casualty was brought into the hospital due to an explosion. Which of the following statement is false about blast injuries?

choices.text: Tympanic membrane rupture is the most common primary blast injury
Traumatic amputations occur in tertiary blast injuries
Secondary blast injuries result in blunt injuries
Quarternary blast injuries include burns and inhalational injuries

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding blast injuries is secondary blast injuries result in blunt injuries.

Secondary blast injuries result in penetrating injuries due to the fragments that are accelerated from the explosion. Souces of fragments are casing of the device, nails, bolts, glass, stones adherent of near to the device, a bone from a suicide bomber. The velocity and wounding potential of the fragments are subject to inverse square law.

Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. Severity depends on the strength of the blast, range from detonation, and surrounding environment. Primary blast injuries predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the tympanic membrane, lungs, and intestine.

The most commonly injured hollow organ is the tympanic membrane > lungs. Damage to the lungs results in a blast lung that results in hypoxia, intrapulmonary hemorrhage, and pulmonary edema. The caecum is the most sensitive among intestinal blast injuries. Solid organs are more resistant to primary blast injuries.

Tertiary blast injuries result in blunt injuries due to gross movement of personnel, objects by blast wind. Traumatic amputation can occur in this type of blast injury.

Quarternary blast injuries refer to the miscellaneous injuries due to the explosion like burns, inhalational injuries, and late-onset respiratory problems.

questions.text: 113. An elderly male with primary open-angle glaucoma is prescribed Brimonidine 0.2% eye drops twice daily. One month later, he returns to the clinic with complaints of excessive daytime drowsiness, fatigue, dry mouth, and occasional confusion. He appears less alert and has difficulty concentrating. His blood pressure is normal, and systemic causes such as infections and metabolic disturbances have been ruled out. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue Brimonidine and switch to an alternative agent, such as Timolol
Reassure the patient that these side effects are mild and advise continued use
Advise the patient to take the eye drops at bedtime to reduce daytime sedation
Start the patient on a stimulant medication to counteract CNS depression

questions.solution:
In a patient on Brimonidine eye drops, the given symptoms are suggestive of the adverse effects of Brimonidine. The next step in management would be to discontinue brimonidine and switch to an alternative agent, such as Timolol.

Brimonidine is an α2-adrenergic agonist that lowers intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. However, it crosses the blood-brain barrier, leading to central nervous system suppression, particularly in elderly patients. Symptoms include drowsiness, fatigue, confusion, and cognitive impairment, which can impact daily functioning. Antiglaucoma medications should be selected carefully in older adults to minimize systemic side effects.

Other options:

Option B: CNS effects of brimonidine do not always improve over time and can worsen with continued use. Simply reassuring the patient is not appropriate.

Option C: Taking brimonidine at bedtime might reduce daytime sedation, but systemic absorption can still cause next-day drowsiness and cognitive slowing, which remains problematic for elderly individuals.

Option D: Using stimulant medications is not a rational approach to managing drug-induced CNS suppression. The underlying issue should be addressed by discontinuing brimonidine.

questions.text:
114. Few residents of a village presented with complaints of recurrent fever with chills and hepatosplenomegaly for the last couple of months. It was reported that there was a rise in the number of sandflies in the region. Which of the following measures is not useful in the prevention and control of the disease transmitted by it, according to NVBDCP?

NVBDCP - National vector-borne disease control program

choices.text: Enhanced case detection through rK39 rapid diagnostic kits
Treatment of cases using oral Miltefosine
Fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid

questions.solution:
The given scenario of fever, chills, and hepatosplenomegaly is suggestive of kala-azar, caused due to sandflies. Among the given options distribution of mosquito nets is not useful in protection against sand flies, which are much smaller than mosquitoes and therefore can pass through small holes in the mosquito net.

Strategies for prevention and control of Kala-azar under NVBDCP:

* Enhanced case detection through the introduction of rK39 rapid diagnostic kits (Option A)

* Treatment of kala-azar cases using oral drug Miltefosine (Option B). 

* Interruption of transmission through vector(sandfly) control by spraying/fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid (Option D)

* Incentives to:

* ASHAs as Rs. 300 for identifying each case of kala-azar, Rs. 100 for ensuring one round, and Rs. 200 for two rounds of insecticide spraying. 

* The patient being treated in the hospital as Rs. 500 for compensation of daily wage for the time he spends in the hospital during the treatment for kala-azar and Rs. 2,000 for PKDL.

Pearl PM1669: Mosquito Control Measures

* Anti-larval measures

* Environmental control

* This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.

* Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control

* Chemical control

* Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.

* Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.

* Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.

* Biological control

* The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.

* These are used in conjunction with other methods.

* Anti-adult measures

* Residual sprays

* Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)

* Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes

* Space sprays

* Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.

* Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.

* Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.

* Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.

* Protection against bites

* Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Pearl PM1686: Insecticides

Contact poisons

* Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils

* Synthetic:

* Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.

* Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.

* Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.

* Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.

* Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin

* Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.

* Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.

Specific Insecticides | Comments DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) | Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound. HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) | Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months. Malathion | Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray. Fenthion | Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray. Pyrethrum | Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: 115. Which of the following is not an indication for active rewarming?

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and cardiac output
Loss of consciousness and pupillary dilation

questions.solution:
A core temperature of 33 ºC is not an indication of active rewarming. 

Active rewarming is indicated when:

* The core temperature is less than 32 ºC (< 90º F)

* Presence of cardiovascular instability

* Extremes of age

* Nervous system dysfunction

* Hormonal insufficiency. 

Active rewarming can be done externally or by active core rewarming. External rewarming can be done by using forced-air heating blankets, external heat exchange pads, radiant heat sources, and hot packs. Electric blankets should be avoided as burns are common in vasoconstricted skin. 

Active core rewarming can also be done via heated humidified oxygen, heated crystalloids, heated irrigation of the gastrointestinal system, or bladder, closed thoracic lavage, peritoneal lavage. Severe cases require extracorporeal blood rewarming. 

Hypothermia is a disorder of thermal regulation when there is a drop in the body's core temperature to less than 35 ºC (95 ºF). As a result, there are changes in the body's physiologic mechanisms. 

Some features of hypothermia include impaired judgment, progressive depression of consciousness, paradoxical undressing, decreased cardiac output, arrhythmias, J wave on ECG, and asystole.  

Other options: 

Option B - Decreased heart rate and cardiac output is an indication of active rewarming as there is cardiovascular dysfunction. 

Option C - Loss of consciousness and pupillary dilation is a sign of central nervous dysfunction needing active rewarming. 

Option D - Elderly male patient with hypothermia is an indication for active rewarming. The elderly have poorer responses to thermal changes and may have systemic illnesses that impair heat generation.

questions.text: 116. A 23-year-old man presented with burns injury. His face and neck are covered with burns along with both the arms and sides of the chest. He requires both crystalloids and colloid resuscitation. Which of the following will you not follow while resuscitating the patient in the first 24 hours?

choices.text: Human albumin solution (HAS) is  commonly used
Muir and Barclay formula is used for calculation of colloids
Urine output should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body wt/hour
Proteins should be given within the first 12 hours of burn

questions.solution:
Proteins should be given after the first 12 hours of burn because proteins leak out of the cells due to intravascular fluid shifts in the first 12 hours of burn.

Human albumin solution (HAS) is commonly used for colloid resuscitation.

The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula. It is calculated as -0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion.

Urine output is a commonly used parameter to monitor resuscitation and it should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body weight per hour.

Pearl PM2215: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation (Updated according to ATLS 11th edition Guidelines)

Below are the formulae provided by ATLS 11th edition to calculate fluid need with a starting target rate. Subsequently, the rate of fluid provided should be adjusted based on patient response by monitoring urine output. Category of burn | Age | Adjusted hourly fluid rate of Ringer’s Lactate (ml/hour) | Target urine output (ml/kg/hour) Thermal burns | Adults & Children ≥13 years | [2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 | 0.5 (30-50 ml/hour) <13 years | [3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 | 1 ≤ 1 year & Children ≤30kgs | [3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 + LR containing 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate | 1 Electrical burns | All ages | [4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16

Children <13 years require LR containing 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate in addition | 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

* 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg

* 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg

* 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24 hours = TBSA % x weight (kgs) x 4. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours. However, ATLS in its 10th edition, recommended against the use of this formula due to the concern of over-resuscitation.

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

* Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA

* Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA

* 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

* 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2

* 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: 117. A 9-year-old child is referred to an immunologist with multiple staphylococcal abscesses and eczema. He also suffers fractures after trivial trauma. Examination shows increased IgE levels and eosinophils. Dental examination shows retained primary teeth. What could be a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of immunodeficiency fit the description of Hyper IgE syndrome or Job syndrome. The given image showing coarse facial features, abscess, retained primary teeth, and angular chelitis supports the diagnosis.

Job syndrome arises due to deficiency of Th17 cells due to STAT3 mutation. It is a primary immunodeficiency disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Features can be summarised as:

F: Coarse Facies

A: Cold Staphylococcal Abscesses

T: Retained primary Teeth

E: Increased IgE

D: Dermatologic problems (eczema)

The image below shows retained primary teeth in Jobs syndrome:

questions.text: 118. In a nuclear family cycle, the phase from the 1st child leaving the parental house until the last child leaving the house of parents is termed as ________
questions.solution:
The phase of a nuclear family cycle starting from the first child leaving the house and ending with the last child leaving the house of parents is called Contraction.

Pearl PM0845: The Family as a Social Organization

* A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.

* It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.

* The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

| Phase | Beginning | End 1 | Formation | Marriage | Birth of 1st child 2 | Extension | Birth of 1st child | Birth of last child 3 | Complete extension | Birth of last child | 1st child leaves home 4 | Contraction | 1st child leaves home | Last child leaves parental home 5 | Completed contraction | Last child leaves parental home | Death of 1st spouse 6 | Dissolution | Death of 1st spouse | Death of survivor

* Types of families:

* A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.

* The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.

* A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.

* A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.

* A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

* Functions of the family:

* Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)

* Division of labour

* Reproduction and raising children

* Socialization and social care

* Economic functions

* Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.

* Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: 119. A 45-year-old male patient who is diagnosed with schizophrenia is brought by his wife to the hospital. His wife says that he talks about suicidal ideas and has attempted suicide once. The psychiatrist changes the medication to clozapine. During the follow-up after a month, the patient says that his pillow is completely soaked with saliva in the mornings. What is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow?
questions.solution:
M4 agonism is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow. This is called 'wet pillow syndrome' in which there is hypersalivation. Pirenzepine, an M1 antagonist alleviates sialorrhea.

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is an antagonist of 5HT2A, D1, D3, D4, and α-receptors. Clozapine is used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidal patients with schizophrenia, severe psychotic depression, and Huntington's disease.  

Adverse effects of clozapine are:

* Sedation and weight gain- H1 antagonism

* Syncope, tachycardia, hypotension- α1 antagonism

* Hypersalivation/sialorrhea- M4 agonism

* Seizures- dose-dependant

* Agranulocytosis- dose-independent

The patient who is on clozapine should undergo regular hematological monitoring for the risk of agranulocytosis. Avoid combining clozapine with other agranulocytosis-causing drugs like carbamazepine, phenytoin, propylthiouracil, sulfonamides.

Clozapine reduces the seizure threshold thus increasing the risk of seizures.

questions.text: 120. Which of the following substances cannot cross the placental barrier?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ascorbic acid, iron, and IgG can cross the placenta and parathormone does not cross the placenta.

The placental membrane is a partition separating the maternal and fetal portions of the placenta. It acts as a protective barrier for the fetus and selectively allows the passage of nutrients to the fetus. Substances with a molecular weight of more than 500 daltons are not allowed to pass through the barrier. Substances crossing the placenta from the maternal to fetal blood first traverse the syncytiotrophoblast, the cytotropho­blast layer, the villous stroma, and finally, the fetal capillary wall. 

The syncytiotrophoblast actively or passively adjusts the amount and rate of substance transfer to the fetus. The fetal-facing basal cell membrane is the site of transfer to the intra-villous space.

Substances that can cross the placenta are as follows: Substances | Mechanism Molecular mass less than 500 DA 

Eg: oxygen, carbon dioxide, water, most electrolytes, and anesthetic gases | Simple diffusion Glucose | Facilitated diffusion with GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 Insulin, steroid hormones, and thyroid hormones | Can cross the placenta but very slowly Immunoglobulin G (molecular weight 160,000 Da ) | Endocytosis and trophoblast Fc receptors Iron (unidirectional from mother to fetus), Iodide, Calcium, Phosphorous | Carrier-mediated active transport Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) | Carrier-mediated active transport

questions.text: 121. A 71-year-old woman, who is a farmer by occupation, presents with the following lesion. Biopsy reveals full‐thickness epidermal dysplasia. Choose the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Periungual Bowen disease is highly recurrent

questions.solution:
The above image shows a red, scaly plaque-like lesion suggestive of Bowen disease. The incorrect statement about this condition is that abdomen is the commonest site of lesions. The lower part of the legs is the common site for Bowen disease.

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque. It is commonly seen in women after the sixth decade of life. It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the sun-exposed areas like lower legs, and head and neck region. Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 infections are associated with it. 

Bowen's disease when subungual or periungual affects younger women and is associated with a high risk of invasion and recurrence.

Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

questions.text: 122. A dead body is brought in for postmortem immediately after the death. You notice that the temperature of the body remains raised for about the first two hours after death. This can occur due to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for about first two hours after death is termed postmortem caloricity. It is not seen in cases of drowning.

Strychnine poisoning, septicaemia and sunstroke lead to an increase in body temperature for the first 2 hours following death.

The condition occurs:

* When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.

* Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.

* When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicaemia, cholera.

Other options:

Cooling of the body after death is termed as algor mortis. In case of drowning, cooling of the body in water will be faster because, water is a better conductor of heat. Cooling in still water is about twice as fast as in air, and in flowing water, it is about three times as fast.

questions.text: 123. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) picture shows the following. The most likely diagnosis based on the image is
questions.solution:
The image depicts smoke stack pattern in Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA). This is characteristically seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Fundus fluorescein angiography helps in confirming the diagnosis of CSR.

Two patterns are seen :

* Ink-blot pattern: It consists of small hyperfluorescent spot which gradually increases in size.

* Smoke-stack pattern: It consists of a small hyperfluorescent spot which ascends vertically like a smoke-stack and gradually spreads laterally to take a mushroom or umbrella configuration.

Image below shows Ink-blot appearance.

* Image B - Central serous retinopathy - Smoke stack pattern

* Image C - Drusen - Stars in the sky appearance

* Image D - Macular Ischemia - enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non perfused areas.

questions.text: 124. You are posted as a medical officer in a PHC, a 19-year-old rape victim is brought to you for medical examination and primary care. Examination confirms the incident and a sample of seminal fluid is collected from the vagina. What is the preferred emergency contraception given to the victim?
questions.solution:
The preferred emergency contraception for this rape victim is Levonorgestrel 1.5mg.

Emergency contraceptives include:
