questions.text: 125. Identify the bacteria based on the culture and microscopy findings shown below.
questions.solution:
The culture showing alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with optochin (Op) sensitivity, and microscopy showing gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, suggests Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).

S. pneumoniae (pneumococci) is a member of the S. mitis group. The virulence of the organism is a function of its polysaccharide capsule, which prevents or delays ingestion by phagocytes.

They are normal inhabitants of the upper respiratory tract of 5–40% of humans but can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis, bronchitis, bacteremia, meningitis, and peritonitis. Clinical features of pneumococcal pneumonia include sudden onset fever, chills, sharp pleural pain, and cough with bloody/ rusty sputum.

Diagnosis is by the presence of typical gram-positive diplococci in stained sputum samples. After some time, the organisms rapidly become gram-negative and tend to lyse spontaneously. This autolysis of pneumococci is greatly enhanced by surface-active agents, such as ox bile (10%) or sodium deoxycholate (2%).

Pneumococci are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar, and this is seen as greening of agar around the colonies. It is sensitive to optochin and shows a zone of inhibition, more than 14 mm around the optochin disk. This helps to differentiate pneumococcus from Streptococcus viridans.

They show characteristic Quellung reaction. When pneumococci of a certain type are mixed with specific antipolysaccharide serum of the same type (or with polyvalent antiserum) on a microscope slide, the capsule swells markedly and is seen as a halo around the organism. A positive reaction shows clumping because of cross-linking of the antibodies and pneumococci.

questions.text:
126. A 48-year-old working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty in breathing. Chest X-ray shows multiple linear opacities in bilateral lower lungs. Which of the following will be seen in this patient's pulmonary function tests?
* Increased Residual Volume
* Decreased DLCO
* FEV1/FVC > 0.7
* Increased FEV1
* Normal total lung capacity
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are correct in this case scenario.

The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with linear opacities on chest X-ray is Asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern.

Asbestosis results in diffuse interstitial fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease. On pulmonary function testing, there is

* Decreased total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV) due to diffuse fibrosis.

* In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or even increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.

* An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.

* Damage to the pulmonary capillaries due to fibrosis causes a decrease in diffusing capacity, resulting in reduced DLco.

* Flow volume loop in restrictive diseases shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

questions.text: 127. A 6-month-old infant with dysmorphic facies was brought to the clinic with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections of the skin, mouth, and respiratory tract. Interestingly, the baby has a Bombay blood group. Which of the following is likely to be associated with the underlying condition in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD)- type 2, which results from defective fucose incorporation. Craniofacial dysmorphism and the Bombay blood group are features unique to LAD-2.

LAD-2 is also known as the congenital disorder of glycosylation II-C. This abnormality prevents the incorporation of fucose into various cell surface glycoproteins, including the carbohydrate structure Sialyl Lewis X, which is critical for the rolling and adhesion of neutrophils to vascular endothelium.

Other options:

Option A- Defective β2 integrin occurs in LAD-1 in which steady adhesion of leukocyte to endothelial surfaces is defective. Some of the characteristics seen in LAD-1 are delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent pyogenic infections with onset in the first week of life, infections caused by Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, absent pus formation, and periodontitis. 

Option C- Defective kindlin-3 gene, which affects integrin activation cascade, is seen in LAD-3. LAD-3 is characterized by a Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, and skin and soft tissue infections similar to those seen in LAD-1.

Option D- Defective lysosomal traffic regulator (LYST) gene in chromosome 1 is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Patients have light skin and silvery hair. They frequently complain about recurrent infections, photosensitivity, photophobia, infections, and neuropathy. 

Note:

Both LAD and CHS are autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.text: 128. A 58-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease stage 4 presents to the clinic with symptoms of urinary tract infection. The physician is considering antibiotic options that are safe to avoid further kidney damage or toxic buildup of the medication. Which of the following is the safest medication?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is primarily eliminated through the gastrointestinal tract, making it safe for use in renal impairment, as it does not require dose adjustment in renal failure. This antibiotic avoids accumulation in patients with decreased kidney function, reducing the risk of nephrotoxicity or adverse effects related to renal impairment.

Other options:

Amoxicillin: While Amoxicillin can be used in renal impairment, it requires monitoring.

Ciprofloxacin: It is partially eliminated through the kidneys, and dose adjustment is required. High levels of Ciprofloxacin can lead to increased side effects, especially with severe renal dysfunction.

Gentamicin: It is primarily excreted through the kidneys and has a high potential for nephrotoxicity.

Pearl PM0493: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

* Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane

* Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

Intravenous anaesthetics:

* Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital

* Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

Opioids:

* Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil

* Unsafe:

* Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)

* Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)

* Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

Muscle relaxants:

* Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium

* Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: 129. A first-year medical student during a practical exam chooses a histological slide of the umbilical cord for discussion. The examiner focuses the slide as shown in the below image. The structure shown by the tip of the arrow develops from which of the following mesoderm?
questions.solution:
The structure shown by the tip of the arrow is Wharton’s jelly, which develops from extraembryonic mesoderm.

The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk develops into a gelatinous substance known as Wharton’s jelly.  

When the tail fold of the embryo is formed, the connecting stalk moves towards the ventral aspect of the embryo. The connecting stalk is now attached only in the region of the umbilical opening. The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk becomes Wharton's jelly in the umbilical cord. Wharton's jelly protects the blood vessels in the umbilical cord.

questions.text: 130. A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus. What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain. 

Sarnat staging of HIE: Signs | Stage 1 | Stage 2 | Stage 3 Level of consciousness | Hyperalert | Lethargic | Stuporous, comatose Muscle tone | Normal | Hypotonic | Flaccid Posture | Normal | Flexion | Decerebrate Tendon reflex/clonus | Hyperactive | Hyperactive | Absent Myoclonus | Present | Present | Absent Moro reflex | Strong | Weak | Absent Pupils | Mydriasis | Miosis | Unequal, poor light reflex Seizures | None | Common | Decerebration EEG findings | Normal | Low voltage changing to seizure activity | Burst suppression to isoelectric Duration | <24 hours if progress it; otherwise, can remain normal | 24 hours to 14 days | Days to weeks Outcome | Good | Variable | Death, severe deficits

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures. 

Poor prognostic factors in HIE are:

* Initial blood ph less than 6.7

* Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score

* Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing

* Seizure onset in less than 12 hours

* Burst suppression pattern in EEG

* Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion

* Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours

* Decerebrate posture

questions.text: 131. A 40-year-old man, who received a single dose of rabies vaccine five years ago as part of a pre-exposure prophylaxis but did not complete the full regimen, is bitten by a stray dog. The bite is deep, with visible bleeding. He seeks medical advice regarding post-exposure prophylaxis. According to WHO guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: No need for rabies vaccine or immunoglobulin
Two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3, without rabies immunoglobulin
Two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3, with rabies immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
This patient's wound is classified as Category III exposure (deep bite with bleeding). He has a history of incomplete pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and therefore will not be considered fully immunized against rabies. According to WHO guidelines, such individuals must receive a full post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen.

Full post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) includes vaccination doses according to either the Essen regimen (1-1-1-1-1) or the updated Thai Red Cross regimen (2-2-2-0-2) and rabies immunoglobulin administration at the initiation of PEP.

Other options:

Option A: The patient is not fully vaccinated and is at risk of developing rabies. He needs rabies vaccination and immunoglobulin administration.

Option B: Two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3, with no immunoglobulin - This is suitable for fully vaccinated individuals.

Option D: Two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3, along with rabies immunoglobulin – Only 2 doses of vaccination are not suitable as the entire vaccination regimen has to be administered.

Pearl PM1725: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:



WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted). There are no contraindications to post-exposure prophylaxis for rabies. It can be safely administered to pregnant women, infants, and immunocompromised individuals.

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

* Passive immunization

* Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine

* Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight

* Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.

* Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

* RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.

* The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.

* RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

* Multiple bites

* Deep wounds

* Bites to head, neck, and hands

* Patients with severe immunodeficiency

* Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal

* Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

* High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.

* Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult

* Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year

* Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

* Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm

* Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.

* Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

* High-risk individuals who receive pre-exposure prophylaxis should have their neutralising antibody titres checked every six months during the first 2 years following immunisation, and every 2 years thereafter. If the levels fall below 0.5 IU/ml, a booster dose of vaccine is recommended. 

Management of re-exposure to rabies virus

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

* Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency

* Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment 

For any exposed or re-exposed patient who has received and can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP:

* Proper wound management

* One site ID / IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3

* RIG not given

Only in case of exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP within the last three months, adequate wound washing alone is required.

questions.text:
132. A young adult male presented with chronic fatigue and gallstones. His father had a similar illness for which splenectomy was done. Investigations were done and shown below. Which of the following protein defects is not seen in this condition?

Hemoglobin- decreased Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased Mean corpuscular volume - decreased Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations and peripheral smear showing numerous spherocytes are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Laminins form part of the basement membrane which binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments. Mutations in laminin and laminin alpha 2 (merosin) result in the blistering phenotype of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) and congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) respectively.  

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene result in the most severe form of HS.



Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. They show normocytic normochromic anemia, an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration, raised RDW(red cell distribution width) and normal or reduced MCV (mean corpuscular volume).

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia and hemosiderosis.

Splenectomy is the current treatment of choice in HS.

questions.text: 133. A 50-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past week. There is no rash. His symptoms began after returning from visiting his daughter in South Carolina, USA. Laboratory investigations reveal leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows intracellular inclusions in monocytes, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows morula, an intracellular inclusion body in a monocyte. This finding along with the clinical vignette and history of travel to the southeastern United States is strongly suggestive of human monocytic ehrlichiosis caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis. 

E. chaffeensis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria that are transmitted by hard ticks such as the Lone star tick. 

Clinically, the symptom onset is typically within one to three weeks of exposure. Patients may present with fever, headache, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and weight loss. Rashes are generally absent. Severe human monocytic ehrlichiosis is characterized by meningoencephalitis, renal failure, respiratory failure, and shock. 

Diagnosis is by demonstration of the characteristic morulae in the mononuclear cells such as monocytes. They are intracellular inclusions formed due to the replication of these bacteria within clustered phagocytic vacuoles. Serological studies such as indirect fluorescent antibody tests and detection using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can also be used. 

The treatment of choice for human monocytic ehrlichiosis is doxycycline. 

Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum and the presence of tetrads (Maltese crosses), which are pathognomic of Babesia microti or Babesia duncani.

questions.text: 134. A 70-year-old female presents with fever and severe left-sided headache. She also gives a history of bilateral shoulder and neck pain over the past few months. On examination, there is left scalp tenderness. What is the ideal screening test and diagnosis?

choices.text: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) - Giant cell arteritis

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 70-year-old female (post-menopausal) with fever, severe unilateral headache, bilateral shoulder and neck pain (polymyalgia rheumatica) and scalp tenderness, is highly suggestive of giant cell arteritis which shows elevated ESR levels and hence used as an ideal screening test.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache, scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever and weight loss. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip.

Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, hypo-/normo-chromic anaemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and increased levels of IgG and complement. The diagnosis can be confirmed by a temporal artery biopsy.

The mainstay of treatment in GCA is steroids. Prednisolone 40-60 mg is given for one month followed by tapering doses. The duration of treatment is approximately 2 years or more.

Other options:

Option B: Polymyositis presents with symmetric and proximal muscle weakness that worsens over several weeks to months. Creatine kinase levels are always elevated

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age. It is associated with the presence of elevated antinuclear antibodies.

Option D: Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women and presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea and photosensitivity. It is not associated with polymyalgia rheumatica.

questions.text: 135. A 1-day old neonate’s mother says that her child has fluid coming out of its eyes. On examination, there is a mucopurulent discharge from both eyes, the conjunctiva is red and swollen. Gram staining of the conjunctiva revealed gram-negative intracellular bacteria. What is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Wash eyes, apply erythromycin ointment and observe
Inj. Ceftriaxone i.m., gentamicin eye drops, bacitracin ointment
Oral erythromycin with chlortetracycline eye ointment

questions.solution:
The history, examination findings and microbiological examination findings point to Ophthalmia Neonatorum or Neonatal conjunctivitis with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being the likely cause of the infection.

Ophthalmia neonatorum is the presence of mucoid, mucopurulent or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life. Time of onset after birth | Cause | Treatment Within the first 48 hours | Neisseria gonorrhoeae | Ceftriaxone inj im, gentamicin e/d, bacitracin e/o Chemical | Wash eyes, apply erythromycin ointment, and observe; usually improves in 24 hours 48-72 hours | Other bacteria | Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops 5-7 days | Herpes simplex virus | Acyclovir 3% e/o, systemic acyclovir for systemic involvement >1 week | Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K) | Erythromycin or chlortetracycline e/o, oral erythromycin

Investigations

Staining: Conjunctival smears should be stained with Gram stain and Giemsa stain.

* Gram-negative intracellular diplococci bacteria with polymorphonuclear leucocytes indicate Neisseria gonorrhoeae 

* Gram stain with polymorphonuclear leukocytes and lymphocytes without bacteria or the occasional bacteria suggests chlamydia trachomatis (d-k)

* Gram stain with many bacteria and polymorphonuclear leukocytes indicative of a bacterial infection like Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Haemophilus spp.

Conjunctival scrapings for chlamydial immunofluorescent antibody test and specimens send for viral, chlamydial and bacterial culture and sensitivity.

questions.text: 136. A 10-year-old child with Thalassemia major has been receiving blood transfusions and now shows signs of iron overload. Physician discussed both oral and parenteral options for iron chelation. Which of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.text: Parenteral Deferiprone is equally effective as parenteral Desferrioxamine
Parenteral Desferrioxamine is the treatment of choice for acute iron poisoning
Oral Deferasirox requires twice-daily dosing and is poorly absorbed
Parenteral Desferrioxamine is ideal for chronic iron overload management

questions.solution:
Desferrioxamine is a parenteral iron chelator with a high affinity for iron, making it the preferred option for acute iron poisoning, especially in children. It forms a stable, non-toxic complex with iron that is excreted in the urine. Desferrioxamine’s low affinity for calcium also makes it safer in terms of avoiding calcium-related side effects. It is not the most convenient option for chronic iron overload due to the need for injections and associated side effects, such as hypotension and histamine release.

Other options: 

Deferiprone may also be used for acute iron poisoning, but it is less effective than desferrioxamine. Deferiprone is an oral iron chelator; and is not given parenterally. It has significant side effects like agranulocytosis.

Deferasirox is well-absorbed and requires only once-daily dosing. It is adjusted based on serum ferritin levels.

Desferrioxamine is effective for iron overload but is not convenient due to the need for parenteral administration and potential side effects, making it less ideal for long-term management compared to oral options.

questions.text: 137. A non-resident Indian mother from the USA has brought her 2-year-old child to India for a vacation. Her child was not immunized with BCG at birth, and she wants to ensure the child receives the vaccine now. Which of the following is the appropriate course of action according to the Indian Academy of Pediatrics?

choices.text: Perform a Mantoux test and then administer BCG
Conduct an IGRA test and then give BCG
The BCG vaccine should not be given since the child has surpassed the age limit

questions.solution:
According to the Indian Academy of Paediatrics, catch-up vaccination of BCG is allowed up to 5 years of age. So, this patient should be administered the BCG vaccine straightaway.

The BCG vaccine is given intradermally at a dose of 0.1 ml in the left upper arm at the deltoid insertion site as soon as possible after birth. This vaccine is contraindicated in children with immunodeficiency and symptomatic HIV. It should be stored at a temperature between 2 to 8 degrees Celsius, as it is sensitive to both heat and light. The vaccine must be discarded 4 hours after reconstitution.

A positive Mantoux or IGRA test indicates only hypersensitivity due to exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not affect the level of protection provided by the BCG vaccine. Therefore, these tests are not necessary before administering the vaccine and should not influence the decision to vaccinate.

Note: According to the National Immunization Schedule, the BCG vaccine should be administered at birth, with catch-up vaccination permissible until the age of 1 year. However, the Indian Academy of Paediatrics states that catch-up vaccination is allowed up to 5 years of age.

questions.text: 138. Which of the following condition commonly has an appearance of watered silk on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
On fundus examination, the Hypermetropic eye has a bright reflex suggesting the appearance of watered silk.

Signs of hypermetropia include the following:

* Size of the eyeball: small.

* The cornea may be slightly smaller.

* Short anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

* Fundus picture:

* Pseudopapillitis - characterized by a small optic disc, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins and without disc edema

* Watered silk appearance - The retina, as a whole, may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections.

The convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.text: 139. The electrophoresis report below shows the serum proteins of an elderly patient with back pain suspected of having hematological malignancy. The patient was started on a proteasome pathway inhibitor. Identify the agent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where an elderly patient with back pain is suspected to have a hematological malignancy showing M-band on serum protein electrophoresis is suggestive of a plasma cell neoplasm such as Multiple Myeloma. Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor used in multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma typically occurs in the elderly population, and lower back pain can be a presenting feature, due to osteolytic vertebral metastatic lesions from the myeloma. Bony pain is the most common presenting symptom in multiple myeloma and should be taken seriously in the elderly. Persistent bony pain may indicate an underlying pathological fracture.

Electrophoresis refers to the movement of charged particles through an electrolyte upon being subjected to an electric field. Normally, serum electrophoresis results in 5 bands: albumin (55-65%), alpha-1-globulin(2-4%), alpha-2-globulin(6-12%), beta globulin(8-12%), and gamma globulin(12-22%). 

In paraproteinemias such as Multiple Myeloma, there is a sharp spike known as M-band that is seen on electrophoresis, as seen in the image given which occurs due to monoclonal production of immunoglobulins by plasma cells. This is shown below:



The treatment of Multiple myeloma includes chemotherapy with various regimens and finally, autologous stem cell transplant to replace the affected bone marrow. The algorithm for treating multiple myeloma is outlined below:



Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor approved for the treatment of multiple myeloma to induce adequate bone marrow suppression and make the patient eligible for transplant.  Its mechanism of action is the stimulation of the cell's unfolded protein response, thus pushing the cell toward apoptosis.

It achieves this by inhibiting ubiquitin-mediated proteasomal degradation of various pro-apoptotic proteins. It also blocks the degradation of I-kappaBeta, which remains in a complex to NF-KB, an important inducer of cellular proliferation, which is then unable to act in the nucleus. Thus the myeloma cells undergo apoptosis in the absence of proliferative signals.

It is used as a first-line agent and also in relapsed patients of multiple myeloma and has been additionally approved for refractory/relapsed Mantle cell lymphoma. Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, anemia, neutropenia, vomiting, diarrhea, peripheral neuropathy, and precipitation of hypotension, especially in volume-depleted patients. Neuropathy is the most chronic of all toxicities and ameliorates after discontinuation or dose reduction of the drug.

Other Options:

Option A: Ibrutinib is an oral small molecule Bruton tyrosine kinase inhibitor that inhibits malignant B-cell proliferation and has been used in Mantle cell lymphoma, Marginal zone lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, etc.

Option C: Sonidegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor approved for use in locally advanced basal cell carcinoma that has recurred following surgery or radiotherapy. 

Option D: Cladribine is an adenosine deaminase-resistant purine analog. It is incorporated into DNA as cladribine triphosphate and produces strand breaks leading to cell apoptosis. It is the preferred agent in the management of Hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: 140. A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?

choices.text: Analgesia during the second stage of labor

questions.solution:
A pudendal nerve block is not used for cervical cerclage, either spinal anesthesia or local block is used for this procedure.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

* During the 2nd stage of labor when contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia are present or if there is a requirement for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.

* Episiotomy repair

* Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.

* Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Pudendal nerve does not innervate cervix or upper vagina and so is not useful in uterine manipulation.

The image below shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

questions.text: 141. A 20-year-old patient presents to the ER with palpitations, headache, and sweating. There have been multiple such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. Investigations reveal a suprarenal mass and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine. The given clinical condition is associated with the germline mutation of all the following genes except ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pheochromocytoma and it has been associated with the germline mutation of all the above genes except NF-2 gene.

Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine, and suprarenal mass makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma is associated with:

* MEN-2: caused by germline mutations of the RET proto-oncogene

* Familial paraganglioma syndrome: caused by germline mutations within the succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, and SDHC genes.

* Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome: caused by a germline mutation in the VHL gene.

* Neurofibromatosis type 1: caused by a germline mutation in the NF1 gene.

questions.text: 142. A man from Bihar presented with normoanesthetic hypopigmented lesion as shown below. He had a remote history of admission for fever. No thickened nerves are present. What is the best-suited management?
questions.solution:
The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL). According to the NVBDCP, miltefosine is the preferred first-line drug for the management of PKDL.

Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a condition when Leishmania donovani is found in the skin and manifests as dermal lesions. It is usually seen in the kala-azar-endemic zones, i.e., Bihar, Jharkhand, U.P, and West Bengal (Northeastern states of India).

These patients present with erythematous rash and hypopigmented macules similar in appearance and distribution to those of lepromatous leprosy but normally less than 1cm. After a variable period of years or months, diffuse nodulation begins to develop in these macules. The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

Miltefosine is a relatively safe oral drug for the treatment of PKDL. Oral miltefosine treatment is administered to adults weighing more than 25 kg as 50 mg twice daily for 12 weeks. 

The image below shows post-kala-azar cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: 143. A patient was referred to the ICTC for HIV screening. He turned out to be positive by HIV spot test. A confirmation regarding the type of HIV was done using immunoblot for ART selection. Presence of which of the following proteins differentiates HIV2 compared to HIV1?
questions.solution:
Presence of gp36 points towards a diagnosis of HIV2.

HIV2 is genetically similar to HIV1 by only 40%. Moreover, it is intrinsically resistant to NNRTI, hence it should be differentiated from HIV1 for optimum ART prescription. Its prevalence is low in India (less than 3%), however widespread studies are needed. Clinically, HIV2 is slower to progress than HIV1

Western blot (WB) detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env. WB has a high specificity and is therefore used as a confirmatory test.

Note: In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

Apart from Western blot, Line immunoassays (LIA) and PCR to detect vpu or vpx genes, in HIV1 and HIV2 respectively can be carried out for confirmation.

questions.text: 144. Which one of the following is not a feature of absorbable meshes?

choices.text: They are used in temporary abdominal wall closure
They are used to buttress sutured repair

questions.solution:
Collagen deposition is maximum when non-absorbable meshes are used, not with absorbable meshes.

Absorbable meshes:

* Composed of fibres such as polyglactin or polyglycolic acid.

* Induce a sustained foreign body reaction and stimulate fibroblast activity.

* Associated with a lower incidence of infection compared with permanent meshes.

* Cause minimal damage to adjacent organs.

* Polyglactin 910 is completely resorbed within approximately 30 days, while polyglycolic acid takes around 90 days.

* Once the material is fully absorbed, it is replaced by collagen-rich connective tissue.

* The disappearance of the absorbable mesh may reduce long-term tensile strength, potentially compromising durable repair.

Nonabsorbable prosthetic materials (e.g., polypropylene):

* Provide lasting support as the implant remains in place, encouraging ongoing scar formation and connective tissue reinforcement.

questions.text: 145. A middle-aged man is being evaluated for complaints of seizures and visual disturbances. His magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is as shown. The transmission of the causative agent, in this case, is an example of?
questions.solution:
The MRI brain is showing multiple cysticerci within the brain suggesting neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. The transmission of Taenia solium is an example of cyclo-zoonoses. 

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from a vertebrate to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Cyclo-zoonoses is a type of zoonotic transmission that requires >1 vertebrate host species to complete the developmental cycle of the agent. They do not require any invertebrate hosts. Examples are the human taeniases, echinococcosis, and pentastomid infections.

Cysticercosis is a condition that occurs due to the infection by the larval stage of T. solium. Neurocysticercosis is the most serious and most common form of cysticercosis. 

Clinical features of neurocysticercosis include seizures, increased intracranial pressure, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, and visual disturbances. 

Diagnosis:

* Biopsy - the microscopy of the lesion shows invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks. It provides a definitive diagnosis

* Imaging techniques -  

* X-rays - may demonstrate calcified cysticerci in the subcutaneous tissues, muscles and skull

* Computed tomography scan - best method to demonstrate dead calcified cysts

* MRI - demonstrates non-calcified cysts, ventricular cysts, spinal cysticerci

* Serology -  

* Antibody detection - by ELISA in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid

* Antigen detection - by ELISA. Their presence indicates recent infection

* Ophthalmoscopy - to detect ocular cysticercosis

Treatment: Excision, praziquantel, albendazole.

Pearl PM1724: Classification of Zoonoses

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

* Anthropozoonoses

* Zoo-anthroponoses

* Amphixenoses

Classification based on life cycle if infecting agent is: Category | Mode | Example Direct zoonoses | Direct contact/fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission. | Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis Cyclo-zoonoses | More than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle. Invertebrate hosts will not suffice. | Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections Meta-zoonoses | Transmitted by invertebrate vectors. Inside the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies. After an extrinsic period of incubation, the infective agent is transmitted to another vertebrate host. | Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis Sapro-zoonoses | Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir. | Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

questions.text: 146. A 6-year-old child is brought with a history of cough for two months that has not responded to any kind of treatment and relevant investigations have all returned normal. The mother says that the child coughs loudly and abruptly but with no change in facial appearance or any other associated symptoms, and he does not cough when he is watching TV or sleeping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of chronic cough in a child, which is refractory to treatment, with no associated symptoms and not occurring when the child is asleep or distracted is suggestive of tic cough.

Tic cough, also known as somatic cough disorder, habit cough or psychogenic cough, is a behavioural abnormality in the paediatric population that is not associated with any pathology of the respiratory system. The child may begin coughing due to a URTI but continues to do so as a habit even after the infection has subsided. It is characterised by intense loud, abrupt coughing that does not match the child's affect. The cough is generally absent during sleep or periods of distraction. The frequency of the cough may cause the child to miss school and may lead to several medical investigations.

Behavioural and speech therapy are indicated for the management and the parents are to be reassured that there is no underlying pathology of concern and that the child may resume all normal activities.

Other options:

Option A: Common cold due to a viral infection is likely to be associated with symptoms such as sneezing, rhinorrhea and possibly systemic signs like fever and malaise.

Option B: Cough due to a foreign body is likely to be acute rather than chronic, and the presence of a foreign body is likely to be ruled out with preliminary investigations in a child. In this case, all investigations returned normal.

Option D: Cough due to adenoid hypertrophy is likely to be associated with grunting and exacerbation during sleep, along with other typical symptoms like adenoid facies and voice change.

questions.text: 147. You are a junior resident in oncology. A woman has been referred to the department with newly diagnosed breast cancer and she has asked you if she would be eligible for chemotherapy. Which of these features would prompt you to reply to her with a negative response?
questions.solution:
ER-positive tumors are usually candidates for hormonal therapy, and not chemotherapy

The indications for chemotherapy include:

* Locally advanced breast cancer: T3, T4/N2, N3 disease- to downsize the tumour.

* Select cases of early breast cancer:

*

* To downsize the tumour to facilitate breast conservation surgery (BCS)

* Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC)

* HER2/neu-positive tumours

* Premenopausal women (age <50 years)

3. Presence of axillary node metastasis.

Chemotherapy in breast cancer aims to downsize the disease.

questions.text: 148. A 17-year-old girl presents with a 2-week history of vulval swelling with increasing pain and fever for the past two days. Local examination revealed a right-sided erythematous, tender swelling on the posterior half of the labium majus similar to that seen in the image given below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Involved structure is homologous to male glands of Littre.
Biopsy should be done in elderly with recurrence.

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infection of the Bartholin gland i.e. Bartholin abscess. Bartholin glands are not homologous to the male glands of Littre.

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties.  

The male glands of Littre are homologous to mucous secreting periurethral glands in females.

Clinical conditions associated with the Bartholin gland are Bartholin cyst and Bartholin abscess. The cyst is caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation due to infection. An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess.

These infections commonly involve the duct and are most commonly sexually transmitted. It is generally polymicrobial. (Option A)Bacteroides species, Peptostreptococcus species, Escherichia coli, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are frequently encountered in the culture of purulent drainage. Less often, Chlamydia trachomatis may be identified.

Larger cysts can cause vaginal discomfort and dyspareunia. Abscesses will show erythema with tenderness. The cystic swelling and the abscess are both fluctuant. Bartholin cysts are transilluminating due to the clear fluid they contain. 

Treatment:

* Analgesics for pain

* Antibiotic for combating infections.

* Specific treatment:

* Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.

* Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management. (Option C) The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:

* Simple procedure

* Can be done even under local anesthesia.

* Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).

* The postoperative complication is almost nil.

* Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 

* Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement: A deflated Word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.

* Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

In older women with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy. (Option D)

questions.text: 149. A 10-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother, who was concerned that her daughter was shorter than her classmates. On examination, you notice that the girl has a webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline. Suspecting a genetic disorder, you get a chest X-ray done. Which of the following signs will be seen on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest and low posterior hairline in the 10-year-old girl are highly suggestive of Turner's syndrome. The cardiovascular lesion associated with Turner's syndrome is coarctation of the aorta which shows the figure 3 sign on X-ray.

Figure 3 sign is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta and occurs due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinum.



Coarctation of aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation and Turner syndrome. It is more common in males.

On barium swallow, the reverse figure 3 sign (also known as the E sign) is seen as the medial equivalent of the figure 3 sign seen on chest X-ray. It is formed by prestenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, indentation of the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

Notching of ribs (Roesler's sign) due to inferior rib erosion by dilated intercostal collateral vessels, is also seen in coarctation of aorta.



Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes (45 XO)- O for the absent X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, short webbed neck, shield chest with widely spaced nipples, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies.

Two X chromosomes are required for the development of ovaries and the loss of one X chromosome results in streak ovaries with inadequate estrogen production. The loss of negative feedback from reduced estrogen raises the FSH and LH levels causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Other options:

Option A: Egg-on-string sign is a characteristic X-ray finding seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA). It refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.



Option C: Snowman's heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.



Option D: Gooseneck sign is seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defect. It is the most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: 150. A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

* Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).

* Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.

* Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

* CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.

* Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.

* Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: 151. A man suffered from a stab injury to his hand and the muscle marked in the image below is injured. Which of the following movements will be affected in him?
questions.solution:
The muscle injured is the abductor pollicis brevis. Injury to this muscle will lead to loss of abduction of the thumb. Abduction of the thumb refers to the drawing of the thumb ventrally in a plane that is at the right angle to the palm of the hand.

The abductor pollicis brevis is a thin subcutaneous muscle that is a part of the thenar eminence. It arises from the flexor retinaculum, tubercles of the scaphoid, and trapezium bone. Its medial fibers are attached to the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, and its lateral fibres join the dorsal digital expansion of the thumb.

It helps in the abduction of the thumb. 

Other muscles of the thenar eminence

Medial to abductor pollicis brevis muscle is the flexor pollicis brevis. It flexes the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.

Adductor pollicis arises by oblique and transverse heads. The oblique head attaches to the capitate bone, bases of the second and third metacarpal bones, palmar ligament, and tendon of flexor carpi radialis. However, the majority of the fibers unite to form a tendon which is attached to the ulnar side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It helps in the adduction of the thumb. Adduction is the approximation of the thumb to the palm of the hand.

Opponens pollicis muscle lies deep to the abductor pollicis brevis. It is attached to the lateral half of the palmar surface of the metacarpal bone of the thumb. It flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve with the exception of the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis which are supplied by ulnar nerves.

questions.text: 152. Which of the following is the site of placement of the V2 chest lead while recording an ECG?

choices.text: In the fourth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum
In the fifth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum
At the anterior axillary line in the fifth intercostal space
At the midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space

questions.solution:
While recording an ECG, the V2 chest lead is placed at the 4th intercostal space, to the left of the sternum 

The site of placement of the chest leads is as follows:

V1: 4th intercostal space, right of the sternum  V2: 4th intercostal space, left of the sternum  V3: 5th intercostal space, left of the sternum (Option B) V4: 5th intercostal space, centered on clavicle(Option D) V5: 5th intercostal space, left of V4 V6: 5th intercostal space, under the left arm

An ECG can be recorded by using an active electrode that is connected to an electrode at zero potential (unipolar recording) or by using two active electrodes (bipolar recording).

For unipolar recording, six chest leads or precordial leads (V1–V6) and three limb leads (VR-right arm, VL-left arm, and VF-left foot) are used. Because the heart surfaces are close to the chest wall, the chest lead mainly records the electrical potential of the cardiac musculature immediately beneath it. Therefore, relatively minute abnormalities in the heart muscles can cause marked changes in the ECGs recorded from individual chest leads.



In some patients, posterior leads may be placed on the same horizontal plane as V4 to facilitate the detection of acute posterolateral infarction (V7 in midaxillary line; V8 in posterior axillary line; and V9 in posterior scapular line).

Right chest leads (V3R and V6R) can help enhance the detection of right ventricular involvement in patients with inferior infarction.

questions.text: 153. A 43-year-old woman was evaluated for uterine bleeding. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a swiss-cheese pattern. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Swiss-cheese pattern in histopathological examination of endometrium in a premenopausal woman is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica. It is characterized by massive painless vaginal bleeding.

Metropathia haemorrhagica/ Cystic glandular hyperplasia/ Schroeder's disease: It is a specialized type of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, usually seen in premenopausal women (40 to 45 years). Typically patients complain of continuous painless vaginal bleeding. It can occur after 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea or can be preceded by a period of menorrhagia.

The uterus becomes bulky due to symmetrical enlargement. The endometrium is thickened, and thin polypi project into the uterine cavity. There is also mild degree of myohyperplasia of the uterine wall. Ovaries may contain cysts, but the corpus luteum is absent.

Microscopy reveals:

* Swiss cheese pattern of cystic glandular hyperplasia.

* Absence of secretory endometrium- since the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium. so the cork-screw glands are not seen.

* Endometrium shows superficial necrosis resembling that of the first day of menstruation.

If the patient has a preceding history of amenorrhea, it can be confused with ectopic pregnancy or abortion. However, painless vaginal bleeding is the clue to differentiation.

questions.text: 154. Which of the following scenarios best defines atavism?

choices.text: A child with physical features similar to their cousins
A child inheriting a new genetic mutation not found in either parent
A child with physical resemblance to grandparents but not the parents
A child with physical resemblance to one of their parents

questions.solution:
Atavism is defined as a child exhibiting traits present in their grandparents but absent in their parents.

Atavism (from "Atavis = grandfather") refers to the reappearance of traits in a child present in remote ancestors like grandparents, but absent in the immediate generation, i.e., the parents. This happens due to chance recombination of genes, which can cause certain ancestral traits to re-emerge.

questions.text: 155. You are being asked to describe a normal chest X-ray in your final year practical examination. Which of the following statement is false regarding a normal chest radiograph?

choices.text: Lower lobe veins contribute significantly to the hilar shadow
Poor inspiratory effort produces prominent pulmonary vessels
Medial borders of the clavicles should be equidistant from the spinous process
Left dome of diaphragm is lower than right

questions.solution:
The blood vessels that contribute significantly to the hilar shadow in a normal chest X-ray are the upper lobe veins, not the lower lobe veins.

Features of a normal chest radiograph

* An ideal chest radiograph should not be rotated. No rotation implies that the distance between the medial end of the clavicle and the spinous process should be equidistant on both sides.

* A good inspiratory effort is also important in an ideal radiograph.

* With poor inspiratory effort, pulmonary vessels become more prominent and a false diagnosis of cardiac failure will be made.

* In a normal chest X-ray, the left dome of the diaphragm is lower than the right because the heart pushes the left dome down.

* In 97% of the cases, the left hilum is higher than the right hilum and in 3% both are at the same level.

* The pulmonary arteries and the upper lobar veins contribute significantly to the hilar shadow on a plain radiograph.

The most commonly used and preferred view is the PA view (posteroanterior view).

questions.text:
156. Which of the following statements is/are false about transfusion-associated malaria?
* Sporozoite is the infective stage of the parasite.
* Pre-erythrocytic stage is not present.
* It may be associated with severe complications and relapses.
* It has a shorter incubation period compared to mosquito-borne malaria.
* It requires radical treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3 and 5 are false. In transfusion-associated malaria, trophozoite is the infective stage (1). It does not show relapses (3) and does not require radical treatment (5).

Transfusion-transmitted malaria:

* This condition occurs when a person rcieves blood infected with the malarial parasite.

* The parasite may survive in stored blood for 1 to 2 weeks.

* Unlike mosquito-borne malaria where sporozoites enter the blood,here transfused RBCs containing the trophozoites enter the patient’s (recipient’s) blood directly. Hence, there is no pre-erythrocytic stage and the incubation period is usually shorter than mosquito-borne malaria.

* The patient may develop severe complications.

* However, hypnozoites are absent and there are no relapses, hence no radical treatment is required.

Other conditions where the trophozoites directly cause the infection include: congenital malaria (due to transplacental transmission from mother to fetus), renal transplantation, and shared syringes among drug addicts.

questions.text: 157. Cell growth can be stopped at some specific checkpoints in the cell cycle, as depicted in the given image. Which stage of the cell cycle demonstrates the primary point in the regulation of cell growth?
questions.solution:
The primary point in the regulation of cell growth is the end of G1 phase.

The sequence of events that results in cell proliferation is called the cell cycle. The cell cycle is regulated by activators and inhibitors called cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs).

The G1 restriction point refers to the stage in G1 where the cell is committed to advancing further into the cell cycle without requiring any more of the growth signal that initiated cell division. The G1-S checkpoint monitors DNA integrity before irreversibly committing cellular resources to DNA replication. Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2 regulate the G1-to-S transition by phosphorylating the Rb- retinoblastoma protein.

The G2-M is also a restriction point, but it checks for accurate genetic replication before the cell actually divides. When DNA irregularities are noted, the cycle is stopped and DNA repair mechanisms are activated. If repair cannot be done, cells either undergo apoptosis or enter a nonreplicative state called senescence through p53-dependent mechanisms.

questions.text: 158. A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. Which of the following antibodies are demonstrated for the purpose of early diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as 'white islands in a red sea' due to erythema with petechiae. Demonstration of circulating IgM antibody provides early diagnosis as it appears within two to five days of onset of illness and persists for one to three months.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. 

The four DENV infections can be asymptomatic or manifest. The diseases range in severity from undifferentiated acute febrile illness, classical dengue fever (DF), to the life-threatening conditions Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF)/Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). 

After an incubation period of 3–15 days, classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. During the febrile phase, dehydration can lead to neurological disturbances and febrile seizures in young children.  

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or DHF is associated with hemorrhagic manifestations, plasma leakage resulting from an increased vascular permeability, and thrombocytopenia. Plasma leakage is characterized by hemoconcentration (hematocrit increase of 20%), development of ascites, or pleural effusion.

Dengue Shock Syndrome is distinguished from Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever by the presence of cardiovascular compromise, which occurs when plasma leakage into the interstitial spaces results in shock. DSS is a fatal condition. Common clinical warning signs for DSS include a rapidly rising hematocrit, intense abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, and narrowed or absent blood pressure.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies. IgG antibodies can be done in paired serum samples.

The treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration, cold sponging, and paracetamol for fever. Aspirin/ NSAIDS like Ibuprofen should be avoided as they can cause gastritis, vomiting, acidosis, platelet dysfunction and severe bleeding. Fluid and electrolyte replacement and platelet infusion should be done for severe cases.

questions.text: 159. Which of the following tubes is ideally used for performing gastric lavage in patients with suspected poisoning?
questions.solution:
The tube used for performing gastric lavage is the Ewald tube. It is also known as Boa tube, stomach tube, or orogastric lavage tube.



Gastric lavage is the administration and evacuation of small volumes of liquid through an orogastric tube to remove toxic substances within the stomach. In adults, small amounts of warm water or saline are administered and, via a siphoning action, removed again. In children, normal saline is used because children are at greater risk of developing hyponatremia if lavaged with water.

In an unconscious patient, gastric lavage is performed after induction of general anesthesia with the patient intubated, to prevent aspiration.

Ryle tube (nasogastric tube) is indicated in intestinal obstruction and nutritional support. It is also used for gastric lavage but is preferred more in children.



Sengstaken Blakemore tube is used for balloon tamponade in case of hemorrhage due to esophageal varices.



Salem Sump tube is used for gastrointestinal decompression. It has 2 lumens.

questions.text: 160. You as a public health official in a developing country are tasked with selecting medications for a government-sponsored healthcare program. According to the WHO’s criteria, which of the following is the most important feature when selecting a drug for inclusion in the essentials medicines list?

choices.text: The drug must have adequate data on efficacy and safety from clinical studies
The drug must be the newest formulation available
The drug should be highly specialised for rare diseases
The drug should be available in a form that requires specialised equipment for administration

questions.solution:
According to WHO’s criteria for essential medicines, essential medicines should have adequate data on efficacy and safety from clinical studies to ensure they are suitable for the healthcare needs of the population. They should be affordable, available in appropriate forms and address prevalent diseases. This helps optimise resource utilisation, especially in developing conditions. 

(a) Adequate data on its efficacy and safety should be available from clinical studies.

(b) It should be available in a form in which quality, including bioavailability, and stability on storage can be assured. 

(c) Its choice should depend upon the pattern of prevalent diseases; availability of facilities and trained personnel; financial resources; genetic, demographic and environmental factors.

(d) In case of two or more similar medicines, choice should be made on the basis of their relative efficacy, safety, quality, price and availability. Cost-benefit ratio should be a major consideration.

(e) Choice may also be influenced by comparative pharmacokinetic properties and local facilities for manufacture and storage.

(f) Most essential medicines should be single compounds. Fixed ratio combination products should be included only when dosage of each ingredient meets the requirements of a defined population group, and when the combination has a proven advantage in therapeutic effect, safety, adherence or in decreasing the emergence of drug resistance. 

(g) Selection of essential medicines should be a continuous process which should take into account the changing priorities for public health action, epidemiological conditions as well as availability of better medicines/formulations and progress in pharmacological knowledge.

(h) Recently, it has been emphasized to select essential medicines based on rationally developed treatment guidelines.

questions.text: 161. A 3-year-old child develops the following type of skin lesions. What is the type of isomorphic/Koebner response, that would be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the center which is suggestive of Molluscum contagiosum infection, and the PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen in this condition.

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Molluscum contagiosum:

* The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.

* The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.

* In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).

* There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.

* Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

Pearl PM1956: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures. True Koebner's phenomenon | In immune-mediated conditions | Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: 162. All of the following are risk factors in developing epithelial ovarian cancer except
questions.solution:
Tubal ligation and hysterectomy are each associated with a substantial reduction in risk of ovarian cancer.

Theoretically, any gynecological procedure that precludes irritants from reaching the ovaries via ascension from the lower genital tract might plausibly exert a similar protective effect.

Risk factors for developing epithelial ovarian cancer:

* Nulliparity

* Early menarche

* Late menopause

* White race

* Increasing age

* Family history

* Personal history of breast cancer

* Ethnic background (European, Jewish, Icelandic, Hungarian)

* Postmenopausal hormone therapy

* Pelvic inflammatory disease

questions.text: 163. A 22-year-old primigravida who presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhea was diagnosed to be a case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following would be a contraindication to expectant management in her?

choices.text: Presence of fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound
Absence of evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
Serum β-HCG level of 300 IU/L and a falling trend

questions.solution:
In the case of ectopic pregnancy, the presence of a fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound is a contraindication for expectant management.

A gestational sac of 3 cm with no fetal cardiac activity, falling levels of serum β-HCG (with an initial level less than 1500 IU/L), and no symptoms are indications for expectant management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. It is done only in selected cases of asymptomatic women who are well-counseled and willing for subsequent follow-up visits.

* Conservative management

* Medical 

* Surgical

questions.text: 164. You are a medical officer evaluating the community health meal programs in your area. One of the program's objectives is to attract more children to maintain attendance in school. Which one of the following statements about this meal program is correct?

choices.text: Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
It should be a substitute to the home diet
The menu should not be changed to maintain consistency
The meal should not be prepared in schools

questions.solution:
It provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement is the correct statement about the mid-day meal program

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the ministry of education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meal should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of human resources development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text: 165. A 5-year-old child is bought to your outpatient department with complaints of bleeding gums. Investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. Further workup revealed a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX. What is the underlying pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX are suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is a disorder of platelet adhesion.

Platelet adhesion normally occurs due to interaction between Gp Ib of the platelets and von Willebrand factor (vWF) of the subendothelium of blood vessels. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the defect in Gp Ib/IX results in impaired adhesion of platelets. This causes a defect in the formation of the primary platelet plug, leading to abnormal bleeding tendency.

Other options:

Option A- Disorder of platelet aggregation - Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a disorder of platelet aggregation. It occurs because of the dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb–IIIa, which is responsible for bridge formation between the platelets by binding fibrinogen.

Option C- Disorder of platelet activation - These are characterized by the defective release of certain mediators of platelet activation, such as thromboxanes and granule-bound ADP. These include platelet storage pool disorders and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Option D- Disorder of platelet production - These may include disorders involving ineffective hematopoiesis such as leukemias and bone marrow failure or they may be drug-induced.

questions.text: 166. A 42-year-old man presented with recurrent abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year with increased stool frequency. According to ROME IV criteria he was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome of the diarrhea-predominant type. Which neurotransmitter is likely to be associated with the disease process of this patient?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhea-predominant type (IBS-D) is serotonin (5-HT).

Serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells in the colon are increased in a subset of patients with IBS-D compared to healthy individuals. Serotonin may contribute to the postprandial symptoms of these patients and provide a rationale for the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this disorder.

Pearl PM0774: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

* Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)

* Associated with a change in stool frequency

* Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.
