questions.text: 167. A 45-year-old female underwent mammography for breast cancer during her regular checkup. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mammography for screening of breast cancer is an example of Prescriptive screening.

Prescriptive screening is done for the identification of an unrecognised disease. It is done for the benefit of the individual being screened. It is used for early detection and treatment of disease in individuals.

Some examples of Prescriptive screening are:

* Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism and phenylketonuria

* Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer

* Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus

Other options:

Option B: Prospective screening is performed for the benefit of others or public health purposes rather than solely for the benefit of the individual being screened. It is used for disease control and transmission prevention. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.

Option C: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease, irrespective of the particular risk an individual might have.

Option D: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people.

questions.text: 168. A soldier infested with body louse comes with a 2-month history of recurrent fever with chills, headaches, and shin pain lasting for five days. The physician suspects it to be trench fever. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Also known as five day fever
Causative organism is associated with culture negative endocarditis

questions.solution:
Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana. It is an exclusively human disease and there is no known animal reservoir.

Trench fever is also known as a five-day fever. It occurred among the soldiers fighting in the trenches during World War. It is caused by Bartonella quintana and the vector is body louse.

Clinical features include sudden onset fever lasting for 5 days. It is associated with chills, headaches, malaise, shin pain, and restlessness.

Bartonella quintana is now frequently seen as the cause of culture-negative endocarditis in homeless individuals.

Bartonella henselae is another important organism in this genus. Cat is the animal reservoir for Bartonella henselae. It causes cat scratch disease, bacillary angiomatosis, and bacillary peliosis. In cat scratch disease, patients present with fever and lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. A biopsy of the affected lymph node will show the presence of rounded or stellate granuloma. Organisms can be seen with Warthin-Starry staining.

Bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis are mainly seen in HIV-infected or immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: 169. A patient underwent reconstruction surgery with a flap known as the Abbe-Estlander flap, shown below. This flap is used for the reconstruction of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Abbe-Estlander flap, which is used for lip reconstruction.

The Abbe-Estlander flap is a full-thickness lip-switch flap. Here, a part of the uninvolved lip is rotated across the mouth and into the defect of the involved lip.

The Estlander and Abbé flaps are based on the labial artery used for the reconstruction of the lip. The Estlander flap involves resection of the commissure, while the Abbé flap preserves the commissure.

* Up to half of the lip can be removed and closed primarily.

* Defects encompassing between one half and two-thirds of the lip require augmentation.

* Karapandzic flap consists of circumoral incisions with the circular rotation of the skin flaps while maintaining innervation.

* When the defect involves the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

questions.text: 170. A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of seizures. On examination, she has a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan showed characteristic tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Optic nerve glioma is not an ocular finding associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome, it is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. 

The characteristic features of Sturge-Weber syndrome include port-wine stain on the face, a history of seizures, and tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. The ocular findings commonly associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Important ocular manifestations in neurofibromatosis type 1 include:

* Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture.

* Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.

* Bilateral Lisch nodules are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.

* Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

questions.text: 171. A 3-year-old girl is being evaluated for congenital ptosis. On examination, there is retraction of the ptotic lid when she is asked to move her jaw from side to side. It is inferred that there is a misdirection of the nerve supplying the jaw muscles to the levator palpebrae muscle. Identify the misdirected nerve.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome. The misdirected cranial nerve supplying the jaw muscles is the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve labeled as '4'.

Trigeminal nerve

The trigeminal nerve leaves the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor root and a large sensory root. The nerve passes forward out of the posterior cranial fossa and rests on the upper surface of the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone in the middle cranial fossa. The large sensory root now expands to form the crescent-shaped trigeminal ganglion, which lies within a pouch of dura mater called the trigeminal or Meckel cave. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves arise from the anterior border of the ganglion.

Branches of the trigeminal nerve

* The ophthalmic nerve (V1)

* Leaves the skull through the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbital cavity.

* Contains only sensory fibers

* Cornea

* Skin of forehead, scalp, eyelids, and nose

* Mucous membrane of paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity

* The maxillary nerve (V2)

* Leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum.

* Contains only sensory fibers from

* Teeth of upper jaw

* Skin of face over maxilla

* Mucous membrane of nose, the maxillary sinus, and palate

* The mandibular nerve (V3)

* Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.

* Contains both sensory and motor fibers.

* Sensory from

* Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head

* Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint

* Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue

* Motor to

* Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter and temporalis)

* Tensor tympani

* Anterior belly of digastric

* Mylohyoid

Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

* About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.

* The vast majority are unilateral.

* Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.

* Signs

* Retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.

* Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.

* Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

questions.text: 172. A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome. The physician performs a clinical test, where direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs. Which of the following clinical tests is being performed?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is Durkan's test or carpal compression test.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

* Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.

* Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.

* Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:



The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40-50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

Other options:

Option D- Semmes-Weinstein monofilament test measures the response to a touching sensation of the monofilaments using a numerical quantity. It is used to detect peripheral nerve injuries and compression syndromes.

questions.text: 173. A 65-year-old man with benign prostatic hyperplasia is started on doxazosin. Two hours after taking his first dose of 2 mg, he experiences dizziness and reports nearly fainting while walking to the bathroom. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Upon review, the physician notes that he was also recently started on hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: First dose hypotension due to alpha-1 blocker

questions.solution:
Alpha-1 blockers like doxazosine can cause significant first-dose hypotension, particularly when taken with other antihypertensive agents such as diuretics (like hydrochlorothiazide in this case). This occurs because alpha-1 blockers cause vasodilation, reducing vascular resistance, which may lead to dizziness and hypotension. Thiazide diuretics, by reducing blood volume, can exacerbate this effect. 

Other options:

Hydrochlorothiazide can cause electrolyte disturbances such as hypokalemia, hyponatremia, or hypercalcemia, which may result in symptoms like muscle cramps or fatigue. However, dizziness and a sudden drop in blood pressure are not typically due to electrolyte imbalance.

A hypertensive crisis would present with a severe increase in blood pressure, usually resulting in symptoms such as headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, or visual disturbances. Since the patient’s blood pressure dropped (90/60 mmHg), this does not fit the presentation.

Doxazosine is a selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist; hence, beta 2 action is not the possible cause of his symptoms.

questions.text: 174. Radiological investigations of a patient with a groin hernia revealed a portion of the wall of the hernia sac is formed by the colon along with a defect in the posterior wall. According to Nyhus classification, what is the type of groin hernia is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above case, as the colon (internal organ) composes a portion of the wall of the hernial sac is suggestive of a sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia. According to Nyhus classification, a posterior wall defect along with sliding hernia is classified as type III.

A sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus is involved in the colon or urinary bladder.

* Type III - Posterior wall defect

* B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)

* C - Femoral hernia

questions.text: 175. A 52-year-old lady came to you in the outpatient department in the peripheral setting. She repeatedly self-medicates with antacid tablets. She complains of numbness in her hands. Which of the following is false with regards to the condition she is suffering from?

choices.text: Pernicious anemia is the most common cause
Upper limbs are affected before lower limbs
Methylmalonic acid, homocysteine levels are elevated
Myopathy is a key feature of the disease

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates vitamin B12 deficiency due to chronic antacid use, leading to neuropathy. Myopathy is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency.

A myopathy is a muscle disease that is unrelated to any disorder of innervation or neuromuscular junction. The common symptoms of myopathy include muscle weakness, impaired function in activities of daily life, and very rarely, muscle pain, and tenderness. 

Acid lowering agents like proton pump inhibitors alter the hydrogen ion secretion into the stomach leading to an increase in gastric pH. The change in pH modifies the bioavailability and absorption of vitamins and minerals, like vitamin B12. 

Pernicious anemia is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may produce several neurological manifestations.

A preferential large-fiber sensory loss affecting proprioception and vibration with sparing of small-fiber modalities occurs in Vitamin B12 deficiency. Upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected. 

An unsteady gait may be seen due to sensory ataxia.

Severe cases may show optic neuropathy and behavioral changes ranging from mild irritation and forgetfulness to severe dementia and frank psychosis.

Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated because the enzymes which metabolize them require B12 and in a deficient state these products start building up.

questions.text: 176. You are a medical officer at a blood bank. Following a medical camp, you have obtained around 10 units of cryoprecipitate. Which of these conditions cannot be treated with cryoprecipitate?
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate can be used in patients with Haemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, hypofibrinogenemia, and factor XIII deficiency as it contains factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, factor XIII and fibrinogen. Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX and factor XI. Therefore it cannot be used in patients with hemophilia B and factor XI deficiency.

Cryoprecipitate is prepared from fresh frozen plasma by thawing it to +4°C. The plasma is then centrifuged to obtain cryoprecipitate. It is stored at a temperature of–25°C or colder for up to 1 year after the date of phlebotomy.

During the administration of cryoprecipitate, ABO compatibility should be checked. After thawing, it should be transfused as soon as possible or maximum within 6 hours.

Uses of other blood components

Whole blood- Red cell replacement in acute blood loss with hypovolemia, and exchange transfusion.

Red cell concentrates- In patients with anaemia. Whole blood and red cell concentrates are stored between +2°C and +6°C .

Platelets concentrates- These can be stored up to 5 days at +20°C to +24°C, with agitation. It is used in thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, during massive blood transfusion to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia, and in bone marrow failure.

Fresh frozen plasma- FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from secondary centrifugation of platelet rich plasma. It is stored at –25°C or colder for up to 1 year. Before use, it should be thawed in the blood transfusion centre between +30°C and +37°C. It contains stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin and Factor VIII. It can be used in coagulation factor deficiency, reversing the effects of warfarin, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable.

questions.text: 177. The cutaneous lymphoma shown in the image below presents with patches and plaques, most commonly on the back. Histological examination shows the classic Pautrier abscess. This condition commonly progresses to a particular syndrome. Which of the following is not a feature of that syndrome?
questions.solution:
The image shown above with cutaneous patches and plaques and the characteristic Pautrier microabscesses is suggestive of a diagnosis of mycosis fungoides. Mycosis fungoides can progress to a syndrome called Sezary syndrome. Neutrophilic microabscesses are not one of the features of this syndrome.

Sezary syndrome is defined by the following clinical triad:

* Erythroderma

* Peripheral lymphadenopathy

* Atypical circulating mononuclear cells

Sezary syndrome is most often seen as a progression of mycosis fungoides (MF). MF is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It is more common in middle-aged men and people with darker skin. MF may present as dermatitis or eczema for a few years before progressing to the classical presentation of patches and plaques as shown in the image above. The most common sites involved are the trunk, limbs, breasts, and buttocks. The lesions may present with pruritus or be asymptomatic. As it progresses, the patient may develop, ulceration and pain or even widespread erythroderma. The gradual progression to Sezary syndrome with erythroderma and lymphadenopathy may be accompanied by the typical 'B' symptoms of fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Important investigations to consider are cutaneous and lymph node biopsies (showing the Pautrier abscess, which is a lymphocytic microabscess) and blood samples to count the Sezary cells (atypical mononuclear tumor cells). Treatment for both MF and Sezary syndrome depends upon the severity of the disease. Topical steroid therapy, phototherapy, and skin-directed radiotherapy can be tried as a first-line attempt. Advanced disease can be treated with methotrexate, interferons, chemotherapy, etc.

The progression to Sezary syndrome with erythroderma can be seen in the image below:



The Pautrier microabscess can be seen in the histological slide below (marked with an arrow). The Sezary cells within these abscesses can have a cerebriform appearance:

questions.text: 178. A 28-years-old female patient came to the psychiatric OPD with a sad mood and decreased appetite for a month. She had a breakup with her boyfriend 1 month ago. She says, "I do not feel like myself anymore. I can't live without him" She said she always did what he told her and they even got a cat together although she is allergic. Her two previous relationships ended on a similar note that she was nice but "too clingy". She works as a receptionist and has been going to work to distract herself from her remnant feelings for her boyfriend. She enjoys binge-watching shows on weekends. She is thinking to have a roommate. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
History of clingy, passive, and submissive (doing everything partner says, getting cat even if allergic) behavior are suggestive of dependent personality disorder.

A dependent personality disorder is characterized by passive and submissive behavior, the person is unsure of himself/herself and becomes entirely dependent on others (her thinking of getting a roommate after the breakup).

It comes under Cluster C personality disorders.

Other options:

Major Depressive Disorder: MDD is characterized by 5 or more of the following diagnostic symptoms lasting 2 or more weeks (must include one of the first two) - (DIGS SPACE- Mnemonic)

* Depressed Mood

* Loss of Interest (Anhedonia)

* Guilt or feeling of worthlessness

* Sleep disturbance

* Suicidal Ideation

* Psychomotor retardation or agitation

* Appetite/Weight changes

* Concentration problems

* Energy loss or fatigue

This patient does not meet the criteria for MDD.

Adjustment disorder:  The patient develops behavioral or emotional symptoms within 3 months of the onset of stressors. The distress is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor. Once the stressor has been eliminated, the symptoms do not last for more than 6 months. This patient has a sad mood that is in proportion to the break up which is not affecting her work (she is going to work and enjoys shows)

Borderline personality disorder: is characterized by impulsiveness, instability, feeling of emptiness and boredom, unpredictability, temperamental, and self-damaging concerning sex, money, and substance use.

questions.text: 179. A patient who was started on varenicline for smoking cessation now presents with insomnia and disturbed sleep. Which of the following is the best course of action?

choices.text: Reduce the dose of varenicline and watch for symptom improvement.
Switch the patient to nicotine chewing gum.
Switch the patient to nicotine nasal spray.

questions.solution:
Since varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation, and the patient has presented with a non-serious adverse effect, the best course of management would be to reduce the dose of varenicline or avoid the evening dose and watch for symptom improvement.

Since all three medications used for smoking cessation can be effective at lower doses as well, it is better to try dose reduction as a primary measure in patients with non-serious adverse effects.

Nicotine is the principal constituent of tobacco responsible for its addictive behaviour. One of the newest agents introduced to aid in smoking cessation is varenicline. Varenicline works by blocking the effects of nicotine on the brain. It blocks α-4, β-2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subtypes, inhibits dopaminergic activation produced by smoking through their partial agonism, and decreases the craving and withdrawal syndrome that occurs with cessation attempts. It prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system associated with nicotine addiction, thus helping to occlude the "rewarding" effect of smoking.

Varenicline is prescribed only to patients 18 years or older. Varenicline is taken orally at a dose of 0.5 mg OD on days 1 to 3, which is then increased to 0.5 mg BD on days 4 through 7 and 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks. Therapy should start one week before the target quit date. It can be continued for another 12 weeks (1 mg BD) to maintain abstinence.

The adverse effects include nausea, which can be mitigated by starting at lower doses and gradually increasing the dose. Other symptoms include disturbed sleep, sleepwalking, agitation, drowsiness, and constipation; it may also increase the risk of pancreatitis. Varenicline has also been implicated in specific skin syndromes such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, and photosensitivity. Varenicline can cause renal failure and kidney stones; therefore, renal function must be monitored.

The FDA has issued a warning about mood and behavioral changes associated with its use, and there is some evidence of increased cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: 180. A 25-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room in a state of altered sensorium, irritability, and aggression. His relatives give a history of a headache earlier that day, for which the patient had taken a paracetamol tablet. On further investigation, he was found to have a deficiency of citrin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is type II citrullinemia.

Type II citrullinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the deficiency of citrin due to mutations in the SLC25A13 gene. Citrin is a membrane transport protein in the urea cycle that facilitates the transfer of aspartate from mitochondria to the cytoplasm.

Patients usually present between 20 and 50 years of age, with neuropsychiatric symptoms like altered mental status, confusion, seizures, flapping tremors, irritability, or even a coma-like state resulting from hepatic encephalopathy. There are recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia which are usually precipitated by triggers like surgery, drugs (like acetaminophen), alcohol consumption, and high sugar intake. The patient will also have a history of aversion to carbohydrate-rich foods like rice, bread, and potato.

During an acute attack, elevated levels of ammonia, citrulline, and arginine are observed with low or normal levels of glutamine. Levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the RBCs are also increased. Demonstration of the gene mutation is useful for confirmation of the diagnosis.

It is managed with a diet that is rich in fats and proteins and low in carbohydrates with supplements of medium-chain triglycerides, arginine, and pyruvate. Liver transplantation helps to prevent the progression of symptoms.

Note: Deficiency of any of the urea cycle enzymes would result in hyperammonemia

Other options:

Option A: Type I citrullinemia is a urea cycle disorder caused by a deficiency of argininosuccinate synthase, which catalyzes the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate; Patients have a history of protein aversion, lethargy progressing to coma, and liver failure.

Option C: Hartnup disease is caused due to a defective intestinal transport of the essential amino acids such as tryptophan and niacin. Clinical features include pellagra like rash and neurologic manifestations such as cerebellar ataxia and delirium.

Option D: Type I hyperammonemia is also a urea cycle disorder caused due to a deficiency of the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthase-I, which is essential for the condensation of CO2, ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. Clinical features include irritability, vomiting, lethargy (especially a few days after birth).

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 181. A pregnant woman with an atrial septal defect presents for safe confinement. Which among the following is a predictor of adverse maternal outcomes in a pregnant woman with heart disease?
questions.solution:
Prior heart failure is a predictor of adverse maternal outcomes in a pregnant woman with heart disease.

Risk factors for adverse cardiac events include:

* Previous heart failure, transient ischemic attack, stroke, or arrhythmia

* NYHA functional class III–IV symptoms or cyanosis

* Obstruction of the left heart, defined as:

* Mitral valve area below 2 cm²

* Aortic valve area below 1.5 cm²

* Peak left ventricular outflow tract gradient above 30 mmHg

* Systolic function of the systemic ventricle <40%

The risk of pulmonary edema, sustained arrhythmia, stroke, or cardiac arrest was substantially elevated with one of these factors and even more so with two or more.

questions.text:
182. A patient presents with a sudden high-grade fever associated with chills and a productive cough for the past 3 days. A chest x-ray is taken which is shown below. The sputum is sent for culture and sensitivity. Arrange the following histopathological changes in the sequence of appearance during the course of this condition.
* Massive exudate containing neutrophils, RBCs, and fibrin
* Disintegration of RBCs and presence of fibrinosuppurative exudate
* Intra-alveolar edema containing few neutrophils and numerous bacteria
* Exudates containing granular, semifluid debris which is broken down by macrophages and fibroblasts
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of this patient showing high-grade fever, productive cough, and consolidation of the middle lobe of the right lung on chest x-ray is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia. The correct sequence of histopathological changes observed during the course of this condition is 3, 1, 2, 4.

Bacterial pneumonia is classified morphologically into lobular pneumonia and lobar pneumonia. Patchy consolidation of the lung is called lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia), while consolidation of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.

Stages of lobar pneumonia:  Stages | Duration | Morphology Stage I - Congestion | 1-2 days | Gross: Heavy, boggy, and red

Histopathology: intra-alveolar edema fluid containing few neutrophils, and numerous bacteria. Stage II - Red hepatization | 2-4 days | Gross: Red, firm, and airless

Histopathology: Massive intra-alveolar exudate containing neutrophils, RBCs and fibrin Stage III - Gray hepatization | 4-8 days | Gross: Grayish-brown

Histopathology: Disintegration of RBCs and persistence of fibrinosuppurative exudate Stage IV - Resolution | 9-10 days | Histopathology: Enzymatic digestion of exudate producing granular, semifluid debris which is broken down by macrophages or organized by fibroblasts growing into it.

Complications:

* Lung abscess (common in pneumococcal or Klebsiella infections)

* Spread to pleural cavity causing empyema or pleural fibrinous reaction to the underlying inflammation causing pleuritis.

* Bacteremic dissemination to other sites of the body causes abscesses, endocarditis, meningitis, or suppurative arthritis.

Treatment:

Solely depends on the identification of the causative organism and administration of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text:
183. Choose the false statement(s) about triple sugar iron (TSI) media.
* A pink color indicates fermentation of sugars.
* Blackening of the media indicates H2S production.
* Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.
* It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.
questions.solution:
All the statements mentioned above are true about the triple sugar iron (TSI) medium except that a pink color indicates fermentation of sugars. Fermentation of sugars is indicated by yellow color on the TSI medium.

TSI medium is a composite medium and is used for the identification of isolates. It is convenient and economical as a single composite medium indicates different properties of the bacterium.

It indicates whether bacteria ferments glucose only or lactose and sucrose also, with/without gas formation. It also indicates H2S production.

* If the slant and the butt turn yellow, all the sugars (glucose, lactose, sucrose) are fermented.

* The blackening of the media indicates H2S production.

* Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.

It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.

Examples of composite media:

* TSI medium

* Bile esculin medium - differentiates between Enterococcus (group D) and other streptococci

questions.text: 184. A study was conducted in a group to study the association between consumption of alcohol and esophageal cancer, with smoking being noted as a plausible confounding factor. Which of the subsequent characteristics of smoking is essential for it to be deemed a confounding variable?

choices.text: Its high prevalence in a society
Its equal distribution among alcoholics and non alcoholics

questions.solution:
In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor and in order for it to be deemed so smoking must have properties common with the exposure and the outcome of interest.

A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because:

* It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).

* It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome).

In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.

Other options :

Option B : Smoking must be related to the exposure, ie, those consuming alcohol, as well as the outcome, ie, esophageal cancer. 

Option C : A confounder need not be considered if its present in a highly prevalent population. Smoking can still be considered a confounder if its present in populations with lower prevalence.

Option D : Smoking can be present in either the alcoholic or non alcoholic group, but is not evenly distributed among both groups.

questions.text: 185. A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Screening for other defects and early cost-free intervention for this condition is covered under which of the following schemes?
questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is clubfoot (congenital talipes equinovarus or CTEV). Screening of this birth defect and early intervention are covered under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram scheme.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an important initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 ‘D’s which are:

* Defects at birth

* Deficiencies

* Diseases

* Development delays, including disability.

The first level of screening is done by medical officers, staff nurses, and ANMs, at all the places where deliveries are conducted. After 48 hours, up to 6 weeks, the screening of newborns will be done by ASHA at home as a part of the Home Based New-born Care (HBNC) package.

The target groups are divided into three groups based on age:

* Newborn to 6 weeks

* 6 weeks to 6 years

* 6 years to 18 years.

They screen all the babies born at public health facilities and at home, preschool children in rural areas and urban slums, and children up to 12th grade enrolled in government schools.

Defects screened during birth :

* Neural tube defect 

* Down's Syndrome 

* Cleft Lip & Palate / Cleft palate alone

* Talipes (club foot)

* Developmental dysplasia of the hip

* Congenital cataract

* Congenital deafness

* Congenital heart diseases

* Retinopathy of Prematurity

Other options :

Option B: Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: NSSK is a program aimed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation, has been launched to address care at birth issues i.e. prevention of hypothermia, prevention of infection, early initiation of breastfeeding, and basic newborn resuscitation.

Option C: Janani Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram: It is an initiative to provide completely free and cashless services to pregnant women including normal deliveries and cesarean operations and sick newborns (up to 30 days after birth) in Government health institutions in both rural & urban areas.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: 186. A 45-year-old man working in a poorly ventilated underground facility develops headache, confusion, and mild shortness of breath. ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO₂ 60 mmHg, PaO₂ 90 mmHg, and HCO₃⁻ 26 mEq/L. Despite hyperventilation during the examination, his PaCO₂ continues to rise, leading to worsening drowsiness. What best explains his progressive respiratory failure?

choices.text: Desensitization of peripheral chemoreceptors to CO₂
Linear increase in minute ventilation with rising PaCO₂
Inhibition of the medullary respiratory center
Decreased CO₂ solubility in blood at high partial pressures

questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing progressive hypercapnia (high CO₂ levels) in a poorly ventilated underground facility. This is leading to respiratory acidosis with neurologic symptoms (headache, confusion, drowsiness), which is characteristic of CO₂ narcosis. In this condition, excessively high levels of CO₂ depress the central nervous system (CNS), including the respiratory center in the medulla.

CO₂ is a potent respiratory stimulant that triggers increased ventilation through central chemoreceptors in the medulla. Initially, inhaling CO₂ leads to hyperventilation, increasing CO₂ excretion and limiting the rise in arterial PCO₂. However, when inspired CO₂ exceeds 7%, ventilation can no longer compensate, and PaCO₂ rises uncontrollably. This leads to CO₂ narcosis, a state of CNS depression that causes confusion, headache, and eventually coma. 

Other options:

Option A: Desensitization of peripheral chemoreceptors to CO₂ -Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies sense PaO₂ and pH (not just CO₂). While chronic CO₂ retention (e.g., in COPD) can lead to desensitization, this process takes days to weeks, not hours.

Option B: Linear increase in minute ventilation with rising PaCO₂ -Normally, ventilation increases linearly with CO₂ up to a point. However, at very high PaCO₂ levels, the system fails due to direct CNS depression, leading to decreasing ventilation (CO₂ narcosis).

Option D: CO₂ remains highly soluble in blood even at high pressures. The issue here is neurologic depression, not CO₂ solubility.

questions.text: 187. What type of gland produces the secretions removed by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Wax-producing ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands.

Wax is composed of secretion of sebaceous glands, ceruminous glands, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin and dirt.

The thick subcutaneous tissue of the cartilaginous part of the external auditory meatus contains numerous ceruminous glands that secrete wax, or cerumen. The medial bony part of EAC and the auricle are normally devoid of these glands, although they can be seen rarely as an incidental finding. 

Their coiled tubular structure resembles that of sweat glands. The secretory cells are columnar when active but cuboidal when quiescent; they are covered externally by myoepithelial cells. Ducts open either onto the epithelial surface or into the nearby sebaceous gland of a hair follicle.

Syringing is a procedure where the pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and a stream of water from the ear syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. The pressure of water, built up deeper into the wax, expels the wax out.

Types of glands: Apocrine | Holocrine | Eccrine(Merocrine) Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge | Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge | The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll) | Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland 

Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola

Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce

Fordyce's spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa | Eg: Sweat glands on palms and soles

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips



Pearl PM0709: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature | Apocrine sweat gland | Eccrine sweat gland Activity | Active at puberty | Throughout life Opening on the surface | Around hair shaft | Through sweat pores Function | Provides peculiar odour | Maintains temperature Nervous control | Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are adrenergic | Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are cholinergic Secretions | Viscid with lipids and proteins | Watery with salts

questions.text: 188. A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with intractable abdominal pain unresponsive to opioids. The anesthetist decides to opt for a regional block. Which of the following would he choose?
questions.solution:
The block he would choose in a case of pancreatic cancer is celiac plexus block.

The celiac plexus block is indicated in patients with pain arising from the abdominal viscera, specifically intraabdominal cancers. 

The celiac ganglia are generally clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left. It is posterior to the pancreas. 

The patient should be placed in a prone position and 15-20 ml of local anesthetic is injected under fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasound guidance. The needle should be inserted 7-8 cm from the midline at the inferior edge of the spinous process of L1. 

The approaches that can be taken for this block include the posterior retrocrural approach, posterior anterocrural approach, posterior transaortic approach, and an anterior approach. 

The most common complication is postural hypotension. This occurs due to blocking of visceral sympathetic innervation which results in vasodilation. To prevent this, the patient should be adequately intravenously hydrated. 

Other complications include diarrhea (secondary to blockade of sympathetic fibers), pneumothorax, retroperitoneal hemorrhage and visceral organ injury.

Other options: 

Option A - The stellate block is indicated in patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. 

Option C - The lumbar sympathetic block is indicated in painful conditions involving the pelvis and lower extremities like a peripheral vascular disease. 

Option D - The superior hypogastric plexus block is indicated in pelvic pain that is unresponsive to lumbar or caudal epidural blocks. It is used in patients with cancer of the pelvic organs or non cancer pelvic pain.

questions.text: 189. A woman with a history of two previous cesarean deliveries visits the family planning clinic to discuss long-term contraception. She wants a method that can reduce dysmenorrhea and improve bone health. Which of the following is the most appropriate option for her?
questions.solution:
In this case, the most appropriate long-term contraception that also provides non-contraceptive benefits such as reduced dysmenorrhea and improved bone health will be the Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS).

The following points favor the use of LNG-IUS:

* Contraceptive efficacy: The LNG-IUS is highly effective with a low failure rate.

* Non-contraceptive benefits: - Reduces menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea by thinning the endometrium. - Can be used in conditions like adenomyosis or menorrhagia. - Improves bone mineral density indirectly by reducing hypoestrogenic states in premenopausal women.

* Suitability after cesarean sections: Safe to use in women with prior cesarean deliveries.

Other options:

Option A) Cu-IUD : Effective but does not reduce dysmenorrhea or improve bone health; it may worsen menstrual cramps and bleeding.

Option B) COCPs : Improves bone health and reduces dysmenorrhea, but long-term use increases the risk of venous thromboembolism, especially in women >35 or those with cesarean history.

Option D)Tubal ligation : A permanent method that does not provide non-contraceptive benefits like those listed above.

questions.text: 190. A neonate has a cardiac murmur and the eye finding shown in the image below. Investigations revealed bilateral hearing defect. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. The most common cardiac defect seen in such neonates is:
questions.solution:
Maternal history of viral exanthem in the first trimester and the image showing the presence of bilateral congenital cataract and hearing defect is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common cardiac defect associated with this condition.

Congenital rubella syndrome is associated with rubella infection in mothers in early pregnancy. The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

* Sensorineural hearing loss

* Congenital cataract

questions.text: 191. A 2-year-old male child is brought with complaints of delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability. On examination, the child had coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea. Which of the following recombinant enzymes is useful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with intellectual disability, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea is suggestive of Hunter's disease. Idursulfase a.k.a Elaprase is used in the treatment of this condition.

Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II (MPS II) resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

All MPS are inherited in an AR manner, except Hunter’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The clinical features include coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike other mucopolysaccharidosis, these patients lack clouding of the cornea.  

Elaprase a.k.a Idursulfase (Recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice for Hunter's disease to ameliorate nonneural manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C: Galsulfase a.k.a Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, marked corneal clouding, and contractures. 

Option D: Myozyme a.k.a alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding.

questions.text: 192. A farmer from a tribal area is referred from his PHC with complaints of chest pain and hemoptysis. A CT chest was done and the finding is given in the image. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.

It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.

questions.text: 193. Macrophages are the most dominant cells in chronic inflammation. There are 2 major pathways for macrophage recruitment: classical and alternate. Which of the following is not part of the classical pathway for macrophage activation?
questions.solution:
Interleukin 4 and interleukin 13 are part of an alternate pathway for macrophage activation

There are two major pathways of macrophage activation called classical and alternative, that endow macrophages with different functional activities

Classical macrophage activation may be induced by microbial products such as endotoxin, which engage TLRs and other sensors; by T cell-derived signals, importantly the cytokine IFN-γ, in immune responses; or by foreign substances, including crystals and particulate matter. Classically activated (also called M1) macrophages produce NO and lysosomal enzymes, which enhance their ability to kill ingested organisms, and secrete cytokines that stimulate inflammation. The main role of these macrophages in host defense is to destroy microbes and promote the inflammatory response.

Alternative macrophage activation is induced by cytokines other than IFN-γ, such as IL-4 and IL-13, produced by T lymphocytes and other cells. These macrophages are not actively microbicidal; instead, their principal functions are to terminate inflammation and promote tissue repair.

Chronic inflammation is characterized by the following: 

* Infiltration with mononuclear cells, which include macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells

* Tissue destruction, induced by the persistent offending agent or by the inflammatory cells.

* Attempts at healing by connective tissue replacement of damaged tissue, accomplished by angiogenesis (proliferation of small blood vessels) and, in particular, fibrosis

questions.solution:
Littre's hernia is a rare inguinal hernia where Meckel's diverticulum is the content of the sac. Meckel’s diverticulum is the embryological remnant of the proximal 1/3rd of the vitellointestinal duct.

questions.text: 196. While performing laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery, a surgeon mistakenly applies the stapler in the lateral half of the trapezoid of disaster. Which of the following complications can occur due to this?
questions.solution:
Chronic pain in the lateral thigh can be caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve which is a content of the triangle of pain which forms the lateral half of the trapezoid of disaster.

The trapezoid of disaster is a zone made of the triangle of doom and the triangle of pain, and surgeons avoid it due to the presence of important structures.

Triangle of Doom Boundaries: 

Medial - Vas deferens Lateral - Testicular vessels Apex- Deep inguinal ring Inferior - Peritoneal reflection Contents- External iliac artery and vein, deep circumflex iliac vein, genital branch of the genito-femoral nerve

questions.text:
197. Identify the correct sequence of events during electrical conduction in the heart after the impulse is generated in the SA node.
* Depolarization of endocardium
* Depolarization of epicardium
* Repolarization of epicardium
* Repolarization of endocardium
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1→2→3→4.

Depolarization proceeds from the endocardium to the epicardium in an intact cardiac muscle.

Repolarization of cardiac muscle proceeds from the epicardium to the endocardium.

The sequence of the spread of cardiac excitation is as follows:

After depolarization of the sinoatrial node (SA node), the impulse created travels through both the atria and converges at the atrioventricular node (AV node). The AV node is in the inter-atrial septum. Since the AV nodal conduction is slow, there is a delay before the impulse spreads to the ventricles.

The impulse from the AV node then spreads to the Purkinje fibers, which conduct rapidly to the ventricles. The depolarization of the ventricles starts at the interventricular septum and spreads to the cardiac apex. Thus, depolarization starts from the endocardium and then extends to the epicardium.

In normal conditions, repolarization retraces the path of depolarization and proceeds in the direction opposite to that of depolarization. So, repolarization first takes place in the epicardium and moves towards the endocardium.

questions.text: 198. What is the procedure of choice for the following condition in an elderly female?
questions.solution:
The given image shows eversion of lower lid margin in an aged female with visible fornix. It is suggestive of lower lid severe senile ectropion and the surgical treatment of choice is Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation.

In this surgery, a base up pentagonal full-thickness excision from the lateral third of the eyelid is combined with triangular excision of the skin from the area just lateral to lateral canthus to elevate the lid. 

As a temporary method, taping of the sagging lid can be done

The first image below depicts the important components of this surgery. The second image depicts the taping method. The last image shows the components of medial conjunctivoplasty.







Ectropion: Out rolling or outward turning of the lid margin.

Etiological types:

* Congenital ectropion: Common in Downs syndrome.

* Involutional/Senile ectropion: Age-related laxity of either medial canthus tendon, lateral canthus tendon or horizontal lower lid. It can sometimes be associated with disinsertion of  lower lid retractors.'

* Cicatricial ectropion: Scarring associated with chemical, thermal or lacerating injuries.

* Paralytic ectropion: Due to paralysis of the seventh cranial nerve secondary to infections of the middle ear or iatrogenic during parotid surgery.

* Mechanical ectropion: Due to lower lid tumours or proptosis.

Clinical features:

* The most consistent symptom is epiphora.

* Rarely associated with photophobia and discomfort.

Signs:

Snap test: Lid can be easily pulled away from the globe but fails to snap back to the normal position on release.

Depending upon the degree of outrolling, ectropion can be divided into three grades:

* Grade I: The punctum is everted.

* Grade II: Lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible.

* Grade III: The fornix is also visible

Treatment of senile ectropion:

* Medial conjunctivoplasty: It is useful in mild cases of ectropion involving punctal area.

* Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation

* Horizontal lid shortening

* Lateral tarsal strip technique

Note:

Weis operation (Transverse lid split and everting sutures), Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones procedure), Quickert's procedure (horizontal lid laxity in entropion), Anterior lamellar resection and Tarsal wedge resection are the surgical procedures employed in the correction of entropion.

questions.text: 199. A 30-year-old male patient presents with mildly pruritic plaques in the left axilla for 2 weeks. Wood’s lamp examination showed coral-red fluorescence. What is the first-line therapeutic agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image, along with coral-red fluorescence under Wood’s lamp, is suggestive of erythrasma, which responds well to topical erythromycin.

Relapse can occur. In such cases, long-term topical povidone-iodine application with drying agents can be used. Photodynamic therapy can also be attempted. 

Erythrasma is a mild, chronic, superficial infection of the skin. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It affects the axillae, groins, toe webs, inter-gluteal and submammary regions. Lesions may be symptomless or show mild discomfort and itching.

The lesions may be of irregular shape with sharp margins. They may start as smooth, red patches and then become brown. The lesions are more likely to be pruritic in tropical regions and may be asymptomatic in temperate climate. 

The image below shows erythrasma in the axilla of a patient.



Coral‐red fluorescence with Wood’s light is due to coproporphyrin III and suggests erythrasma. The fluorescence may persist after the eradication of the disease.

Note:

Aluminium chloride antiperspirant is used in trichomycosis axillaris, caused by Corynebacterium tenuis. It is a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of an adherent granular nodule which can be yellow, black, or red in color, on the hair shaft.



Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: 200. A 78-year-old man was found to be dead at his apartment after his neighbors complained of no signs or replies to their calls. He was found to have lost a lot of weight, thinned out, and had no food at his house. There were no signs of robbery or physical struggle. Any attempt to contact his children was not useful and it was decided that post mortem autopsy be done to confirm the cause of death. If starvation is the cause, as suspected, which of the following findings will not be seen on autopsy?
questions.solution:
In starvation, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. So bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder and gets distended.

Starvation:

* Feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30–48 hours.

* Person can survive for 10–12 days without food and water and for 6–8 weeks without food alone.

* Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal.

* Loss of 70–90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal.

* There is reduction in weight and size of all organs except brain.

Other features of starvation:

* Dry, lustreless hair

* Brittle nails 

* Pale skin with edema around ankles

* Loss of fat in subcutaneous tissue, in the omentum  (sparing of fat in female breast and orbit till later)

* Atrophy of muscles and darkening due to lipochrome

* The heart is atrophied with empty chambers

* Pale and collapsed lung

* Shrunken liver with necrosis

* Tissue paper-like intestinal mucosa

* Empty bladder
